Text

MADAME BOVARY

Part I

Chapter One

We were in class when the head-master came in, followed by a

``new fellow,'' (the head-master)
not wearing the school uniform, and a school servant carrying a large desk. Those who had been asleep woke up, and every one rose as if just surprised at his (servant) work.

The head-master made a sign to us to sit down. Then, turning to the class-master, he (servant) said to him (servant) in a low voice--

``Monsieur Roger, here is a pupil whom I recommend to your care; he (Roger)'ll be in the second. If his (Roger) work and conduct are satisfactory, he (Roger) will go into one of the upper classes, as becomes his (Roger) age.'' (him)

The

``new fellow,'' (he)
standing in the corner behind the door so that he (servant) could hardly be seen, was a country lad of about fifteen, and taller than any of us. His (servant) hair was cut square on his (servant) forehead like a village chorister's; he (servant) looked reliable, but very ill at ease. Although he (servant) was not broad-shouldered, his (servant) short school jacket of green cloth with black buttons must have been tight about the arm-holes, and showed at the opening of the cuffs red wrists accustomed to being bare. His (servant) legs, in blue stockings, looked out from beneath yellow trousers, drawn tight by braces, He (servant) wore stout, ill-cleaned, hob-nailed boots.

We began repeating the lesson. He (servant) listened with all his (servant) ears, as attentive as if at a sermon, not daring even to cross his (servant) legs or lean on his (servant) elbow; and when at two o’clock the bell rang, the master was obliged to tell him (master) to fall into line with the rest of us.

When we came back to work, we were in the habit of throwing our caps on the ground so as to have our hands more free; we used from the door to toss them under the form, so that they hit against the wall and made a lot of dust: it was

``the thing.'' (he)

But, whether he (master) had not noticed the trick, or did not dare to attempt it, the

``new fellow,'' (he)
was still holding his (master) cap on his (master) knees even after prayers were over. It was one of those head-gears of composite order, in which we can find traces of the bearskin, shako, billycock hat, sealskin cap, and cotton night-cap; one of those poor things, in fine, whose dumb ugliness has depths of expression, like an imbecile's face. Oval, stiffened with whalebone, it began with three round knobs; then came in succession lozenges of velvet and rabbit-skin separated by a red band; after that a sort of bag that ended in a cardboard polygon covered with complicated braiding, from which hung, at the end of a long thin cord, small twisted gold threads in the manner of a tassel. The cap was new; its peak shone.

``Rise,'' (the master)
said the master.

He (master) stood up; his (master) cap fell. The whole class began to laugh. He (master) stooped to pick it up. A neighbor knocked it down again with his (master) elbow; he (master) picked it up once more.

``Get rid of your helmet,'' (the master bit)
said the master, who was a bit of a wag.

There was a burst of laughter from the boys, which so thoroughly put the poor lad out of countenance that he (lad) did not know whether to keep his (lad) cap in his (lad) hand, leave it on the ground, or put it on his (lad) head. He (lad) sat down again and placed it on his (lad) knee.

``Rise,'' (the master)
repeated the master,
``and tell me your name.'' (the master)

The new boy articulated in a stammering voice an unintelligible name.

``Again!'' (unknown)

The same sputtering of syllables was heard, drowned by the tittering of the class.

``Louder!'' (the master)
cried the master;
``louder!'' (the master)

The

``new fellow'' (someone)
then took a supreme resolution, opened an inordinately large mouth, and shouted at the top of his (master) voice as if calling someone in the word
``Charbovari.'' (someone)

A hubbub broke out, rose in crescendo with bursts of shrill voices -LRB-they yelled, barked, stamped, repeated

``Charbovari! Charbovari'' (a cracker)
-RRB-, then died away into single notes, growing quieter only with great difficulty, and now and again suddenly recommencing along the line of a form whence rose here and there, like a damp cracker going off, a stifled laugh.

However, amid a rain of impositions, order was gradually re-established in the class; and the master having succeeded in catching the name of

``Charles Bovary,'' (the master)
having had it dictated to him (master), spelt out, and re-read, at once ordered the poor devil to go and sit down on the punishment form at the foot of the master's desk. He (master) got up, but before going hesitated.

``What are you looking for?'' (the master)
asked the master.

``My c-a-p,'' (him)
timidly said the
``new fellow,'' (him)
casting troubled looks round him (master).

``Five hundred lines for all the class!'' (unknown)
shouted in a furious voice stopped, like the Quos ego*, a fresh outburst.
``Silence!'' (the master)
continued the master indignantly, wiping his (master) brow with his (master) handkerchief, which he (master) had just taken from his (master) cap.
``As to you, `new boy,' you will conjugate `ridiculus sum' ** twenty times.'' (unknown)

Then, in a gentler tone,

``Come, you'll find your cap again; it hasn't been stolen.'' (unknown)

*A quotation from the Aeneid signifying a threat.

**I am ridiculous.

Quiet was restored. Heads bent over desks, and the

``new fellow'' (unknown)
remained for two hours in an exemplary attitude, although from time to time some paper pellet flipped from the tip of a pen came bang in his (master) face. But he (master) wiped his (master) face with one hand and continued motionless, his (master) eyes lowered.

In the evening, at preparation, he (master) pulled out his (master) pens from his (master) desk, arranged his (master) small belongings, and carefully ruled his (master) paper. We saw him (master) working conscientiously, looking up every word in the dictionary, and taking the greatest pains. Thanks, no doubt, to the willingness he (master) showed, he (master) had not to go down to the class below. But though he (master) knew his (master) rules passably, he (master) had little finish in composition. It was the cure of his (master) village who had taught him (master) his (master) first Latin; his (master) parents, from motives of economy, having sent him (master) to school as late as possible.

His (master) father, Monsieur Charles Denis Bartolome Bovary, retired assistant-surgeon-major, compromised about 1812 in certain conscription scandals, and forced at this time to leave the service, had taken advantage of his (master) fine figure to get hold of a dowry of sixty thousand francs that offered in the person of a hosier's daughter who had fallen in love with his (master) good looks. A fine man, a great talker, making his (man) spurs ring as he (man) walked, wearing whiskers that ran into his (man) moustache, his (man) fingers always garnished with rings and dressed in loud colours, he (man) had the dash of a military man with the easy go of a commercial traveller.

Once married, he (traveller) lived for three or four years on his (traveller) wife's fortune, dining well, rising late, smoking long porcelain pipes, not coming in at night till after the theatre, and haunting cafes. The father-in-law died, leaving little; he (father-in-law) was indignant at this,

``went in for the business,'' (he)
lost some money in it, then retired to the country, where he (father-in-law) thought he (father-in-law) would make money.

But, as he (father-in-law) knew no more about farming than calico, as he (father-in-law) rode his (father-in-law) horses instead of sending them to plough, drank his (father-in-law) cider in bottle instead of selling it in cask, ate the finest poultry in his (father-in-law) farmyard, and greased his (father-in-law) hunting-boots with the fat of his (father-in-law) pigs, he (father-in-law) was not long in finding out that he (father-in-law) would do better to give up all speculation.

For two hundred francs a year he (father-in-law) managed to live on the border of the provinces of Caux and Picardy, in a kind of place half farm, half private house; and here, soured, eaten up with regrets, cursing his (father-in-law) luck, jealous of everyone, he (father-in-law) shut himself up at the age of forty-five, sick of men, he (father-in-law) said, and determined to live at peace.

His (father-in-law) wife had adored him (father-in-law) once on a time; she (wife) had bored him (father-in-law) with a thousand servilities that had only estranged him (father-in-law) the more. Lively once, expansive and affectionate, in growing older she (wife) had become -LRB-after the fashion of wine that, exposed to air, turns to vinegar-RRB- ill-tempered, grumbling, irritable. She (wife) had suffered so much without complaint at first, until she (wife) had seem him (father-in-law) going after all the village drabs, and until a score of bad houses sent him (father-in-law) back to her (wife) at night, weary, stinking drunk. Then her (wife) pride revolted. After that she (wife) was silent, burying her (wife) anger in a dumb stoicism that she (wife) maintained till her (wife) death. She (wife) was constantly going about looking after business matters. She (wife) called on the lawyers, the president, remembered when bills fell due, got them renewed, and at home ironed, sewed, washed, looked after the workmen, paid the accounts, while he (president), troubling himself about nothing, eternally besotted in sleepy sulkiness, whence he (president) only roused himself to say disagreeable things to her (wife), sat smoking by the fire and spitting into the cinders.

When she (wife) had a child, it had to be sent out to nurse. When he (president) came home, the lad was spoilt as if he (lad) were a prince. His (lad) mother stuffed him (lad) with jam; his (lad) father let him (lad) run about barefoot, and, playing the philosopher, even said he (lad) might as well go about quite naked like the young of animals. As opposed to the maternal ideas, he (lad) had a certain virile idea of childhood on which he (lad) sought to mould his (lad) son, wishing him (lad) to be brought up hardily, like a Spartan, to give him (lad) a strong constitution. He (lad) sent him (lad) to bed without any fire, taught him (lad) to drink off large draughts of rum and to jeer at religious processions. But, peaceable by nature, the lad answered only poorly to his (lad) notions. His (lad) mother always kept him (lad) near her (mother); she (mother) cut out cardboard for him (lad), told him (lad) tales, entertained him (lad) with endless monologues full of melancholy gaiety and charming nonsense. In her (mother) life's isolation she (mother) centered on the child's head all her (mother) shattered, broken little vanities. She (mother) dreamed of high station; she (mother) already saw him (lad), tall, handsome, clever, settled as an engineer or in the law. She (mother) taught him (engineer) to read, and even, on an old piano, she (mother) had taught him (engineer) two or three little songs. But to all this Monsieur Bovary, caring little for letters, said,

``It was not worth while. Would they ever have the means to send him (fellow) to a public school, to buy him (fellow) a practice, or start him (fellow) in business? Besides, with cheek a man always gets on in the world.'' (Monsieur Bovary)
Madame Bovary bit her (mother) lips, and the child knocked about the village.

He (engineer) went after the labourers, drove away with clods of earth the ravens that were flying about. He (engineer) ate blackberries along the hedges, minded the geese with a long switch, went haymaking during harvest, ran about in the woods, played hop-scotch under the church porch on rainy days, and at great fetes begged the beadle to let him (beadle) toll the bells, that he (beadle) might hang all his (beadle) weight on the long rope and feel himself borne upward by it in its swing. Meanwhile he (beadle) grew like an oak; he (beadle) was strong on hand, fresh of colour.

When he (beadle) was twelve years old his (beadle) mother had her (mother) own way; he (beadle) began lessons. The cure took him (beadle) in hand; but the lessons were so short and irregular that they could not be of much use. They were given at spare moments in the sacristy, standing up, hurriedly, between a baptism and a burial; or else the cure, if he (beadle) had not to go out, sent for his (beadle) pupil after the Angelus*. They went up to his (beadle) room and settled down; the flies and moths fluttered round the candle. It was close, the child fell asleep, and the good man, beginning to doze with his (man) hands on his (man) stomach, was soon snoring with his (man) mouth wide open. On other occasions, when Monsieur le Cure, on his (man) way back after administering the viaticum to some sick person in the neighbourhood, caught sight of Charles playing about the fields, he (Charles) called him (Charles), lectured him (Charles) for a quarter of an hour and took advantage of the occasion to make him (Charles) conjugate his (Charles) verb at the foot of a tree. The rain interrupted them or an acquaintance passed. All the same he (acquaintance) was always pleased with him (acquaintance), and even said the

``young man'' (him)
had a very good memory.

*A devotion said at morning, noon, and evening, at the sound of a bell. Here, the evening prayer.

Charles could not go on like this. Madame Bovary took strong steps. Ashamed, or rather tired out, Monsieur Bovary gave in without a struggle, and they waited one year longer, so that the lad should take his (lad) first communion.

Six months more passed, and the year after Charles was finally sent to school at Rouen, where his (Charles) father took him (Charles) towards the end of October, at the time of the St. Romain fair.

It would now be impossible for any of us to remember anything about him (Charles). He (Charles) was a youth of even temperament, who played in playtime, worked in school-hours, was attentive in class, slept well in the dormitory, and ate well in the refectory. He (Charles) had in loco parentis* a wholesale ironmonger in the Rue Ganterie, who took him (Charles) out once a month on Sundays after his (Charles) shop was shut, sent him (Charles) for a walk on the quay to look at the boats, and then brought him (Charles) back to college at seven o’clock before supper. Every Thursday evening he (Charles) wrote a long letter to his (Charles) mother with red ink and three wafers; then he (Charles) went over his (Charles) history note-books, or read an old volume of

``Anarchasis'' (he)
that was knocking about the study. When he (Charles) went for walks he (Charles) talked to the servant, who, like himself, came from the country.

*In place of a parent.

By dint of hard work he (Charles) kept always about the middle of the class; once even he (Charles) got a certificate in natural history. But at the end of his (Charles) third year his (Charles) parents withdrew him (Charles) from the school to make him (Charles) study medicine, convinced that he (Charles) could even take his (Charles) degree by himself.

His (Charles) mother chose a room for him (Charles) on the fourth floor of a dyer's she (mother) knew, overlooking the Eau-de-Robec. She (mother) made arrangements for his (Charles) board, got him (Charles) furniture, table and two chairs, sent home for an old cherry-tree bedstead, and bought besides a small cast-iron stove with the supply of wood that was to warm the poor child.

Then at the end of a week she (mother) departed, after a thousand injunctions to be good now that he (Charles) was going to be left to himself.

The syllabus that he (Charles) read on the notice-board stunned him (Charles); lectures on anatomy, lectures on pathology, lectures on physiology, lectures on pharmacy, lectures on botany and clinical medicine, and therapeutics, without counting hygiene and materia medica--all names of whose etymologies he (Charles) was ignorant, and that were to him (Charles) as so many doors to sanctuaries filled with magnificent darkness.

He (Charles) understood nothing of it all; it was all very well to listen--he (Charles) did not follow. Still he (Charles) worked; he (Charles) had bound note-books, he (Charles) attended all the courses, never missed a single lecture. He (Charles) did his (Charles) little daily task like a mill-horse, who goes round and round with his (Charles) eyes bandaged, not knowing what work he (Charles) is doing.

To spare him (Charles) expense his (Charles) mother sent him (Charles) every week by the carrier a piece of veal baked in the oven, with which he (Charles) lunched when he (Charles) came back from the hospital, while he (Charles) sat kicking his (Charles) feet against the wall. After this he (Charles) had to run off to lectures, to the operation-room, to the hospital, and return to his (Charles) home at the other end of the town. In the evening, after the poor dinner of his (Charles) landlord, he (Charles) went back to his (Charles) room and set to work again in his (Charles) wet clothes, which smoked as he (Charles) sat in front of the hot stove.

On the fine summer evenings, at the time when the close streets are empty, when the servants are playing shuttle-cock at the doors, he (Charles) opened his (Charles) window and leaned out. The river, that makes of this quarter of Rouen a wretched little Venice, flowed beneath him (Charles), between the bridges and the railings, yellow, violet, or blue. Working men, kneeling on the banks, washed their bare arms in the water. On poles projecting from the attics, skeins of cotton were drying in the air. Opposite, beyond the roots spread the pure heaven with the red sun setting. How pleasant it must be at home! How fresh under the beech-tree! And he (Charles) expanded his (Charles) nostrils to breathe in the sweet odours of the country which did not reach him (Charles).

He (Charles) grew thin, his (Charles) figure became taller, his (Charles) face took a saddened look that made it nearly interesting. Naturally, through indifference, he (Charles) abandoned all the resolutions he (Charles) had made. Once he (Charles) missed a lecture; the next day all the lectures; and, enjoying his (Charles) idleness, little by little, he (Charles) gave up work altogether. He (Charles) got into the habit of going to the public-house, and had a passion for dominoes. To shut himself up every evening in the dirty public room, to push about on marble tables the small sheep bones with black dots, seemed to him (Charles) a fine proof of his (Charles) freedom, which raised him (Charles) in his (Charles) own esteem. It was beginning to see life, the sweetness of stolen pleasures; and when he (Charles) entered, he (Charles) put his (Charles) hand on the door-handle with a joy almost sensual. Then many things hidden within him (Charles) came out; he (Charles) learnt couplets by heart and sang them to his (Charles) boon companions, became enthusiastic about Beranger, learnt how to make punch, and, finally, how to make love.

Thanks to these preparatory labours, he (Charles) failed completely in his (Charles) examination for an ordinary degree. He (Charles) was expected home the same night to celebrate his (Charles) success. He (Charles) started on foot, stopped at the beginning of the village, sent for his (Charles) mother, and told her (mother) all. She (mother) excused him (Charles), threw the blame of his (Charles) failure on the injustice of the examiners, encouraged him (Charles) a little, and took upon herself to set matters straight. It was only five years later that Monsieur Bovary knew the truth; it was old then, and he (Charles) accepted it. Moreover, he (Charles) could not believe that a man born of him (Charles) could be a fool.

So Charles set to work again and crammed for his (Charles) examination, ceaselessly learning all the old questions by heart. He (Charles) passed pretty well. What a happy day for his (Charles) mother! They gave a grand dinner.

Where should he (Charles) go to practice? To Tostes, where there was only one old doctor. For a long time Madame Bovary had been on the look-out for his (doctor) death, and the old fellow had barely been packed off when Charles was installed, opposite his (Charles) place, as his (Charles) successor.

But it was not everything to have brought up a son, to have had him (Charles) taught medicine, and discovered Tostes, where he (Charles) could practice it; he (Charles) must have a wife. She (wife) found him (Charles) one--the widow of a bailiff at Dieppe--who was forty-five and had an income of twelve hundred francs. Though she (wife) was ugly, as dry as a bone, her (wife) face with as many pimples as the spring has buds, Madame Dubuc had no lack of suitors. To attain her (wife) ends Madame Bovary had to oust them all, and she (wife) even succeeded in very cleverly baffling the intrigues of a port-butcher backed up by the priests.

Charles had seen in marriage the advent of an easier life, thinking he (Charles) would be more free to do as he (Charles) liked with himself and his (Charles) money. But his (Charles) wife was master; he (Charles) had to say this and not say that in company, to fast every Friday, dress as she (wife) liked, harass at her (wife) bidding those patients who did not pay. She (wife) opened his (Charles) letter, watched his (Charles) comings and goings, and listened at the partition-wall when women came to consult him (Charles) in his (Charles) surgery.

She (wife) must have her (wife) chocolate every morning, attentions without end. She (wife) constantly complained of her (wife) nerves, her (wife) chest, her (wife) liver. The noise of footsteps made her (wife) ill; when people left her (wife), solitude became odious to her (wife); if they came back, it was doubtless to see her (wife) die. When Charles returned in the evening, she (wife) stretched forth two long thin arms from beneath the sheets, put them round his (Charles) neck, and having made him (Charles) sit down on the edge of the bed, began to talk to him (Charles) of her (wife) troubles: he (Charles) was neglecting her (wife), he (Charles) loved another. She (wife) had been warned she (wife) would be unhappy; and she (wife) ended by asking him (Charles) for a dose of medicine and a little more love.

Chapter Two

One night towards eleven o’clock they were awakened by the noise of a horse pulling up outside their door. The servant opened the garret-window and parleyed for some time with a man in the street below. He (man) came for the doctor, had a letter for him (man). Natasie came downstairs shivering and undid the bars and bolts one after the other. The man left his (man) horse, and, following the servant, suddenly came in behind her (wife). He (man) pulled out from his (man) wool cap with grey top-knots a letter wrapped up in a rag and presented it gingerly to Charles, who rested on his (Charles) elbow on the pillow to read it. Natasie, standing near the bed, held the light. Madame in modesty had turned to the wall and showed only her (wife) back.

This letter, sealed with a small seal in blue wax, begged Monsieur Bovary to come immediately to the farm of the Bertaux to set a broken leg. Now from Tostes to the Bertaux was a good eighteen miles across country by way of Longueville and Saint-Victor. It was a dark night; Madame Bovary junior was afraid of accidents for her (wife) husband. So it was decided the stable-boy should go on first; Charles would start three hours later when the moon rose. A boy was to be sent to meet him (boy), and show him (boy) the way to the farm, and open the gates for him (boy).

Towards four o’clock in the morning, Charles, well wrapped up in his (Charles) cloak, set out for the Bertaux. Still sleepy from the warmth of his (Charles) bed, he (Charles) let himself be lulled by the quiet trot of his (Charles) horse. When it stopped of its own accord in front of those holes surrounded with thorns that are dug on the margin of furrows, Charles awoke with a start, suddenly remembered the broken leg, and tried to call to mind all the fractures he (Charles) knew. The rain had stopped, day was breaking, and on the branches of the leafless trees birds roosted motionless, their little feathers bristling in the cold morning wind. The flat country stretched as far as eye could see, and the tufts of trees round the farms at long intervals seemed like dark violet stains on the cast grey surface, that on the horizon faded into the gloom of the sky.

Charles from time to time opened his (Charles) eyes, his (Charles) mind grew weary, and, sleep coming upon him (Charles), he (Charles) soon fell into a doze wherein, his (Charles) recent sensations blending with memories, he (Charles) became conscious of a double self, at once student and married man, lying in his (man) bed as but now, and crossing the operation theatre as of old. The warm smell of poultices mingled in his (man) brain with the fresh odour of dew; he (man) heard the iron rings rattling along the curtain-rods of the bed and saw his (man) wife sleeping. As he (man) passed Vassonville he (man) came upon a boy sitting on the grass at the edge of a ditch.

``Are you the doctor?'' (the child)
asked the child.

And on Charles's answer he (Charles) took his (Charles) wooden shoes in his (Charles) hands and ran on in front of him (Charles).

The general practitioner, riding along, gathered from his (Charles) guide's talk that Monsieur Rouault must be one of the well-to-do farmers.

He (Rouault) had broken his (Rouault) leg the evening before on his (Rouault) way home from a Twelfth-night feast at a neighbour's. His (Rouault) wife had been dead for two years. There was with him (Rouault) only his (Rouault) daughter, who helped him (Rouault) to keep house.

The ruts were becoming deeper; they were approaching the Bertaux.

The little lad, slipping through a hole in the hedge, disappeared; then he (lad) came back to the end of a courtyard to open the gate. The horse slipped on the wet grass; Charles had to stoop to pass under the branches. The watchdogs in their kennels barked, dragging at their chains. As he (Charles) entered the Bertaux, the horse took fright and stumbled.

It was a substantial-looking farm. In the stables, over the top of the open doors, one could see great cart-horses quietly feeding from new racks. Right along the outbuildings extended a large dunghill, from which manure liquid oozed, while amidst fowls and turkeys, five or six peacocks, a luxury in Chauchois farmyards, were foraging on the top of it. The sheepfold was long, the barn high, with walls smooth as your hand. Under the cart-shed were two large carts and four ploughs, with their whips, shafts and harnesses complete, whose fleeces of blue wool were getting soiled by the fine dust that fell from the granaries. The courtyard sloped upwards, planted with trees set out symmetrically, and the chattering noise of a flock of geese was heard near the pond.

A young woman in a blue merino dress with three flounces came to the threshold of the door to receive Monsieur Bovary, whom she (woman) led to the kitchen, where a large fire was blazing. The servant's breakfast was boiling beside it in small pots of all sizes. Some damp clothes were drying inside the chimney-corner. The shovel, tongs, and the nozzle of the bellows, all of colossal size, shone like polished steel, while along the walls hung many pots and pans in which the clear flame of the hearth, mingling with the first rays of the sun coming in through the window, was mirrored fitfully.

Charles went up the first floor to see the patient. He (Charles) found him (Charles) in his (Charles) bed, sweating under his (Charles) bed-clothes, having thrown his (Charles) cotton nightcap right away from him (Charles). He (Charles) was a fat little man of fifty, with white skin and blue eyes, the forepart of his (Charles) head bald, and he (Charles) wore earrings. By his (Charles) side on a chair stood a large decanter of brandy, whence he (Charles) poured himself a little from time to time to keep up his (Charles) spirits; but as soon as he (Charles) caught sight of the doctor his (Charles) elation subsided, and instead of swearing, as he (Charles) had been doing for the last twelve hours, began to groan freely.

The fracture was a simple one, without any kind of complication.

Charles could not have hoped for an easier case. Then calling to mind the devices of his (Charles) masters at the bedsides of patients, he (Charles) comforted the sufferer with all sorts of kindly remarks, those caresses of the surgeon that are like the oil they put on bistouries. In order to make some splints a bundle of laths was brought up from the cart-house. Charles selected one, cut it into two pieces and planed it with a fragment of windowpane, while the servant tore up sheets to make bandages, and Mademoiselle Emma tried to sew some pads. As she (Emma) was a long time before she (Emma) found her (Emma) work-case, her (Emma) father grew impatient; she (Emma) did not answer, but as she (Emma) sewed she (Emma) pricked her (Emma) fingers, which she (Emma) then put to her (Emma) mouth to suck them. Charles was surprised at the whiteness of her (Emma) nails. They were shiny, delicate at the tips, more polished than the ivory of Dieppe, and almond-shaped. Yet her (Emma) hand was not beautiful, perhaps not white enough, and a little hard at the knuckles; besides, it was too long, with no soft inflections in the outlines. Her (Emma) real beauty was in her (Emma) eyes. Although brown, they seemed black because of the lashes, and her (Emma) look came at you frankly, with a candid boldness.

The bandaging over, the doctor was invited by Monsieur Rouault himself to

``pick a bit'' (Rouault/Monsieur Rouault/Monsieur)
before he (Rouault) left.

Charles went down into the room on the ground floor. Knives and forks and silver goblets were laid for two on a little table at the foot of a huge bed that had a canopy of printed cotton with figures representing Turks. There was an odour of iris-root and damp sheets that escaped from a large oak chest opposite the window. On the floor in corners were sacks of flour stuck upright in rows. These were the overflow from the neighbouring granary, to which three stone steps led. By way of decoration for the apartment, hanging to a nail in the middle of the wall, whose green paint scaled off from the effects of the saltpetre, was a crayon head of Minerva in gold frame, underneath which was written in Gothic letters

``To dear Papa.'' (Minerva)

First they spoke of the patient, then of the weather, of the great cold, of the wolves that infested the fields at night.

Mademoiselle Rouault did not at all like the country, especially now that she (Minerva) had to look after the farm almost alone. As the room was chilly, she (Minerva) shivered as she (Minerva) ate. This showed something of her (Minerva) full lips, that she (Minerva) had a habit of biting when silent.

Her (Minerva) neck stood out from a white turned-down collar. Her (Minerva) hair, whose two black folds seemed each of a single piece, so smooth were they, was parted in the middle by a delicate line that curved slightly with the curve of the head; and, just showing the tip of the ear, it was joined behind in a thick chignon, with a wavy movement at the temples that the country doctor saw now for the first time in his (doctor) life. The upper part of her (Minerva) cheek was rose-coloured. She (Minerva) had, like a man, thrust in between two buttons of her (Minerva) bodice a tortoise-shell eyeglass.

When Charles, after bidding farewell to old Rouault, returned to the room before leaving, he (Rouault) found her (Minerva) standing, her (Minerva) forehead against the window, looking into the garden, where the bean props had been knocked down by the wind. She (Minerva) turned round.

``Are you looking for anything?'' (she)
she (Minerva) asked.

``My whip, if you please,'' (he)
he (Rouault) answered.

He (Rouault) began rummaging on the bed, behind the doors, under the chairs. It had fallen to the floor, between the sacks and the wall. Mademoiselle Emma saw it, and bent over the flour sacks.

Charles out of politeness made a dash also, and as he (Charles) stretched out his (Charles) arm, at the same moment felt his (Charles) breast brush against the back of the young girl bending beneath him (Charles). She (girl) drew herself up, scarlet, and looked at him (Charles) over her (girl) shoulder as she (girl) handed him (Charles) his (Charles) whip.

Instead of returning to the Bertaux in three days as he (Charles) had promised, he (Charles) went back the very next day, then regularly twice a week, without counting the visits he (Charles) paid now and then as if by accident.

Everything, moreover, went well; the patient progressed favourably; and when, at the end of forty-six days, old Rouault was seen trying to walk alone in his (Rouault)

``den,'' (Rouault/Monsieur Rouault/Monsieur)
Monsieur Bovary began to be looked upon as a man of great capacity. Old Rouault said that he (Rouault) could not have been cured better by the first doctor of Yvetot, or even of Rouen.

As to Charles, he (Charles) did not stop to ask himself why it was a pleasure to him (Charles) to go to the Bertaux. Had he (Charles) done so, he (Charles) would, no doubt, have attributed his (Charles) zeal to the importance of the case, or perhaps to the money he (Charles) hoped to make by it. Was it for this, however, that his (Charles) visits to the farm formed a delightful exception to the meagre occupations of his (Charles) life? On these days he (Charles) rose early, set off at a gallop, urging on his (Charles) horse, then got down to wipe his (Charles) boots in the grass and put on black gloves before entering. He (Charles) liked going into the courtyard, and noticing the gate turn against his (Charles) shoulder, the cock crow on the wall, the lads run to meet him (Charles). He (Charles) liked the granary and the stables; he (Charles) liked old Rouault, who pressed his (Rouault) hand and called him (Rouault) his (Rouault) saviour; he (Rouault) liked the small wooden shoes of Mademoiselle Emma on the scoured flags of the kitchen--her (Emma) high heels made her (Emma) a little taller; and when she (Emma) walked in front of him (Rouault), the wooden soles springing up quickly struck with a sharp sound against the leather of her (Emma) boots.

She (Emma) always accompanied him (Rouault) to the first step of the stairs. When his (Rouault) horse had not yet been brought round she (Emma) stayed there. They had said

``Good-bye'' (unknown)
; there was no more talking. The open air wrapped her (Emma) round, playing with the soft down on the back of her (Emma) neck, or blew to and fro on her (Emma) hips the apron-strings, that fluttered like streamers. Once, during a thaw the bark of the trees in the yard was oozing, the snow on the roofs of the outbuildings was melting; she (Emma) stood on the threshold, and went to fetch her (Emma) sunshade and opened it. The sunshade of silk of the colour of pigeons' breasts, through which the sun shone, lighted up with shifting hues the white skin of her (Emma) face. She (Emma) smiled under the tender warmth, and drops of water could be heard falling one by one on the stretched silk.

During the first period of Charles's visits to the Bertaux, Madame Bovary junior never failed to inquire after the invalid, and she (Emma) had even chosen in the book that she (Emma) kept on a system of double entry a clean blank page for Monsieur Rouault. But when she (Emma) heard he (Rouault) had a daughter, she (Emma) began to make inquiries, and she (Emma) learnt the Mademoiselle Rouault, brought up at the Ursuline Convent, had received what is called

``a good education'' (Mademoiselle Rouault)
; and so knew dancing, geography, drawing, how to embroider and play the piano. That was the last straw.

``So it is for this,'' (she)
she (Emma) said to herself,
``that his (Papa) face beams when he (Papa) goes to see her (it), and that he (Papa) puts on his (Papa) new waistcoat at the risk of spoiling it with the rain. Ah! that woman! That woman!'' (she)

And she (Emma) detested her (Emma) instinctively. At first she (Emma) solaced herself by allusions that Charles did not understand, then by casual observations that he (Charles) let pass for fear of a storm, finally by open apostrophes to which he (Charles) knew not what to answer.

``Why did he (Papa) go back to the Bertaux now that Monsieur Rouault was cured and that these folks hadn't paid yet? Ah! it was because a young lady was there, some one who know how to talk, to embroider, to be witty. That was what he (Rouault) cared about; he (Rouault) wanted town misses.'' (she)
And she (Emma) went on--

``The daughter of old Rouault a town miss! Get out! Their grandfather was a shepherd, and they have a cousin who was almost had up at the assizes for a nasty blow in a quarrel. It is not worth while making such a fuss, or showing herself at church on Sundays in a silk gown like a countess. Besides, the poor old chap, if it hadn't been for the colza last year, would have had much ado to pay up his (chap) arrears.'' (she)

For very weariness Charles left off going to the Bertaux. Heloise made him (Charles) swear, his (Charles) hand on the prayer-book, that he (Charles) would go there no more after much sobbing and many kisses, in a great outburst of love. He (Charles) obeyed then, but the strength of his (Charles) desire protested against the servility of his (Charles) conduct; and he (Charles) thought, with a kind of naive hypocrisy, that his (Charles) interdict to see her (Heloise) gave him (Charles) a sort of right to love her (Heloise). And then the widow was thin; she (Heloise) had long teeth; wore in all weathers a little black shawl, the edge of which hung down between her (Heloise) shoulder-blades; her (Heloise) bony figure was sheathed in her (Heloise) clothes as if they were a scabbard; they were too short, and displayed her (Heloise) ankles with the laces of her (Heloise) large boots crossed over grey stockings.

Charles's mother came to see them from time to time, but after a few days the daughter-in-law seemed to put her (daughter-in-law) own edge on her (daughter-in-law), and then, like two knives, they scarified him (Charles) with their reflections and observations. It was wrong of him (Charles) to eat so much.

Why did he (Charles) always offer a glass of something to everyone who came? What obstinacy not to wear flannels! In the spring it came about that a notary at Ingouville, the holder of the widow Dubuc's property, one fine day went off, taking with him (Dubuc) all the money in his (Dubuc) office. Heloise, it is true, still possessed, besides a share in a boat valued at six thousand francs, her (Heloise) house in the Rue St. Francois; and yet, with all this fortune that had been so trumpeted abroad, nothing, excepting perhaps a little furniture and a few clothes, had appeared in the household. The matter had to be gone into. The house at Dieppe was found to be eaten up with mortgages to its foundations; what she (Heloise) had placed with the notary God only knew, and her (Heloise) share in the boat did not exceed one thousand crowns. She (Heloise) had lied, the good lady! In his (God) exasperation, Monsieur Bovary the elder, smashing a chair on the flags, accused his (God) wife of having caused misfortune to the son by harnessing him (God) to such a harridan, whose harness wasn't worth her (wife) hide. They came to Tostes. Explanations followed. There were scenes. Heloise in tears, throwing her (Heloise) arms about her (Heloise) husband, implored him (husband) to defend her (Heloise) from his (husband) parents.

Charles tried to speak up for her (Heloise). They grew angry and left the house.

But

``the blow had struck home.'' (she)
A week after, as she (Heloise) was hanging up some washing in her (Heloise) yard, she (Heloise) was seized with a spitting of blood, and the next day, while Charles had his (Charles) back turned to her (Heloise) drawing the window-curtain, she (Heloise) said,
``O God!'' (she)
gave a sigh and fainted. She (Heloise) was dead! What a surprise! When all was over at the cemetery Charles went home. He (Charles) found no one downstairs; he (Charles) went up to the first floor to their room; saw her (Heloise) dress still hanging at the foot of the alcove; then, leaning against the writing-table, he (Charles) stayed until the evening, buried in a sorrowful reverie. She (Heloise) had loved him (Charles) after all!

Chapter Three

One morning old Rouault brought Charles the money for setting his (Charles) leg--seventy-five francs in forty-sou pieces, and a turkey. He (Charles) had heard of his (Charles) loss, and consoled him (Charles) as well as he (Charles) could.

``I know what it is,'' (he)
said he (Charles), clapping him (Charles) on the shoulder;
``I've been through it. When I lost my dear departed, I went into the fields to be quite alone. I fell at the foot of a tree; I cried; I called on God; I talked nonsense to Him (God). I wanted to be like the moles that I saw on the branches, their insides swarming with worms, dead, and an end of it. And when I thought that there were others at that very moment with their nice little wives holding them in their embrace, I struck great blows on the earth with my stick. I was pretty well mad with not eating; the very idea of going to a cafe disgusted me--you wouldn't believe it. Well, quite softly, one day following another, a spring on a winter, and an autumn after a summer, this wore away, piece by piece, crumb by crumb; it passed away, it is gone, I should say it has sunk; for something always remains at the bottom as one would say--a weight here, at one's heart. But since it is the lot of all of us, one must not give way altogether, and, because others have died, want to die too. You must pull yourself together, Monsieur Bovary. It will pass away. Come to see us; my daughter thinks of you now and again, d’ye know, and she (daughter) says you are forgetting her (daughter). Spring will soon be here. We'll have some rabbit-shooting in the warrens to amuse you a bit.'' (him)

Charles followed his (Charles) advice. He (Charles) went back to the Bertaux. He (Charles) found all as he (Charles) had left it, that is to say, as it was five months ago. The pear trees were already in blossom, and Farmer Rouault, on his (Farmer) legs again, came and went, making the farm more full of life.

Thinking it his (Farmer) duty to heap the greatest attention upon the doctor because of his (Farmer) sad position, he (Farmer) begged him (Farmer) not to take his (Farmer) hat off, spoke to him (Farmer) in an undertone as if he (Farmer) had been ill, and even pretended to be angry because nothing rather lighter had been prepared for him (Farmer) than for the others, such as a little clotted cream or stewed pears. He (Farmer) told stories. Charles found himself laughing, but the remembrance of his (Charles) wife suddenly coming back to him (Charles) depressed him (Charles). Coffee was brought in; he (Charles) thought no more about her (wife).

He (Charles) thought less of her (wife) as he (Charles) grew accustomed to living alone. The new delight of independence soon made his (Charles) loneliness bearable. He (Charles) could now change his (Charles) meal-times, go in or out without explanation, and when he (Charles) was very tired stretch himself at full length on his (Charles) bed. So he (Charles) nursed and coddled himself and accepted the consolations that were offered him (Charles). On the other hand, the death of his (Charles) wife had not served him (Charles) ill in his (Charles) business, since for a month people had been saying,

``The poor young man! what a loss!'' (a month people)
His (Charles) name had been talked about, his (Charles) practice had increased; and moreover, he (Charles) could go to the Bertaux just as he (Charles) liked. He (Charles) had an aimless hope, and was vaguely happy; he (Charles) thought himself better looking as he (Charles) brushed his (Charles) whiskers before the looking-glass.

One day he (Charles) got there about three o’clock. Everybody was in the fields. He (Charles) went into the kitchen, but did not at once catch sight of Emma; the outside shutters were closed. Through the chinks of the wood the sun sent across the flooring long fine rays that were broken at the corners of the furniture and trembled along the ceiling. Some flies on the table were crawling up the glasses that had been used, and buzzing as they drowned themselves in the dregs of the cider. The daylight that came in by the chimney made velvet of the soot at the back of the fireplace, and touched with blue the cold cinders. Between the window and the hearth Emma was sewing; she (Emma) wore no fichu; he (Emma) could see small drops of perspiration on her (Emma) bare shoulders.

After the fashion of country folks she (Emma) asked him (Emma) to have something to drink. He (Emma) said no; she (Emma) insisted, and at last laughingly offered to have a glass of liqueur with him (Emma). So she (Emma) went to fetch a bottle of curacao from the cupboard, reached down two small glasses, filled one to the brim, poured scarcely anything into the other, and, after having clinked glasses, carried hers to her (Emma) mouth. As it was almost empty she (Emma) bent back to drink, her (Emma) head thrown back, her (Emma) lips pouting, her (Emma) neck on the strain. She (Emma) laughed at getting none of it, while with the tip of her (Emma) tongue passing between her (Emma) small teeth she (Emma) licked drop by drop the bottom of her (Emma) glass.

She (Emma) sat down again and took up her (Emma) work, a white cotton stocking she (Emma) was darning. She (Emma) worked with her (Emma) head bent down; she (Emma) did not speak, nor did Charles. The air coming in under the door blew a little dust over the flags; he (Charles) watched it drift along, and heard nothing but the throbbing in his (Charles) head and the faint clucking of a hen that had laid an egg in the yard. Emma from time to time cooled her (Emma) cheeks with the palms of her (Emma) hands, and cooled these again on the knobs of the huge fire-dogs.

She (Emma) complained of suffering since the beginning of the season from giddiness; she (Emma) asked if sea-baths would do her (Emma) any good; she (Emma) began talking of her (Emma) convent, Charles of his (Charles) school; words came to them. They went up into her (Emma) bedroom. She (Emma) showed him (Charles) her (Emma) old music-books, the little prizes she (Emma) had won, and the oak-leaf crowns, left at the bottom of a cupboard. She (Emma) spoke to him (Charles), too, of her (Emma) mother, of the country, and even showed him (Charles) the bed in the garden where, on the first Friday of every month, she (Emma) gathered flowers to put on her (Emma) mother's tomb. But the gardener they had never knew anything about it; servants are so stupid! She (Emma) would have dearly liked, if only for the winter, to live in town, although the length of the fine days made the country perhaps even more wearisome in the summer. And, according to what she (Emma) was saying, her (Emma) voice was clear, sharp, or, on a sudden all languor, drawn out in modulations that ended almost in murmurs as she (Emma) spoke to herself, now joyous, opening big naive eyes, then with her (Emma) eyelids half closed, her (Emma) look full of boredom, her (Emma) thoughts wandering.

Going home at night, Charles went over her (Emma) words one by one, trying to recall them, to fill out their sense, that he (Charles) might piece out the life she (Emma) had lived before he (Charles) knew her (Emma). But he (Charles) never saw her (Emma) in his (Charles) thoughts other than he (Charles) had seen her (Emma) the first time, or as he (Charles) had just left her (Emma). Then he (Charles) asked himself what would become of her (Emma)--if she (Emma) would be married, and to whom! Alas! Old Rouault was rich, and she (Emma)!--so beautiful! But Emma's face always rose before his (Rouault) eyes, and a monotone, like the humming of a top, sounded in his (Rouault) ears,

``If you should marry after all! If you should marry!'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
At night he (Rouault) could not sleep; his (Rouault) throat was parched; he (Rouault) was athirst. He (Rouault) got up to drink from the water-bottle and opened the window. The night was covered with stars, a warm wind blowing in the distance; the dogs were barking. He (Rouault) turned his (Rouault) head towards the Bertaux.

Thinking that, after all, he (Rouault) should lose nothing, Charles promised himself to ask her (Emma) in marriage as soon as occasion offered, but each time such occasion did offer the fear of not finding the right words sealed his (Charles) lips.

Old Rouault would not have been sorry to be rid of his (Rouault) daughter, who was of no use to him (Rouault) in the house. In his (Rouault) heart he (Rouault) excused her (daughter), thinking her (daughter) too clever for farming, a calling under the ban of Heaven, since one never saw a millionaire in it. Far from having made a fortune by it, the good man was losing every year; for if he (man) was good in bargaining, in which he (man) enjoyed the dodges of the trade, on the other hand, agriculture properly so called, and the internal management of the farm, suited him (man) less than most people. He (man) did not willingly take his (man) hands out of his (man) pockets, and did not spare expense in all that concerned himself, liking to eat well, to have good fires, and to sleep well. He (man) liked old cider, underdone legs of mutton, glorias* well beaten up. He (man) took his (man) meals in the kitchen alone, opposite the fire, on a little table brought to him (man) all ready laid as on the stage.

*A mixture of coffee and spirits.

When, therefore, he (man) perceived that Charles's cheeks grew red if near his (man) daughter, which meant that he (man) would propose for her (daughter) one of these days, he (man) chewed the cud of the matter beforehand. He (man) certainly thought him (man) a little meagre, and not quite the son-in-law he (man) would have liked, but he (man) was said to be well brought-up, economical, very learned, and no doubt would not make too many difficulties about the dowry. Now, as old Rouault would soon be forced to sell twenty-two acres of

``his (man) property,'' (Rouault/Monsieur Rouault/Monsieur)
as he (Rouault) owed a good deal to the mason, to the harness-maker, and as the shaft of the cider-press wanted renewing,
``If he (man) asks for her (daughter),'' (the mason)
he (Rouault) said to himself,
``I'll give her (daughter) to him (man).'' (he)

At Michaelmas Charles went to spend three days at the Bertaux.

The last had passed like the others in procrastinating from hour to hour. Old Rouault was seeing him (Rouault) off; they were walking along the road full of ruts; they were about to part. This was the time. Charles gave himself as far as to the corner of the hedge, and at last, when past it--

``Monsieur Rouault,'' (Charles)
he (Charles) murmured,
``I should like to say something to you.'' (he)

They stopped. Charles was silent.

``Well, tell me your story. Don't I know all about it?'' (Rouault/Monsieur Rouault/Monsieur)
said old Rouault, laughing softly.

``Monsieur Rouault--Monsieur Rouault,'' (Charles)
stammered Charles.

``I ask nothing better'' (the farmer)
, the farmer went on.
``Although, no doubt, the little one is of my mind, still we must ask her (daughter) opinion. So you get off--I'll go back home. If it is `yes', you needn't return because of all the people about, and besides it would upset her (daughter) too much. But so that you mayn't be eating your heart, I'll open wide the outer shutter of the window against the wall; you can see it from the back by leaning over the hedge.'' (he)

And he (Charles) went off.

Charles fastened his (Charles) horse to a tree; he (Charles) ran into the road and waited. Half an hour passed, then he (Charles) counted nineteen minutes by his (Charles) watch. Suddenly a noise was heard against the wall; the shutter had been thrown back; the hook was still swinging.

The next day by nine o’clock he (Charles) was at the farm. Emma blushed as he (Charles) entered, and she (Emma) gave a little forced laugh to keep herself in countenance. Old Rouault embraced his (Rouault) future son-in-law. The discussion of money matters was put off; moreover, there was plenty of time before them, as the marriage could not decently take place till Charles was out of mourning, that is to say, about the spring of the next year.

The winter passed waiting for this. Mademoiselle Rouault was busy with her (Emma) trousseau. Part of it was ordered at Rouen, and she (Emma) made herself chemises and nightcaps after fashion-plates that she (Emma) borrowed. When Charles visited the farmer, the preparations for the wedding were talked over; they wondered in what room they should have dinner; they dreamed of the number of dishes that would be wanted, and what should be entrees.

Emma would, on the contrary, have preferred to have a midnight wedding with torches, but old Rouault could not understand such an idea. So there was a wedding at which forty-three persons were present, at which they remained sixteen hours at table, began again the next day, and to some extent on the days following.

Chapter Four

The guests arrived early in carriages, in one-horse chaises, two-wheeled cars, old open gigs, waggonettes with leather hoods, and the young people from the nearer villages in carts, in which they stood up in rows, holding on to the sides so as not to fall, going at a trot and well shaken up. Some came from a distance of thirty miles, from Goderville, from Normanville, and from Cany.

All the relatives of both families had been invited, quarrels between friends arranged, acquaintances long since lost sight of written to.

From time to time one heard the crack of a whip behind the hedge; then the gates opened, a chaise entered. Galloping up to the foot of the steps, it stopped short and emptied its load. They got down from all sides, rubbing knees and stretching arms. The ladies, wearing bonnets, had on dresses in the town fashion, gold watch chains, pelerines with the ends tucked into belts, or little coloured fichus fastened down behind with a pin, and that left the back of the neck bare. The lads, dressed like their papas, seemed uncomfortable in their new clothes -LRB-many that day hand-sewed their first pair of boots-RRB-, and by their sides, speaking never a work, wearing the white dress of their first communion lengthened for the occasion were some big girls of fourteen or sixteen, cousins or elder sisters no doubt, rubicund, bewildered, their hair greasy with rose pomade, and very much afraid of dirtying their gloves. As there were not enough stable-boys to unharness all the carriages, the gentlemen turned up their sleeves and set about it themselves. According to their different social positions they wore tail-coats, overcoats, shooting jackets, cutaway-coats; fine tail-coats, redolent of family respectability, that only came out of the wardrobe on state occasions; overcoats with long tails flapping in the wind and round capes and pockets like sacks; shooting jackets of coarse cloth, generally worn with a cap with a brass-bound peak; very short cutaway-coats with two small buttons in the back, close together like a pair of eyes, and the tails of which seemed cut out of one piece by a carpenter's hatchet. Some, too -LRB-but these, you may be sure, would sit at the bottom of the table-RRB-, wore their best blouses--that is to say, with collars turned down to the shoulders, the back gathered into small plaits and the waist fastened very low down with a worked belt.

And the shirts stood out from the chests like cuirasses! Everyone had just had his (carpenter) hair cut; ears stood out from the heads; they had been close-shaved; a few, even, who had had to get up before daybreak, and not been able to see to shave, had diagonal gashes under their noses or cuts the size of a three-franc piece along the jaws, which the fresh air en route had enflamed, so that the great white beaming faces were mottled here and there with red dabs.

The mairie was a mile and a half from the farm, and they went thither on foot, returning in the same way after the ceremony in the church. The procession, first united like one long coloured scarf that undulated across the fields, along the narrow path winding amid the green corn, soon lengthened out, and broke up into different groups that loitered to talk. The fiddler walked in front with his (fiddler) violin, gay with ribbons at its pegs. Then came the married pair, the relations, the friends, all following pell-mell; the children stayed behind amusing themselves plucking the bell-flowers from oat-ears, or playing amongst themselves unseen. Emma's dress, too long, trailed a little on the ground; from time to time she (Emma) stopped to pull it up, and then delicately, with her (Emma) gloved hands, she (Emma) picked off the coarse grass and the thistledowns, while Charles, empty handed, waited till she (Emma) had finished. Old Rouault, with a new silk hat and the cuffs of his (Rouault) black coat covering his (Rouault) hands up to the nails, gave his (Rouault) arm to Madame Bovary senior. As to Monsieur Bovary senior, who, heartily despising all these folk, had come simply in a frock-coat of military cut with one row of buttons--he (Rouault) was passing compliments of the bar to a fair young peasant. She (Emma) bowed, blushed, and did not know what to say. The other wedding guests talked of their business or played tricks behind each other's backs, egging one another on in advance to be jolly. Those who listened could always catch the squeaking of the fiddler, who went on playing across the fields. When he (fiddler) saw that the rest were far behind he (fiddler) stopped to take breath, slowly rosined his (fiddler) bow, so that the strings should sound more shrilly, then set off again, by turns lowering and raising his (fiddler) neck, the better to mark time for himself. The noise of the instrument drove away the little birds from afar.

The table was laid under the cart-shed. On it were four sirloins, six chicken fricassees, stewed veal, three legs of mutton, and in the middle a fine roast suckling pig, flanked by four chitterlings with sorrel. At the corners were decanters of brandy. Sweet bottled-cider frothed round the corks, and all the glasses had been filled to the brim with wine beforehand. Large dishes of yellow cream, that trembled with the least shake of the table, had designed on their smooth surface the initials of the newly wedded pair in nonpareil arabesques. A confectioner of Yvetot had been intrusted with the tarts and sweets. As he (their) had only just set up on the place, he (their) had taken a lot of trouble, and at dessert he (their) himself brought in a set dish that evoked loud cries of wonderment. To begin with, at its base there was a square of blue cardboard, representing a temple with porticoes, colonnades, and stucco statuettes all round, and in the niches constellations of gilt paper stars; then on the second stage was a dungeon of Savoy cake, surrounded by many fortifications in candied angelica, almonds, raisins, and quarters of oranges; and finally, on the upper platform a green field with rocks set in lakes of jam, nutshell boats, and a small Cupid balancing himself in a chocolate swing whose two uprights ended in real roses for balls at the top.

Until night they ate. When any of them were too tired of sitting, they went out for a stroll in the yard, or for a game with corks in the granary, and then returned to table. Some towards the finish went to sleep and snored. But with the coffee everyone woke up. Then they began songs, showed off tricks, raised heavy weights, performed feats with their fingers, then tried lifting carts on their shoulders, made broad jokes, kissed the women. At night when they left, the horses, stuffed up to the nostrils with oats, could hardly be got into the shafts; they kicked, reared, the harness broke, their masters laughed or swore; and all night in the light of the moon along country roads there were runaway carts at full gallop plunging into the ditches, jumping over yard after yard of stones, clambering up the hills, with women leaning out from the tilt to catch hold of the reins.

Those who stayed at the Bertaux spent the night drinking in the kitchen. The children had fallen asleep under the seats.

The bride had begged her (bride) father to be spared the usual marriage pleasantries. However, a fishmonger, one of their cousins -LRB-who had even brought a pair of soles for his (fishmonger) wedding present-RRB-, began to squirt water from his (fishmonger) mouth through the keyhole, when old Rouault came up just in time to stop him (Rouault), and explain to him (Rouault) that the distinguished position of his (Rouault) son-in-law would not allow of such liberties. The cousin all the same did not give in to these reasons readily. In his (cousin) heart he (cousin) accused old Rouault of being proud, and he (cousin) joined four or five other guests in a corner, who having, through mere chance, been several times running served with the worst helps of meat, also were of opinion they had been badly used, and were whispering about their host, and with covered hints hoping he (cousin) would ruin himself.

Madame Bovary, senior, had not opened her (Rouault) mouth all day. She (Rouault) had been consulted neither as to the dress of her (Rouault) daughter-in-law nor as to the arrangement of the feast; she (Rouault) went to bed early. Her (Rouault) husband, instead of following her (Rouault), sent to Saint-Victor for some cigars, and smoked till daybreak, drinking kirsch-punch, a mixture unknown to the company. This added greatly to the consideration in which he (husband) was held.

Charles, who was not of a facetious turn, did not shine at the wedding. He (Charles) answered feebly to the puns, doubles entendres*, compliments, and chaff that it was felt a duty to let off at him (Charles) as soon as the soup appeared.

*Double meanings.

The next day, on the other hand, he (Charles) seemed another man. It was he (Charles) who might rather have been taken for the virgin of the evening before, whilst the bride gave no sign that revealed anything. The shrewdest did not know what to make of it, and they looked at her (bride) when she (bride) passed near them with an unbounded concentration of mind. But Charles concealed nothing. He (Charles) called her (bride)

``my wife'' (her)
, tutoyed* her (bride), asked for her (bride) of everyone, looked for her (bride) everywhere, and often he (Charles) dragged her (bride) into the yards, where he (Charles) could be seen from far between the trees, putting his (Charles) arm around her (bride) waist, and walking half-bending over her (bride), ruffling the chemisette of her (bride) bodice with his (Charles) head.

*Used the familiar form of address.

Two days after the wedding the married pair left. Charles, on account of his (Charles) patients, could not be away longer. Old Rouault had them driven back in his (Rouault) cart, and himself accompanied them as far as Vassonville. Here he (Rouault) embraced his (Rouault) daughter for the last time, got down, and went his (Rouault) way. When he (Rouault) had gone about a hundred paces he (Rouault) stopped, and as he (Rouault) saw the cart disappearing, its wheels turning in the dust, he (Rouault) gave a deep sigh. Then he (Rouault) remembered his (Rouault) wedding, the old times, the first pregnancy of his (Rouault) wife; he (Rouault), too, had been very happy the day when he (Rouault) had taken her (wife) from her (wife) father to his (Rouault) home, and had carried her (wife) off on a pillion, trotting through the snow, for it was near Christmas-time, and the country was all white. She (wife) held him (Rouault) by one arm, her (wife) basket hanging from the other; the wind blew the long lace of her (wife) Cauchois headdress so that it sometimes flapped across his (Rouault) mouth, and when he (Rouault) turned his (Rouault) head he (Rouault) saw near him (Rouault), on his (Rouault) shoulder, her (wife) little rosy face, smiling silently under the gold bands of her (wife) cap. To warm her (wife) hands she (wife) put them from time to time in his (Rouault) breast. How long ago it all was! Their son would have been thirty by now. Then he (son) looked back and saw nothing on the road. He (son) felt dreary as an empty house; and tender memories mingling with the sad thoughts in his (son) brain, addled by the fumes of the feast, he (son) felt inclined for a moment to take a turn towards the church. As he (son) was afraid, however, that this sight would make him (son) yet more sad, he (son) went right away home.

Monsieur and Madame Charles arrived at Tostes about six o’clock.

The neighbors came to the windows to see their doctor's new wife.

The old servant presented herself, curtsied to her (wife), apologised for not having dinner ready, and suggested that madame, in the meantime, should look over her (wife) house.

Chapter Five

The brick front was just in a line with the street, or rather the road. Behind the door hung a cloak with a small collar, a bridle, and a black leather cap, and on the floor, in a corner, were a pair of leggings, still covered with dry mud. On the right was the one apartment, that was both dining and sitting room. A canary yellow paper, relieved at the top by a garland of pale flowers, was puckered everywhere over the badly stretched canvas; white calico curtains with a red border hung crossways at the length of the window; and on the narrow mantelpiece a clock with a head of Hippocrates shone resplendent between two plate candlesticks under oval shades. On the other side of the passage was Charles's consulting room, a little room about six paces wide, with a table, three chairs, and an office chair. Volumes of the

``Dictionary of Medical Science,'' (unknown)
uncut, but the binding rather the worse for the successive sales through which they had gone, occupied almost along the six shelves of a deal bookcase.

The smell of melted butter penetrated through the walls when he (Charles) saw patients, just as in the kitchen one could hear the people coughing in the consulting room and recounting their histories.

Then, opening on the yard, where the stable was, came a large dilapidated room with a stove, now used as a wood-house, cellar, and pantry, full of old rubbish, of empty casks, agricultural implements past service, and a mass of dusty things whose use it was impossible to guess.

The garden, longer than wide, ran between two mud walls with espaliered apricots, to a hawthorn hedge that separated it from the field. In the middle was a slate sundial on a brick pedestal; four flower beds with eglantines surrounded symmetrically the more useful kitchen garden bed. Right at the bottom, under the spruce bushes, was a cure in plaster reading his (it) breviary.

Emma went upstairs. The first room was not furnished, but in the second, which was their bedroom, was a mahogany bedstead in an alcove with red drapery. A shell box adorned the chest of drawers, and on the secretary near the window a bouquet of orange blossoms tied with white satin ribbons stood in a bottle. It was a bride's bouquet; it was the other one's. She (bride) looked at it. Charles noticed it; he (Charles) took it and carried it up to the attic, while Emma seated in an arm-chair -LRB-they were putting her (Emma) things down around her (Emma)-RRB- thought of her (Emma) bridal flowers packed up in a bandbox, and wondered, dreaming, what would be done with them if she (Emma) were to die.

During the first days she (Emma) occupied herself in thinking about changes in the house. She (Emma) took the shades off the candlesticks, had new wallpaper put up, the staircase repainted, and seats made in the garden round the sundial; she (Emma) even inquired how she (Emma) could get a basin with a jet fountain and fishes. Finally her (Emma) husband, knowing that she (Emma) liked to drive out, picked up a second-hand dogcart, which, with new lamps and splashboard in striped leather, looked almost like a tilbury.

He (husband) was happy then, and without a care in the world. A meal together, a walk in the evening on the highroad, a gesture of her (Emma) hands over her (Emma) hair, the sight of her (Emma) straw hat hanging from the window-fastener, and many another thing in which Charles had never dreamed of pleasure, now made up the endless round of his (Charles) happiness. In bed, in the morning, by her (Emma) side, on the pillow, he (Charles) watched the sunlight sinking into the down on her (Emma) fair cheek, half hidden by the lappets of her (Emma) night-cap. Seen thus closely, her (Emma) eyes looked to him (Charles) enlarged, especially when, on waking up, she (Emma) opened and shut them rapidly many times. Black in the shade, dark blue in broad daylight, they had, as it were, depths of different colours, that, darker in the centre, grew paler towards the surface of the eye. His (Charles) own eyes lost themselves in these depths; he (Charles) saw himself in miniature down to the shoulders, with his (Charles) handkerchief round his (Charles) head and the top of his (Charles) shirt open. He (Charles) rose. She (Emma) came to the window to see him (Charles) off, and stayed leaning on the sill between two pots of geranium, clad in her (Emma) dressing gown hanging loosely about her (Emma). Charles, in the street buckled his (Charles) spurs, his (Charles) foot on the mounting stone, while she (Emma) talked to him (Charles) from above, picking with her (Emma) mouth some scrap of flower or leaf that she (Emma) blew out at him (Charles). Then this, eddying, floating, described semicircles in the air like a bird, and was caught before it reached the ground in the ill-groomed mane of the old white mare standing motionless at the door. Charles from horseback threw her (mare) a kiss; she (mare) answered with a nod; she (mare) shut the window, and he (Charles) set off. And then along the highroad, spreading out its long ribbon of dust, along the deep lanes that the trees bent over as in arbours, along paths where the corn reached to the knees, with the sun on his (Charles) back and the morning air in his (Charles) nostrils, his (Charles) heart full of the joys of the past night, his (Charles) mind at rest, his (Charles) flesh at ease, he (Charles) went on, re-chewing his (Charles) happiness, like those who after dinner taste again the truffles which they are digesting.

Until now what good had he (Charles) had of his (Charles) life? His (Charles) time at school, when he (Charles) remained shut up within the high walls, alone, in the midst of companions richer than he (Charles) or cleverer at their work, who laughed at his (Charles) accent, who jeered at his (Charles) clothes, and whose mothers came to the school with cakes in their muffs? Later on, when he (Charles) studied medicine, and never had his (Charles) purse full enough to treat some little work-girl who would have become his (Charles) mistress? Afterwards, he (Charles) had lived fourteen months with the widow, whose feet in bed were cold as icicles. But now he (Charles) had for life this beautiful woman whom he (Charles) adored. For him (Charles) the universe did not extend beyond the circumference of her (woman) petticoat, and he (Charles) reproached himself with not loving her (woman). He (Charles) wanted to see her (woman) again; he (Charles) turned back quickly, ran up the stairs with a beating heart. Emma, in her (Emma) room, was dressing; he (Charles) came up on tiptoe, kissed her (Emma) back; she (Emma) gave a cry.

He (Charles) could not keep from constantly touching her (Emma) comb, her (Emma) ring, her (Emma) fichu; sometimes he (Charles) gave her (Emma) great sounding kisses with all his (Charles) mouth on her (Emma) cheeks, or else little kisses in a row all along her (Emma) bare arm from the tip of her (Emma) fingers up to her (Emma) shoulder, and she (Emma) put him (Charles) away half-smiling, half-vexed, as you do a child who hangs about you.

Before marriage she (Emma) thought herself in love; but the happiness that should have followed this love not having come, she (Emma) must, she (Emma) thought, have been mistaken. And Emma tried to find out what one meant exactly in life by the words felicity, passion, rapture, that had seemed to her (Emma) so beautiful in books.

Chapter Six

She (Emma) had read

``Paul and Virginia,'' (She)
and she (Emma) had dreamed of the little bamboo-house, the nigger Domingo, the dog Fidele, but above all of the sweet friendship of some dear little brother, who seeks red fruit for you on trees taller than steeples, or who runs barefoot over the sand, bringing you a bird's nest.

When she (Emma) was thirteen, her (Emma) father himself took her (Emma) to town to place her (Emma) in the convent. They stopped at an inn in the St. Gervais quarter, where, at their supper, they used painted plates that set forth the story of Mademoiselle de la Valliere. The explanatory legends, chipped here and there by the scratching of knives, all glorified religion, the tendernesses of the heart, and the pomps of court.

Far from being bored at first at the convent, she (Valliere) took pleasure in the society of the good sisters, who, to amuse her (Valliere), took her (Valliere) to the chapel, which one entered from the refectory by a long corridor. She (Valliere) played very little during recreation hours, knew her (Valliere) catechism well, and it was she (Valliere) who always answered Monsieur le Vicaire's difficult questions. Living thus, without ever leaving the warm atmosphere of the classrooms, and amid these pale-faced women wearing rosaries with brass crosses, she (Valliere) was softly lulled by the mystic languor exhaled in the perfumes of the altar, the freshness of the holy water, and the lights of the tapers. Instead of attending to mass, she (Valliere) looked at the pious vignettes with their azure borders in her (Valliere) book, and she (Valliere) loved the sick lamb, the sacred heart pierced with sharp arrows, or the poor Jesus sinking beneath the cross he (Jesus) carries. She (Valliere) tried, by way of mortification, to eat nothing a whole day. She (Valliere) puzzled her (Valliere) head to find some vow to fulfil.

When she (Valliere) went to confession, she (Valliere) invented little sins in order that she (Valliere) might stay there longer, kneeling in the shadow, her (Valliere) hands joined, her (Valliere) face against the grating beneath the whispering of the priest. The comparisons of betrothed, husband, celestial lover, and eternal marriage, that recur in sermons, stirred within her (Valliere) soul depths of unexpected sweetness.

In the evening, before prayers, there was some religious reading in the study. On week-nights it was some abstract of sacred history or the Lectures of the Abbe Frayssinous, and on Sundays passages from the

``Genie du Christianisme,'' (Abbe)
as a recreation. How she (Valliere) listened at first to the sonorous lamentations of its romantic melancholies reechoing through the world and eternity! If her (Valliere) childhood had been spent in the shop-parlour of some business quarter, she (Valliere) might perhaps have opened her (Valliere) heart to those lyrical invasions of Nature, which usually come to us only through translation in books. But she (Valliere) knew the country too well; she (Valliere) knew the lowing of cattle, the milking, the ploughs.

Accustomed to calm aspects of life, she (Valliere) turned, on the contrary, to those of excitement. She (Valliere) loved the sea only for the sake of its storms, and the green fields only when broken up by ruins.

She (Valliere) wanted to get some personal profit out of things, and she (Valliere) rejected as useless all that did not contribute to the immediate desires of her (Valliere) heart, being of a temperament more sentimental than artistic, looking for emotions, not landscapes.

At the convent there was an old maid who came for a week each month to mend the linen. Patronized by the clergy, because she (maid) belonged to an ancient family of noblemen ruined by the Revolution, she (maid) dined in the refectory at the table of the good sisters, and after the meal had a bit of chat with them before going back to her (maid) work. The girls often slipped out from the study to go and see her (maid). She (maid) knew by heart the love songs of the last century, and sang them in a low voice as she (maid) stitched away.

She (maid) told stories, gave them news, went errands in the town, and on the sly lent the big girls some novel, that she (maid) always carried in the pockets of her (maid) apron, and of which the good lady herself swallowed long chapters in the intervals of her (maid) work. They were all love, lovers, sweethearts, persecuted ladies fainting in lonely pavilions, postilions killed at every stage, horses ridden to death on every page, sombre forests, heartaches, vows, sobs, tears and kisses, little skiffs by moonlight, nightingales in shady groves,

``gentlemen'' (ladies)
brave as lions, gentle as lambs, virtuous as no one ever was, always well dressed, and weeping like fountains. For six months, then, Emma, at fifteen years of age, made her (Emma) hands dirty with books from old lending libraries.

Through Walter Scott, later on, she (Emma) fell in love with historical events, dreamed of old chests, guard-rooms and minstrels. She (Emma) would have liked to live in some old manor-house, like those long-waisted chatelaines who, in the shade of pointed arches, spent their days leaning on the stone, chin in hand, watching a cavalier with white plume galloping on his (Scott) black horse from the distant fields. At this time she (Emma) had a cult for Mary Stuart and enthusiastic veneration for illustrious or unhappy women. Joan of Arc, Heloise, Agnes Sorel, the beautiful Ferroniere, and Clemence Isaure stood out to her (Joan) like comets in the dark immensity of heaven, where also were seen, lost in shadow, and all unconnected, St. Louis with his (Louis) oak, the dying Bayard, some cruelties of Louis XI, a little of St. Bartholomew's Day, the plume of the Bearnais, and always the remembrance of the plates painted in honour of Louis XIV.

In the music class, in the ballads she (Joan) sang, there was nothing but little angels with golden wings, madonnas, lagunes, gondoliers;-mild compositions that allowed her (Joan) to catch a glimpse athwart the obscurity of style and the weakness of the music of the attractive phantasmagoria of sentimental realities. Some of her (Joan) companions brought

``keepsakes'' (companions)
given them as new year's gifts to the convent. These had to be hidden; it was quite an undertaking; they were read in the dormitory. Delicately handling the beautiful satin bindings, Emma looked with dazzled eyes at the names of the unknown authors, who had signed their verses for the most part as counts or viscounts.

She (Emma) trembled as she (Emma) blew back the tissue paper over the engraving and saw it folded in two and fall gently against the page.
