But the cure from time to time looked into the church, where the kneeling boys were shouldering one another, and tumbling over like packs of cards.

``I should like to know--'' (she)
she (Emma) went on.

``You look out, Riboudet,'' (the priest)
cried the priest in an angry voice;
``I'll warm your ears, you imp!'' (the priest)
Then turning to Emma,
``He (Paul)'s Boudet the carpenter's son; his (Paul) parents are well off, and let him (Paul) do just as he (Paul) pleases. Yet he (Paul) could learn quickly if he (Paul) would, for he (Paul) is very sharp. And so sometimes for a joke I call him (Paul) Riboudet -LRB-like the road one takes to go to Maromme-RRB- and I even say `Mon Riboudet.' Ha! Ha! `Mont Riboudet.' The other day I repeated that just to Monsignor, and he (Monsignor) laughed at it; he (Monsignor) condescended to laugh at it. And how is Monsieur Bovary?'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

She (Emma) seemed not to hear him (priest). And he (priest) went on--

``Always very busy, no doubt; for he (Monsignor) and I are certainly the busiest people in the parish. But he (Monsignor) is doctor of the body,'' (he)
he (priest) added with a thick laugh,
``and I of the soul.'' (he)

She (Emma) fixed her (Emma) pleading eyes upon the priest.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Emma) said,
``you solace all sorrows.'' (she)

``Ah! don't talk to me of it, Madame Bovary. This morning I had to go to Bas-Diauville for a cow that was ill; they thought it was under a spell. All their cows, I don't know how it is--But pardon me! Longuemarre and Boudet! Bless me! Will you leave off?'' (he)

And with a bound he (priest) ran into the church.

The boys were just then clustering round the large desk, climbing over the precentor's footstool, opening the missal; and others on tiptoe were just about to venture into the confessional. But the priest suddenly distributed a shower of cuffs among them. Seizing them by the collars of their coats, he (priest) lifted them from the ground, and deposited them on their knees on the stones of the choir, firmly, as if he (priest) meant planting them there.

``Yes,'' (he)
said he (priest), when he (priest) returned to Emma, unfolding his (priest) large cotton handkerchief, one corner of which he (priest) put between his (priest) teeth,
``farmers are much to be pitied.'' (he)

``Others, too,'' (she)
she (Emma) replied.

``Assuredly. Town-labourers, for example.'' (unknown)

``It is not they--'' (unknown)

``Pardon! I've there known poor mothers of families, virtuous women, I assure you, real saints, who wanted even bread.'' (unknown)

``But those,'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
replied Emma, and the corners of her (Emma) mouth twitched as she (Emma) spoke,
``those, Monsieur le Cure, who have bread and have no--'' (she)

``Fire in the winter,'' (she)
said the priest.

``Oh, what does that matter?'' (unknown)

``What! What does it matter? It seems to me that when one has firing and food--for, after all--'' (unknown)

``My God! my God!'' (she)
she (Emma) sighed.

``It is indigestion, no doubt? You must get home, Madame Bovary; drink a little tea, that will strengthen you, or else a glass of fresh water with a little moist sugar.'' (unknown)

``Why?'' (she)
And she (Emma) looked like one awaking from a dream.

``Well, you see, you were putting your hand to your forehead. I thought you felt faint.'' (unknown)
Then, bethinking himself,
``But you were asking me something? What was it? I really don't remember.'' (unknown)

``I? Nothing! nothing!'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
repeated Emma.

And the glance she (Emma) cast round her (Emma) slowly fell upon the old man in the cassock. They looked at one another face to face without speaking.

``Then, Madame Bovary,'' (he)
he (man) said at last,
``excuse me, but duty first, you know; I must look after my good-for-nothings. The first communion will soon be upon us, and I fear we shall be behind after all. So after Ascension Day I keep them recta* an extra hour every Wednesday. Poor children! One cannot lead them too soon into the path of the Lord, as, moreover, he (Lord) has himself recommended us to do by the mouth of his (Lord) Divine Son. Good health to you, madame; my respects to your husband.'' (he)

*On the straight and narrow path.

And he (man) went into the church making a genuflexion as soon as he (man) reached the door.

Emma saw him (man) disappear between the double row of forms, walking with a heavy tread, his (man) head a little bent over his (man) shoulder, and with his (man) two hands half-open behind him (man).

Then she (Emma) turned on her (Emma) heel all of one piece, like a statue on a pivot, and went homewards. But the loud voice of the priest, the clear voices of the boys still reached her (Emma) ears, and went on behind her (Emma).

``Are you a Christian?'' (unknown)

``Yes, I am a Christian.'' (unknown)

``What is a Christian?'' (unknown)

``He (Christian) who, being baptized-baptized-baptized--'' (She)

She (Emma) went up the steps of the staircase holding on to the banisters, and when she (Emma) was in her (Emma) room threw herself into an arm-chair.

The whitish light of the window-panes fell with soft undulations.

The furniture in its place seemed to have become more immobile, and to lose itself in the shadow as in an ocean of darkness. The fire was out, the clock went on ticking, and Emma vaguely marvelled at this calm of all things while within herself was such tumult. But little Berthe was there, between the window and the work-table, tottering on her (Emma) knitted shoes, and trying to come to her (Emma) mother to catch hold of the ends of her (Emma) apron-strings.

``Leave me alone,'' (unknown)
said the latter, putting her (Emma) from her (Emma) with her (Emma) hand.

The little girl soon came up closer against her (Emma) knees, and leaning on them with her (Emma) arms, she (Emma) looked up with her (Emma) large blue eyes, while a small thread of pure saliva dribbled from her (Emma) lips on to the silk apron.

``Leave me alone,'' (the woman)
repeated the young woman quite irritably.

Her (Emma) face frightened the child, who began to scream.

``Will you leave me alone?'' (she)
she (Emma) said, pushing her (Emma) with her (Emma) elbow.

Berthe fell at the foot of the drawers against the brass handle, cutting her (Emma) cheek, which began to bleed, against it. Madame Bovary sprang to lift her (Emma) up, broke the bell-rope, called for the servant with all her (Emma) might, and she (Emma) was just going to curse herself when Charles appeared. It was the dinner-hour; he (Charles) had come home.

``Look, dear!'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma, in a calm voice,
``the little one fell down while she (me) was playing, and has hurt herself.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

Charles reassured her (Emma); the case was not a serious one, and he (Charles) went for some sticking plaster.

Madame Bovary did not go downstairs to the dining-room; she (Emma) wished to remain alone to look after the child. Then watching her (Emma) sleep, the little anxiety she (Emma) felt gradually wore off, and she (Emma) seemed very stupid to herself, and very good to have been so worried just now at so little. Berthe, in fact, no longer sobbed.

Her (Emma) breathing now imperceptibly raised the cotton covering. Big tears lay in the corner of the half-closed eyelids, through whose lashes one could see two pale sunken pupils; the plaster stuck on her (Emma) cheek drew the skin obliquely.

``It is very strange,'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
thought Emma,
``how ugly this child is!'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

When at eleven o’clock Charles came back from the chemist's shop, whither he (Charles) had gone after dinner to return the remainder of the sticking-plaster, he (Charles) found his (Charles) wife standing by the cradle.

``I assure you it's nothing.'' (he)
he (Charles) said, kissing her (wife) on the forehead.
``Don't worry, my poor darling; you will make yourself ill.'' (He)

He (Charles) had stayed a long time at the chemist's. Although he (Charles) had not seemed much moved, Homais, nevertheless, had exerted himself to buoy him (Charles) up, to

``keep up his (Christian) spirits.'' (him)
Then they had talked of the various dangers that threaten childhood, of the carelessness of servants. Madame Homais knew something of it, having still upon her (wife) chest the marks left by a basin full of soup that a cook had formerly dropped on her (wife) pinafore, and her (wife) good parents took no end of trouble for her (wife). The knives were not sharpened, nor the floors waxed; there were iron gratings to the windows and strong bars across the fireplace; the little Homais, in spite of their spirit, could not stir without someone watching them; at the slightest cold their father stuffed them with pectorals; and until they were turned four they all, without pity, had to wear wadded head-protectors. This, it is true, was a fancy of Madame Homais'; her (wife) husband was inwardly afflicted at it. Fearing the possible consequences of such compression to the intellectual organs. He (husband) even went so far as to say to her (wife),
``Do you want to make Caribs or Botocudos of them?'' (her)

Charles, however, had several times tried to interrupt the conversation.

``I should like to speak to you,'' (he)
he (Charles) had whispered in the clerk's ear, who went upstairs in front of him (Charles).

``Can he (Christian) suspect anything?'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
Leon asked himself. His (Leon) heart beat, and he (Leon) racked his (Leon) brain with surmises.

At last, Charles, having shut the door, asked him (Charles) to see himself what would be the price at Rouen of a fine daguerreotypes. It was a sentimental surprise he (Charles) intended for his (Charles) wife, a delicate attention--his (Charles) portrait in a frock-coat. But he (Charles) wanted first to know

``how much it would be.'' (he)
The inquiries would not put Monsieur Leon out, since he (Leon) went to town almost every week.

Why? Monsieur Homais suspected some

``young man's affair'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
at the bottom of it, an intrigue. But he (Leon) was mistaken. Leon was after no love-making. He (Leon) was sadder than ever, as Madame Lefrancois saw from the amount of food he (Lefrancois) left on his (Lefrancois) plate. To find out more about it she (wife) questioned the tax-collector. Binet answered roughly that he (Lefrancois)
``wasn't paid by the police.'' (he)

All the same, his (Lefrancois) companion seemed very strange to him (Lefrancois), for Leon often threw himself back in his (Leon) chair, and stretching out his (Leon) arms, complained vaguely of life.

``It's because you don't take enough recreation,'' (the collector)
said the collector.

``What recreation?'' (unknown)

``If I were you I'd have a lathe.'' (unknown)

``But I don't know how to turn,'' (the clerk)
answered the clerk.

``Ah! that's true,'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
said the other, rubbing his (collector) chin with an air of mingled contempt and satisfaction.

Leon was weary of loving without any result; moreover he (Leon) was beginning to feel that depression caused by the repetition of the same kind of life, when no interest inspires and no hope sustains it. He (Leon) was so bored with Yonville and its inhabitants, that the sight of certain persons, of certain houses, irritated him (Leon) beyond endurance; and the chemist, good fellow though he (fellow) was, was becoming absolutely unbearable to him (fellow). Yet the prospect of a new condition of life frightened as much as it seduced him (fellow).

This apprehension soon changed into impatience, and then Paris from afar sounded its fanfare of masked balls with the laugh of grisettes. As he (fellow) was to finish reading there, why not set out at once? What prevented him (fellow)? And he (fellow) began making home-preparations; he (fellow) arranged his (fellow) occupations beforehand. He (fellow) furnished in his (fellow) head an apartment. He (fellow) would lead an artist's life there! He (fellow) would take lessons on the guitar! He (fellow) would have a dressing-gown, a Basque cap, blue velvet slippers! He (fellow) even already was admiring two crossed foils over his (fellow) chimney-piece, with a death's head on the guitar above them.

The difficulty was the consent of his (fellow) mother; nothing, however, seemed more reasonable. Even his (fellow) employer advised him (fellow) to go to some other chambers where he (fellow) could advance more rapidly. Taking a middle course, then, Leon looked for some place as second clerk at Rouen; found none, and at last wrote his (Leon) mother a long letter full of details, in which he (Leon) set forth the reasons for going to live at Paris immediately. She (mother) consented.

He (Leon) did not hurry. Every day for a month Hivert carried boxes, valises, parcels for him (Leon) from Yonville to Rouen and from Rouen to Yonville; and when Leon had packed up his (Leon) wardrobe, had his (Leon) three arm-chairs restuffed, bought a stock of neckties, in a word, had made more preparations than for a voyage around the world, he (Leon) put it off from week to week, until he (Leon) received a second letter from his (Leon) mother urging him (Leon) to leave, since he (Leon) wanted to pass his (Leon) examination before the vacation.

When the moment for the farewells had come, Madame Homais wept, Justin sobbed; Homais, as a man of nerve, concealed his (Justin) emotion; he (Justin) wished to carry his (Justin) friend's overcoat himself as far as the gate of the notary, who was taking Leon to Rouen in his (Leon) carriage.

The latter had just time to bid farewell to Monsieur Bovary.

When he (Leon) reached the head of the stairs, he (Leon) stopped, he (Leon) was so out of breath. As he (Leon) came in, Madame Bovary arose hurriedly.

``It is I again!'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
said Leon.

``I was sure of it!'' (She)

She (Homais) bit her (Homais) lips, and a rush of blood flowing under her (Homais) skin made her (Homais) red from the roots of her (Homais) hair to the top of her (Homais) collar. She (Homais) remained standing, leaning with her (Homais) shoulder against the wainscot.

``The doctor is not here?'' (he)
he (Leon) went on.

``He (doctor) is out.'' (She)
She (Homais) repeated,
``He (doctor) is out.'' (She)

Then there was silence. They looked at one another and their thoughts, confounded in the same agony, clung close together like two throbbing breasts.

``I should like to kiss Berthe,'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
said Leon.

Emma went down a few steps and called Felicite.

He (Leon) threw one long look around him (Leon) that took in the walls, the decorations, the fireplace, as if to penetrate everything, carry away everything. But she (Emma) returned, and the servant brought Berthe, who was swinging a windmill roof downwards at the end of a string. Leon kissed her (Emma) several times on the neck.

``Good-bye, poor child! good-bye, dear little one! good-bye!'' (he)
And he (Leon) gave her (Emma) back to her (Emma) mother.

``Take her (you) away,'' (she)
she (Emma) said.

They remained alone--Madame Bovary, her (Emma) back turned, her (Emma) face pressed against a window-pane; Leon held his (Leon) cap in his (Leon) hand, knocking it softly against his (Leon) thigh.

``It is going to rain,'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma.

``I have a cloak,'' (he)
he (Leon) answered.

``Ah!'' (She)

She (Emma) turned around, her (Emma) chin lowered, her (Emma) forehead bent forward.

The light fell on it as on a piece of marble, to the curve of the eyebrows, without one's being able to guess what Emma was seeing on the horizon or what she (Emma) was thinking within herself.

``Well, good-bye,'' (he)
he (Leon) sighed.

She (Emma) raised her (Emma) head with a quick movement.

``Yes, good-bye--go!'' (unknown)

They advanced towards each other; he (Leon) held out his (Leon) hand; she (Emma) hesitated.

``In the English fashion, then,'' (she)
she (Emma) said, giving her (Emma) own hand wholly to him (Leon), and forcing a laugh.

Leon felt it between his (Leon) fingers, and the very essence of all his (Leon) being seemed to pass down into that moist palm. Then he (Leon) opened his (Leon) hand; their eyes met again, and he (Leon) disappeared.

When he (Leon) reached the market-place, he (Leon) stopped and hid behind a pillar to look for the last time at this white house with the four green blinds. He (Leon) thought he (Leon) saw a shadow behind the window in the room; but the curtain, sliding along the pole as though no one were touching it, slowly opened its long oblique folds that spread out with a single movement, and thus hung straight and motionless as a plaster wall. Leon set off running.

From afar he (Leon) saw his (Leon) employer's gig in the road, and by it a man in a coarse apron holding the horse. Homais and Monsieur Guillaumin were talking. They were waiting for him (Leon).

``Embrace me,'' (the druggist)
said the druggist with tears in his (Leon) eyes.
``Here is your coat, my good friend. Mind the cold; take care of yourself; look after yourself.'' (unknown)

``Come, Leon, jump in,'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
said the notary.

Homais bent over the splash-board, and in a voice broken by sobs uttered these three sad words--

``A pleasant journey!'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)

``Good-night,'' (Monsieur Guillaumin)
said Monsieur Guillaumin.
``Give him (Leon) his (Leon) head.'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
They set out, and Homais went back.

Madame Bovary had opened her (druggist) window overlooking the garden and watched the clouds. They gathered around the sunset on the side of Rouen and then swiftly rolled back their black columns, behind which the great rays of the sun looked out like the golden arrows of a suspended trophy, while the rest of the empty heavens was white as porcelain. But a gust of wind bowed the poplars, and suddenly the rain fell; it pattered against the green leaves.

Then the sun reappeared, the hens clucked, sparrows shook their wings in the damp thickets, and the pools of water on the gravel as they flowed away carried off the pink flowers of an acacia.

``Ah! how far off he (Leon) must be already!'' (she)
she (their) thought.

Monsieur Homais, as usual, came at half-past six during dinner.

``Well,'' (he)
said he (it),
``so we've sent off our young friend!'' (he)

``So it seems,'' (the doctor)
replied the doctor. Then turning on his (it) chair;
``Any news at home?'' (unknown)

``Nothing much. Only my wife was a little moved this afternoon. You know women--a nothing upsets them, especially my wife. And we should be wrong to object to that, since their nervous organization is much more malleable than ours.'' (unknown)

``Poor Leon!'' (Charles)
said Charles.
``How will he (Leon) live at Paris? Will he (Leon) get used to it?'' (Madame)

Madame Bovary sighed.

``Get along!'' (the chemist)
said the chemist, smacking his (chemist) lips.
``The outings at restaurants, the masked balls, the champagne--all that'll be jolly enough, I assure you.'' (unknown)

``I don't think he (Leon)'ll go wrong,'' (unknown)
objected Bovary.

``Nor do I,'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
said Monsieur Homais quickly;
``although he (Leon)'ll have to do like the rest for fear of passing for a Jesuit. And you don't know what a life those dogs lead in the Latin quarter with actresses. Besides, students are thought a great deal of in Paris. Provided they have a few accomplishments, they are received in the best society; there are even ladies of the Faubourg Saint-Germain who fall in love with them, which subsequently furnishes them opportunities for making very good matches.'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)

``But,'' (the doctor)
said the doctor,
``I fear for him (Leon) that down there--'' (the doctor)

``You are right,'' (the doctor)
interrupted the chemist; ``that is the reverse of the medal. And one is constantly obliged to keep one's hand in one's pocket there. Thus, we will suppose you are in a public garden. An individual presents himself, well dressed, even wearing an order, and whom one would take for a diplomatist. He (Leon) approaches you, he (Leon) insinuates himself; offers you a pinch of snuff, or picks up your hat. Then you become more intimate; he (Leon) takes you to a cafe, invites you to his (Leon) country-house, introduces you, between two drinks, to all sorts of people; and three-fourths of the time it's only to plunder your watch or lead you into some pernicious step.

``That is true,'' (Charles)
said Charles;
``but I was thinking especially of illnesses--of typhoid fever, for example, that attacks students from the provinces.'' (Charles)

Emma shuddered.

``Because of the change of regimen,'' (the chemist)
continued the chemist,
``and of the perturbation that results therefrom in the whole system. And then the water at Paris, don't you know! The dishes at restaurants, all the spiced food, end by heating the blood, and are not worth, whatever people may say of them, a good soup. For my own part, I have always preferred plain living; it is more healthy. So when I was studying pharmacy at Rouen, I boarded in a boarding house; I dined with the professors.'' (the chemist)

And thus he (chemist) went on, expounding his (chemist) opinions generally and his (chemist) personal likings, until Justin came to fetch him (Justin) for a mulled egg that was wanted.

``Not a moment's peace!'' (he)
he (Justin) cried;
``always at it! I can't go out for a minute! Like a plough-horse, I have always to be moiling and toiling. What drudgery!'' (he)
Then, when he (Justin) was at the door,
``By the way, do you know the news?'' (he)

``What news?'' (unknown)

``That it is very likely,'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
Homais went on, raising his (Justin) eyebrows and assuming one of his (Justin) most serious expression,
``that the agricultural meeting of the Seine-Inferieure will be held this year at Yonville-l’Abbaye. The rumour, at all events, is going the round. This morning the paper alluded to it. It would be of the utmost importance for our district. But we'll talk it over later on. I can see, thank you; Justin has the lantern.'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)

Chapter Seven

The next day was a dreary one for Emma. Everything seemed to her (Emma) enveloped in a black atmosphere floating confusedly over the exterior of things, and sorrow was engulfed within her (Emma) soul with soft shrieks such as the winter wind makes in ruined castles. It was that reverie which we give to things that will not return, the lassitude that seizes you after everything was done; that pain, in fine, that the interruption of every wonted movement, the sudden cessation of any prolonged vibration, brings on.

As on the return from Vaubyessard, when the quadrilles were running in her (Emma) head, she (Emma) was full of a gloomy melancholy, of a numb despair. Leon reappeared, taller, handsomer, more charming, more vague. Though separated from her (Emma), he (Leon) had not left her (Emma); he (Leon) was there, and the walls of the house seemed to hold his (Leon) shadow.

She (Emma) could not detach her (Emma) eyes from the carpet where he (Leon) had walked, from those empty chairs where he (Leon) had sat. The river still flowed on, and slowly drove its ripples along the slippery banks.

They had often walked there to the murmur of the waves over the moss-covered pebbles. How bright the sun had been! What happy afternoons they had seen alone in the shade at the end of the garden! He (Leon) read aloud, bareheaded, sitting on a footstool of dry sticks; the fresh wind of the meadow set trembling the leaves of the book and the nasturtiums of the arbour. Ah! he (Leon) was gone, the only charm of her (its) life, the only possible hope of joy. Why had she (its) not seized this happiness when it came to her (its)? Why not have kept hold of it with both hands, with both knees, when it was about to flee from her (its)? And she (its) cursed herself for not having loved Leon. She (its) thirsted for his (Leon) lips. The wish took possession of her (its) to run after and rejoin him (Leon), throw herself into his (Leon) arms and say to him (Leon),

``It is I; I am yours.'' (him)
But Emma recoiled beforehand at the difficulties of the enterprise, and her (Emma) desires, increased by regret, became only the more acute.

Henceforth the memory of Leon was the centre of her (Emma) boredom; it burnt there more brightly than the fire travellers have left on the snow of a Russian steppe. She (Emma) sprang towards him (Leon), she (Emma) pressed against him (Leon), she (Emma) stirred carefully the dying embers, sought all around her (Emma) anything that could revive it; and the most distant reminiscences, like the most immediate occasions, what she (Emma) experienced as well as what she (Emma) imagined, her (Emma) voluptuous desires that were unsatisfied, her (Emma) projects of happiness that crackled in the wind like dead boughs, her (Emma) sterile virtue, her (Emma) lost hopes, the domestic tete-a-tete--she (Emma) gathered it all up, took everything, and made it all serve as fuel for her (Emma) melancholy.

The flames, however, subsided, either because the supply had exhausted itself, or because it had been piled up too much. Love, little by little, was quelled by absence; regret stifled beneath habit; and this incendiary light that had empurpled her (Emma) pale sky was overspread and faded by degrees. In the supineness of her (Emma) conscience she (Emma) even took her (Emma) repugnance towards her (Emma) husband for aspirations towards her (Emma) lover, the burning of hate for the warmth of tenderness; but as the tempest still raged, and as passion burnt itself down to the very cinders, and no help came, no sun rose, there was night on all sides, and she (Emma) was lost in the terrible cold that pierced her (Emma).

Then the evil days of Tostes began again. She (Emma) thought herself now far more unhappy; for she (Emma) had the experience of grief, with the certainty that it would not end.

A woman who had laid on herself such sacrifices could well allow herself certain whims. She (woman) bought a Gothic prie-dieu, and in a month spent fourteen francs on lemons for polishing her (woman) nails; she (woman) wrote to Rouen for a blue cashmere gown; she (woman) chose one of Lheureux's finest scarves, and wore it knotted around her (woman) waist over her (woman) dressing-gown; and, with closed blinds and a book in her (woman) hand, she (woman) lay stretched out on a couch in this garb.

She (woman) often changed her (woman) coiffure; she (woman) did her (woman) hair a la Chinoise, in flowing curls, in plaited coils; she (woman) parted in on one side and rolled it under like a man's.

She (woman) wanted to learn Italian; she (woman) bought dictionaries, a grammar, and a supply of white paper. She (woman) tried serious reading, history, and philosophy. Sometimes in the night Charles woke up with a start, thinking he (Charles) was being called to a patient.

``I'm coming,'' (he)
he (Charles) stammered; and it was the noise of a match Emma had struck to relight the lamp. But her (Emma) reading fared like her (Emma) piece of embroidery, all of which, only just begun, filled her (Emma) cupboard; she (Emma) took it up, left it, passed on to other books.

She (Emma) had attacks in which she (Emma) could easily have been driven to commit any folly. She (Emma) maintained one day, in opposition to her (Emma) husband, that she (Emma) could drink off a large glass of brandy, and, as Charles was stupid enough to dare her (Emma) to, she (Emma) swallowed the brandy to the last drop.

In spite of her (Emma) vapourish airs -LRB-as the housewives of Yonville called them-RRB-, Emma, all the same, never seemed gay, and usually she (Emma) had at the corners of her (Emma) mouth that immobile contraction that puckers the faces of old maids, and those of men whose ambition has failed. She (Emma) was pale all over, white as a sheet; the skin of her (Emma) nose was drawn at the nostrils, her (Emma) eyes looked at you vaguely. After discovering three grey hairs on her (Emma) temples, she (Emma) talked much of her (Emma) old age.

She (Emma) often fainted. One day she (Emma) even spat blood, and, as Charles fussed around her (Emma) showing his (Charles) anxiety--

``Bah!'' (Charles)
she (Emma) answered,
``what does it matter?'' (she)

Charles fled to his (Charles) study and wept there, both his (Charles) elbows on the table, sitting in an arm-chair at his (Charles) bureau under the phrenological head.

Then he (Charles) wrote to his (Charles) mother begging her (mother) to come, and they had many long consultations together on the subject of Emma.

What should they decide? What was to be done since she (Emma) rejected all medical treatment?

``Do you know what your wife wants?'' (Madame)
replied Madame Bovary senior.

``She (wife) wants to be forced to occupy herself with some manual work. If she (wife) were obliged, like so many others, to earn her (wife) living, she (wife) wouldn't have these vapours, that come to her (wife) from a lot of ideas she (wife) stuffs into her (wife) head, and from the idleness in which she (wife) lives.'' (unknown)

``Yet she (wife) is always busy,'' (Charles)
said Charles.

``Ah! always busy at what? Reading novels, bad books, works against religion, and in which they mock at priests in speeches taken from Voltaire. But all that leads you far astray, my poor child. Anyone who has no religion always ends by turning out badly.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

So it was decided to stop Emma reading novels. The enterprise did not seem easy. The good lady undertook it. She (lady) was, when she (lady) passed through Rouen, to go herself to the lending-library and represent that Emma had discontinued her (Emma) subscription. Would they not have a right to apply to the police if the librarian persisted all the same in his (Charles) poisonous trade? The farewells of mother and daughter-in-law were cold. During the three weeks that they had been together they had not exchanged half-a-dozen words apart from the inquiries and phrases when they met at table and in the evening before going to bed.

Madame Bovary left on a Wednesday, the market-day at Yonville.

The Place since morning had been blocked by a row of carts, which, on end and their shafts in the air, spread all along the line of houses from the church to the inn. On the other side there were canvas booths, where cotton checks, blankets, and woollen stockings were sold, together with harness for horses, and packets of blue ribbon, whose ends fluttered in the wind. The coarse hardware was spread out on the ground between pyramids of eggs and hampers of cheeses, from which sticky straw stuck out.

Near the corn-machines clucking hens passed their necks through the bars of flat cages. The people, crowding in the same place and unwilling to move thence, sometimes threatened to smash the shop front of the chemist. On Wednesdays his (chemist) shop was never empty, and the people pushed in less to buy drugs than for consultations. So great was Homais' reputation in the neighbouring villages. His (chemist) robust aplomb had fascinated the rustics. They considered him (chemist) a greater doctor than all the doctors.

Emma was leaning out at the window; she (Emma) was often there. The window in the provinces replaces the theatre and the promenade, she (Emma) was amusing herself with watching the crowd of boors when she (Emma) saw a gentleman in a green velvet coat. He (gentleman) had on yellow gloves, although he (gentleman) wore heavy gaiters; he (gentleman) was coming towards the doctor's house, followed by a peasant walking with a bent head and quite a thoughtful air.

``Can I see the doctor?'' (he)
he (gentleman) asked Justin, who was talking on the doorsteps with Felicite, and, taking him (gentleman) for a servant of the house--
``Tell him (doctor) that Monsieur Rodolphe Boulanger of La Huchette is here.'' (a servant)

It was not from territorial vanity that the new arrival added

``of La Huchette'' (La Huchette)
to his (gentleman) name, but to make himself the better known.

La Huchette, in fact, was an estate near Yonville, where he (gentleman) had just bought the chateau and two farms that he (gentleman) cultivated himself, without, however, troubling very much about them. He (gentleman) lived as a bachelor, and was supposed to have

``at least fifteen thousand francs a year.'' (a bachelor)

Charles came into the room. Monsieur Boulanger introduced his (Boulanger) man, who wanted to be bled because he (Boulanger) felt

``a tingling all over.'' (he)

``That'll purge me,'' (he)
he (Boulanger) urged as an objection to all reasoning.

So Bovary ordered a bandage and a basin, and asked Justin to hold it. Then addressing the peasant, who was already pale--

``Don't be afraid, my lad.'' (the peasant)

``No, no, sir,'' (unknown)
said the other;
``get on.'' (he)

And with an air of bravado he (peasant) held out his (peasant) great arm. At the prick of the lancet the blood spurted out, splashing against the looking-glass.

``Hold the basin nearer,'' (Charles)
exclaimed Charles.

``Lor!'' (the peasant)
said the peasant,
``one would swear it was a little fountain flowing. How red my blood is! That's a good sign, isn't it?'' (the peasant)

``Sometimes,'' (the doctor)
answered the doctor,
``one feels nothing at first, and then syncope sets in, and more especially with people of strong constitution like this man.'' (the doctor)

At these words the rustic let go the lancet-case he (Charles) was twisting between his (Charles) fingers. A shudder of his (Charles) shoulders made the chair-back creak. His (Charles) hat fell off.

``I thought as much,'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)
said Bovary, pressing his (Charles) finger on the vein.

The basin was beginning to tremble in Justin's hands; his (Justin) knees shook, he (Justin) turned pale.

``Emma! Emma!'' (Charles)
called Charles.

With one bound she (peasant) came down the staircase.

``Some vinegar,'' (he)
he (Charles) cried.
``O dear! two at once!'' (he)

And in his (Charles) emotion he (Charles) could hardly put on the compress.

``It is nothing,'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
said Monsieur Boulanger quietly, taking Justin in his (Boulanger) arms. He (Boulanger) seated him (Boulanger) on the table with his (Boulanger) back resting against the wall.

Madame Bovary began taking off his (Boulanger) cravat. The strings of his (Boulanger) shirt had got into a knot, and she (peasant) was for some minutes moving her (peasant) light fingers about the young fellow's neck. Then she (peasant) poured some vinegar on her (peasant) cambric handkerchief; she (peasant) moistened his (fellow) temples with little dabs, and then blew upon them softly. The ploughman revived, but Justin's syncope still lasted, and his (Justin) eyeballs disappeared in the pale sclerotics like blue flowers in milk.

``We must hide this from him (man),'' (Charles)
said Charles.

Madame Bovary took the basin to put it under the table. With the movement she (peasant) made in bending down, her (peasant) dress -LRB-it was a summer dress with four flounces, yellow, long in the waist and wide in the skirt-RRB- spread out around her (peasant) on the flags of the room; and as Emma stooping, staggered a little as she (Emma) stretched out her (Emma) arms.

The stuff here and there gave with the inflections of her (Emma) bust.

Then she (Emma) went to fetch a bottle of water, and she (Emma) was melting some pieces of sugar when the chemist arrived. The servant had been to fetch him (servant) in the tumult. Seeing his (servant) pupil's eyes staring he (servant) drew a long breath; then going around him (servant) he (servant) looked at him (servant) from head to foot.

``Fool!'' (he)
he (servant) said,
``really a little fool! A fool in four letters! A phlebotomy's a big affair, isn't it! And a fellow who isn't afraid of anything; a kind of squirrel, just as he (fellow) is who climbs to vertiginous heights to shake down nuts. Oh, yes! you just talk to me, boast about yourself! Here's a fine fitness for practising pharmacy later on; for under serious circumstances you may be called before the tribunals in order to enlighten the minds of the magistrates, and you would have to keep your head then, to reason, show yourself a man, or else pass for an imbecile.'' (he)

Justin did not answer. The chemist went on--

``Who asked you to come? You are always pestering the doctor and madame. On Wednesday, moreover, your presence is indispensable to me. There are now twenty people in the shop. I left everything because of the interest I take in you. Come, get along! Sharp! Wait for me, and keep an eye on the jars.'' (The chemist)

When Justin, who was rearranging his (Justin) dress, had gone, they talked for a little while about fainting-fits. Madame Bovary had never fainted.

``That is extraordinary for a lady,'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
said Monsieur Boulanger;
``but some people are very susceptible. Thus in a duel, I have seen a second lose consciousness at the mere sound of the loading of pistols.'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)

``For my part,'' (the chemist sight)
said the chemist,
``the sight of other people's blood doesn't affect me at all, but the mere thought of my own flowing would make me faint if I reflected upon it too much.'' (the chemist sight)

Monsieur Boulanger, however, dismissed his (Boulanger) servant, advising him (Boulanger) to calm himself, since his (Boulanger) fancy was over.

``It procured me the advantage of making your acquaintance,'' (he)
he (Boulanger) added, and he (Boulanger) looked at Emma as he (Boulanger) said this. Then he (Boulanger) put three francs on the corner of the table, bowed negligently, and went out.

He (Boulanger) was soon on the other side of the river -LRB-this was his (Boulanger) way back to La Huchette-RRB-, and Emma saw him (Boulanger) in the meadow, walking under the poplars, slackening his (Boulanger) pace now and then as one who reflects.

``She (lady) is very pretty,'' (he)
he (Boulanger) said to himself;
``she (lady) is very pretty, this doctor's wife. Fine teeth, black eyes, a dainty foot, a figure like a Parisienne's. Where the devil does she (lady) come from? Wherever did that fat fellow pick her (lady) up?'' (he)

Monsieur Rodolphe Boulanger was thirty-four; he (Boulanger) was of brutal temperament and intelligent perspicacity, having, moreover, had much to do with women, and knowing them well. This one had seemed pretty to him (Boulanger); so he (Boulanger) was thinking about her (Emma) and her (Emma) husband.

``I think he (fellow) is very stupid. She (lady) is tired of him (fellow), no doubt. He (fellow) has dirty nails, and hasn't shaved for three days. While he (fellow) is trotting after his (fellow) patients, she (lady) sits there botching socks. And she (lady) gets bored! She (lady) would like to live in town and dance polkas every evening. Poor little woman! She (woman) is gaping after love like a carp after water on a kitchen-table. With three words of gallantry she (woman)'d adore one, I'm sure of it. She (woman)'d be tender, charming. Yes; but how to get rid of her (woman) afterwards?'' (him)

Then the difficulties of love-making seen in the distance made him (Boulanger) by contrast think of his (Boulanger) mistress. She (mistress) was an actress at Rouen, whom he (Boulanger) kept; and when he (Boulanger) had pondered over this image, with which, even in remembrance, he (Boulanger) was satiated--

``Ah! Madame Bovary,'' (he)
he (Boulanger) thought,
``is much prettier, especially fresher. Virginie is decidedly beginning to grow fat. She (woman) is so finiky about her (woman) pleasures; and, besides, she (woman) has a mania for prawns.'' (he)

The fields were empty, and around him (Boulanger) Rodolphe only heard the regular beating of the grass striking against his (Rodolphe) boots, with a cry of the grasshopper hidden at a distance among the oats. He (Rodolphe) again saw Emma in her (Emma) room, dressed as he (Rodolphe) had seen her (Emma), and he (Rodolphe) undressed her (Emma).

``Oh, I will have her (woman),'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) cried, striking a blow with his (Rodolphe) stick at a clod in front of him (Rodolphe). And he (Rodolphe) at once began to consider the political part of the enterprise. He (Rodolphe) asked himself--

``Where shall we meet? By what means? We shall always be having the brat on our hands, and the servant, the neighbours, and husband, all sorts of worries. Pshaw! one would lose too much time over it.'' (He)

Then he (Rodolphe) resumed,

``She (woman) really has eyes that pierce one's heart like a gimlet. And that pale complexion! I adore pale women!'' (he)

When he (Rodolphe) reached the top of the Arguiel hills he (Rodolphe) had made up his (Rodolphe) mind.

``It's only finding the opportunities. Well, I will call in now and then. I'll send them venison, poultry; I'll have myself bled, if need be. We shall become friends; I'll invite them to my place. By Jove!'' (he)
added he (Rodolphe),
``there's the agricultural show coming on. She (woman)'ll be there. I shall see her (woman). We'll begin boldly, for that's the surest way.'' (he)

Chapter Eight

At last it came, the famous agricultural show. On the morning of the solemnity all the inhabitants at their doors were chatting over the preparations. The pediment of the town hall had been hung with garlands of ivy; a tent had been erected in a meadow for the banquet; and in the middle of the Place, in front of the church, a kind of bombarde was to announce the arrival of the prefect and the names of the successful farmers who had obtained prizes. The National Guard of Buchy -LRB-there was none at Yonville-RRB- had come to join the corps of firemen, of whom Binet was captain. On that day he (captain) wore a collar even higher than usual; and, tightly buttoned in his (captain) tunic, his (captain) figure was so stiff and motionless that the whole vital portion of his (captain) person seemed to have descended into his (captain) legs, which rose in a cadence of set steps with a single movement. As there was some rivalry between the tax-collector and the colonel, both, to show off their talents, drilled their men separately. One saw the red epaulettes and the black breastplates pass and re-pass alternately; there was no end to it, and it constantly began again. There had never been such a display of pomp. Several citizens had scoured their houses the evening before; tri-coloured flags hung from half-open windows; all the public-houses were full; and in the lovely weather the starched caps, the golden crosses, and the coloured neckerchiefs seemed whiter than snow, shone in the sun, and relieved with the motley colours the sombre monotony of the frock-coats and blue smocks. The neighbouring farmers' wives, when they got off their horses, pulled out the long pins that fastened around them their dresses, turned up for fear of mud; and the husbands, for their part, in order to save their hats, kept their handkerchiefs around them, holding one corner between their teeth.

The crowd came into the main street from both ends of the village. People poured in from the lanes, the alleys, the houses; and from time to time one heard knockers banging against doors closing behind women with their gloves, who were going out to see the fete. What was most admired were two long lamp-stands covered with lanterns, that flanked a platform on which the authorities were to sit. Besides this there were against the four columns of the town hall four kinds of poles, each bearing a small standard of greenish cloth, embellished with inscriptions in gold letters.

On one was written,

``To Commerce'' (unknown)
; on the other,
``To Agriculture'' (unknown)
; on the third,
``To Industry'' (unknown)
; and on the fourth,
``To the Fine Arts.'' (Madame Lefrancois/Lefrancois)

But the jubilation that brightened all faces seemed to darken that of Madame Lefrancois, the innkeeper. Standing on her (Lefrancois) kitchen-steps she (Lefrancois) muttered to herself,

``What rubbish! what rubbish! With their canvas booth! Do they think the prefect will be glad to dine down there under a tent like a gipsy? They call all this fussing doing good to the place! Then it wasn't worth while sending to Neufchatel for the keeper of a cookshop! And for whom? For cowherds! tatterdemalions!'' (she)

The druggist was passing. He (Lefrancois) had on a frock-coat, nankeen trousers, beaver shoes, and, for a wonder, a hat with a low crown.

``Your servant! Excuse me, I am in a hurry.'' (the widow)
And as the fat widow asked where he (Lefrancois) was going--

``It seems odd to you, doesn't it, I who am always more cooped up in my laboratory than the man's rat in his (man) cheese.'' (he)

``What cheese?'' (the landlady)
asked the landlady.

``Oh, nothing! nothing!'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
Homais continued.
``I merely wished to convey to you, Madame Lefrancois, that I usually live at home like a recluse. To-day, however, considering the circumstances, it is necessary--'' (she)

``Oh, you're going down there!'' (she)
she (landlady) said contemptuously.

``Yes, I am going,'' (the druggist)
replied the druggist, astonished.
``Am I not a member of the consulting commission?'' (Madame Lefrancois/Lefrancois)

Mere Lefrancois looked at him (Lefrancois) for a few moments, and ended by saying with a smile--

``That's another pair of shoes! But what does agriculture matter to you? Do you understand anything about it?'' (him)

``Certainly I understand it, since I am a druggist--that is to say, a chemist. And the object of chemistry, Madame Lefrancois, being the knowledge of the reciprocal and molecular action of all natural bodies, it follows that agriculture is comprised within its domain. And, in fact, the composition of the manure, the fermentation of liquids, the analyses of gases, and the influence of miasmata, what, I ask you, is all this, if it isn't chemistry, pure and simple?'' (The landlady)

The landlady did not answer. Homais went on--

``Do you think that to be an agriculturist it is necessary to have tilled the earth or fattened fowls oneself? It is necessary rather to know the composition of the substances in question--the geological strata, the atmospheric actions, the quality of the soil, the minerals, the waters, the density of the different bodies, their capillarity, and what not. And one must be master of all the principles of hygiene in order to direct, criticize the construction of buildings, the feeding of animals, the diet of domestics. And, moreover, Madame Lefrancois, one must know botany, be able to distinguish between plants, you understand, which are the wholesome and those that are deleterious, which are unproductive and which nutritive, if it is well to pull them up here and re-sow them there, to propagate some, destroy others; in brief, one must keep pace with science by means of pamphlets and public papers, be always on the alert to find out improvements.'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)

The landlady never took her (landlady) eyes off the

``Cafe Francois'' (the chemist)
and the chemist went on--

``Would to God our agriculturists were chemists, or that at least they would pay more attention to the counsels of science. Thus lately I myself wrote a considerable tract, a memoir of over seventy-two pages, entitled, `Cider, its Manufacture and its Effects, together with some New Reflections on the Subject,' that I sent to the Agricultural Society of Rouen, and which even procured me the honour of being received among its members--Section, Agriculture; Class, Pomological. Well, if my work had been given to the public--'' (the chemist)
But the druggist stopped, Madame Lefrancois seemed so preoccupied.

``Just look at them!'' (she)
she (landlady) said.
``It's past comprehension! Such a cookshop as that!'' (she)
And with a shrug of the shoulders that stretched out over her (landlady) breast the stitches of her (landlady) knitted bodice, she (landlady) pointed with both hands at her (landlady) rival's inn, whence songs were heard issuing.
``Well, it won't last long,'' (she)
she (landlady) added.
``It'll be over before a week.'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)

Homais drew back with stupefaction. She (landlady) came down three steps and whispered in his (Lefrancois) ear--

``What! you didn't know it? There is to be an execution in next week. It's Lheureux who is selling him (It) out; he (It) has killed him (It) with bills.'' (She)

``What a terrible catastrophe!'' (the druggist)
cried the druggist, who always found expressions in harmony with all imaginable circumstances.

Then the landlady began telling him (Lefrancois) the story that she (landlady) had heard from Theodore, Monsieur Guillaumin's servant, and although she (landlady) detested Tellier, she (landlady) blamed Lheureux. He (Tellier) was

``a wheedler, a sneak.'' (He)

``There!'' (she)
she (landlady) said.
``Look at him (It)! he (It) is in the market; he (It) is bowing to Madame Bovary, who's got on a green bonnet. Why, she (It)'s taking Monsieur Boulanger's arm.'' (unknown)

``Madame Bovary!'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
exclaimed Homais.
``I must go at once and pay her (It) my respects. Perhaps she (It)'ll be very glad to have a seat in the enclosure under the peristyle.'' (Madame Lefrancois/Lefrancois)
And, without heeding Madame Lefrancois, who was calling him (Lefrancois) back to tell him (Lefrancois) more about it, the druggist walked off rapidly with a smile on his (Lefrancois) lips, with straight knees, bowing copiously to right and left, and taking up much room with the large tails of his (Lefrancois) frock-coat that fluttered behind him (Lefrancois) in the wind.

Rodolphe, having caught sight of him (Rodolphe) from afar, hurried on, but Madame Bovary lost her (landlady) breath; so he (Rodolphe) walked more slowly, and, smiling at her (landlady), said in a rough tone--

``It's only to get away from that fat fellow, you know, the druggist.'' (her)
She (landlady) pressed his (Rodolphe) elbow.

``What's the meaning of that?'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) asked himself. And he (Rodolphe) looked at her (landlady) out of the corner of his (Rodolphe) eyes.

Her (landlady) profile was so calm that one could guess nothing from it. It stood out in the light from the oval of her (landlady) bonnet, with pale ribbons on it like the leaves of weeds. Her (landlady) eyes with their long curved lashes looked straight before her (landlady), and though wide open, they seemed slightly puckered by the cheek-bones, because of the blood pulsing gently under the delicate skin. A pink line ran along the partition between her (landlady) nostrils. Her (landlady) head was bent upon her (landlady) shoulder, and the pearl tips of her (landlady) white teeth were seen between her (landlady) lips.

``Is she (It) making fun of me?'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
thought Rodolphe.

Emma's gesture, however, had only been meant for a warning; for Monsieur Lheureux was accompanying them, and spoke now and again as if to enter into the conversation.

``What a superb day! Everybody is out! The wind is east!'' (Madame)

And neither Madame Bovary nor Rodolphe answered him (Rodolphe), whilst at the slightest movement made by them he (Rodolphe) drew near, saying,

``I beg your pardon!'' (he)
and raised his (Rodolphe) hat.

When they reached the farrier's house, instead of following the road up to the fence, Rodolphe suddenly turned down a path, drawing with him (Rodolphe) Madame Bovary. He (Rodolphe) called out--

``Good evening, Monsieur Lheureux! See you again presently.'' (He)

``How you got rid of him (fellow)!'' (she)
she (Emma) said, laughing.

``Why,'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) went on,
``allow oneself to be intruded upon by others? And as to-day I have the happiness of being with you--'' (he)

Emma blushed. He (Rodolphe) did not finish his (Rodolphe) sentence. Then he (Rodolphe) talked of the fine weather and of the pleasure of walking on the grass. A few daisies had sprung up again.

``Here are some pretty Easter daisies,'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) said,
``and enough of them to furnish oracles to all the amorous maids in the place.'' (he)

He (Rodolphe) added,

``Shall I pick some? What do you think?'' (He)

``Are you in love?'' (she)
she (Emma) asked, coughing a little.

``H'm, h'm! who knows?'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
answered Rodolphe.

The meadow began to fill, and the housewives hustled you with their great umbrellas, their baskets, and their babies. One had often to get out of the way of a long file of country folk, servant-maids with blue stockings, flat shoes, silver rings, and who smelt of milk, when one passed close to them. They walked along holding one another by the hand, and thus they spread over the whole field from the row of open trees to the banquet tent.

But this was the examination time, and the farmers one after the other entered a kind of enclosure formed by a long cord supported on sticks.

The beasts were there, their noses towards the cord, and making a confused line with their unequal rumps. Drowsy pigs were burrowing in the earth with their snouts, calves were bleating, lambs baaing; the cows, on knees folded in, were stretching their bellies on the grass, slowly chewing the cud, and blinking their heavy eyelids at the gnats that buzzed round them. Plough-men with bare arms were holding by the halter prancing stallions that neighed with dilated nostrils looking towards the mares. These stood quietly, stretching out their heads and flowing manes, while their foals rested in their shadow, or now and then came and sucked them. And above the long undulation of these crowded animals one saw some white mane rising in the wind like a wave, or some sharp horns sticking out, and the heads of men running about. Apart, outside the enclosure, a hundred paces off, was a large black bull, muzzled, with an iron ring in its nostrils, and who moved no more than if he (manes) had been in bronze. A child in rags was holding him (manes) by a rope.

Between the two lines the committee-men were walking with heavy steps, examining each animal, then consulting one another in a low voice. One who seemed of more importance now and then took notes in a book as he (manes) walked along. This was the president of the jury, Monsieur Derozerays de la Panville. As soon as he (manes) recognised Rodolphe he (manes) came forward quickly, and smiling amiably, said--

``What! Monsieur Boulanger, you are deserting us?'' (he)

Rodolphe protested that he (Rodolphe) was just coming. But when the president had disappeared--

``Ma foi!*'' (the president)
said he (president),
``I shall not go. Your company is better than his (Boulanger).'' (he)

*Upon my word!

And while poking fun at the show, Rodolphe, to move about more easily, showed the gendarme his (Rodolphe) blue card, and even stopped now and then in front of some fine beast, which Madame Bovary did not at all admire. He (Rodolphe) noticed this, and began jeering at the Yonville ladies and their dresses; then he (Rodolphe) apologised for the negligence of his (Rodolphe) own. He (Rodolphe) had that incongruity of common and elegant in which the habitually vulgar think they see the revelation of an eccentric existence, of the perturbations of sentiment, the tyrannies of art, and always a certain contempt for social conventions, that seduces or exasperates them. Thus his (Rodolphe) cambric shirt with plaited cuffs was blown out by the wind in the opening of his (Rodolphe) waistcoat of grey ticking, and his (Rodolphe) broad-striped trousers disclosed at the ankle nankeen boots with patent leather gaiters.

These were so polished that they reflected the grass. He (Rodolphe) trampled on horses's dung with them, one hand in the pocket of his (Rodolphe) jacket and his (Rodolphe) straw hat on one side.

``Besides,'' (he)
added he (Rodolphe),
``when one lives in the country--'' (he)

``It's waste of time,'' (he)
said Emma.

``That is true,'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
replied Rodolphe.
``To think that not one of these people is capable of understanding even the cut of a coat!'' (unknown)

Then they talked about provincial mediocrity, of the lives it crushed, the illusions lost there.

``And I too,'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
said Rodolphe,
``am drifting into depression.'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)

``You!'' (she)
she (Emma) said in astonishment;
``I thought you very light-hearted.'' (she)

``Ah! yes. I seem so, because in the midst of the world I know how to wear the mask of a scoffer upon my face; and yet, how many a time at the sight of a cemetery by moonlight have I not asked myself whether it were not better to join those sleeping there!'' (unknown)

``Oh! and your friends?'' (she)
she (Emma) said.
``You do not think of them.'' (unknown)

``My friends! What friends? Have I any? Who cares for me?'' (he)
And he (Rodolphe) accompanied the last words with a kind of whistling of the lips.

But they were obliged to separate from each other because of a great pile of chairs that a man was carrying behind them. He (man) was so overladen with them that one could only see the tips of his (man) wooden shoes and the ends of his (man) two outstretched arms. It was Lestiboudois, the gravedigger, who was carrying the church chairs about amongst the people. Alive to all that concerned his (man) interests, he (man) had hit upon this means of turning the show to account; and his (man) idea was succeeding, for he (man) no longer knew which way to turn. In fact, the villagers, who were hot, quarreled for these seats, whose straw smelt of incense, and they leant against the thick backs, stained with the wax of candles, with a certain veneration.

Madame Bovary again took Rodolphe's arm; he (Rodolphe) went on as if speaking to himself--

``Yes, I have missed so many things. Always alone! Ah! if I had some aim in life, if I had met some love, if I had found someone! Oh, how I would have spent all the energy of which I am capable, surmounted everything, overcome everything!'' (he)

``Yet it seems to me,'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma,
``that you are not to be pitied.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

``Ah! you think so?'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
said Rodolphe.

``For, after all,'' (she)
she (Emma) went on,
``you are free--'' (she)
she (Emma) hesitated,
``rich--'' (she)

``Do not mock me,'' (she)
he (Rodolphe) replied.

And she (Emma) protested that she (Emma) was not mocking him (Rodolphe), when the report of a cannon resounded. Immediately all began hustling one another pell-mell towards the village.

It was a false alarm. The prefect seemed not to be coming, and the members of the jury felt much embarrassed, not knowing if they ought to begin the meeting or still wait.

At last at the end of the Place a large hired landau appeared, drawn by two thin horses, which a coachman in a white hat was whipping lustily. Binet had only just time to shout,

``Present arms!'' (Binet/Monsieur Binet)
and the colonel to imitate him (colonel). All ran towards the enclosure; everyone pushed forward. A few even forgot their collars; but the equipage of the prefect seemed to anticipate the crowd, and the two yoked jades, trapesing in their harness, came up at a little trot in front of the peristyle of the town hall at the very moment when the National Guard and firemen deployed, beating drums and marking time.

``Present!'' (Binet/Monsieur Binet)
shouted Binet.

``Halt!'' (the colonel)
shouted the colonel.
``Left about, march.'' (unknown)

And after presenting arms, during which the clang of the band, letting loose, rang out like a brass kettle rolling downstairs, all the guns were lowered. Then was seen stepping down from the carriage a gentleman in a short coat with silver braiding, with bald brow, and wearing a tuft of hair at the back of his (gentleman) head, of a sallow complexion and the most benign appearance. His (gentleman) eyes, very large and covered by heavy lids, were half-closed to look at the crowd, while at the same time he (gentleman) raised his (gentleman) sharp nose, and forced a smile upon his (gentleman) sunken mouth. He (gentleman) recognised the mayor by his (gentleman) scarf, and explained to him (gentleman) that the prefect was not able to come. He (prefect) himself was a councillor at the prefecture; then he (prefect) added a few apologies. Monsieur Tuvache answered them with compliments; the other confessed himself nervous; and they remained thus, face to face, their foreheads almost touching, with the members of the jury all round, the municipal council, the notable personages, the National Guard and the crowd. The councillor pressing his (councillor) little cocked hat to his (councillor) breast repeated his (councillor) bows, while Tuvache, bent like a bow, also smiled, stammered, tried to say something, protested his (councillor) devotion to the monarchy and the honour that was being done to Yonville.

Hippolyte, the groom from the inn, took the head of the horses from the coachman, and, limping along with his (groom) club-foot, led them to the door of the

``Lion d’Or'' (the coachman)
, where a number of peasants collected to look at the carriage. The drum beat, the howitzer thundered, and the gentlemen one by one mounted the platform, where they sat down in red utrecht velvet arm-chairs that had been lent by Madame Tuvache.

All these people looked alike. Their fair flabby faces, somewhat tanned by the sun, were the colour of sweet cider, and their puffy whiskers emerged from stiff collars, kept up by white cravats with broad bows. All the waist-coats were of velvet, double-breasted; all the watches had, at the end of a long ribbon, an oval cornelian seal; everyone rested his (Their) two hands on his (Their) thighs, carefully stretching the stride of their trousers, whose unsponged glossy cloth shone more brilliantly than the leather of their heavy boots.

The ladies of the company stood at the back under the vestibule between the pillars while the common herd was opposite, standing up or sitting on chairs. As a matter of fact, Lestiboudois had brought thither all those that he (Their) had moved from the field, and he (Their) even kept running back every minute to fetch others from the church. He (Their) caused such confusion with this piece of business that one had great difficulty in getting to the small steps of the platform.

``I think,'' (Lheureux/Monsieur Lheureux)
said Monsieur Lheureux to the chemist, who was passing to his (chemist) place,
``that they ought to have put up two Venetian masts with something rather severe and rich for ornaments; it would have been a very pretty effect.'' (the chemist)

``To be sure,'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
replied Homais;
``but what can you expect? The mayor took everything on his (mayor) own shoulders. He (mayor) hasn't much taste. Poor Tuvache! and he (mayor) is even completely destitute of what is called the genius of art.'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)

Rodolphe, meanwhile, with Madame Bovary, had gone up to the first floor of the town hall, to the

``council-room,'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)
and, as it was empty, he (Rodolphe) declared that they could enjoy the sight there more comfortably. He (Rodolphe) fetched three stools from the round table under the bust of the monarch, and having carried them to one of the windows, they sat down by each other.

There was commotion on the platform, long whisperings, much parleying. At last the councillor got up. They knew now that his (councillor) name was Lieuvain, and in the crowd the name was passed from one to the other. After he (councillor) had collated a few pages, and bent over them to see better, he (councillor) began--

``Gentlemen! May I be permitted first of all -LRB-before addressing you on the object of our meeting to-day, and this sentiment will, I am sure, be shared by you all-RRB-, may I be permitted, I say, to pay a tribute to the higher administration, to the government to the monarch, gentle men, our sovereign, to that beloved king, to whom no branch of public or private prosperity is a matter of indifference, and who directs with a hand at once so firm and wise the chariot of the state amid the incessant perils of a stormy sea, knowing, moreover, how to make peace respected as well as war, industry, commerce, agriculture, and the fine arts?'' (he)

``I ought,'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
said Rodolphe,
``to get back a little further.'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)

``Why?'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma.

But at this moment the voice of the councillor rose to an extraordinary pitch. He (Rodolphe) declaimed--

``This is no longer the time, gentlemen, when civil discord ensanguined our public places, when the landlord, the business-man, the working-man himself, falling asleep at night, lying down to peaceful sleep, trembled lest he (working-man) should be awakened suddenly by the noise of incendiary tocsins, when the most subversive doctrines audaciously sapped foundations.'' (He)

``Well, someone down there might see me,'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
Rodolphe resumed,
``then I should have to invent excuses for a fortnight; and with my bad reputation--'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)

``Oh, you are slandering yourself,'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
said Emma.

``No! It is dreadful, I assure you.'' (unknown)

``But, gentlemen,'' (the councillor)
continued the councillor,
``if, banishing from my memory the remembrance of these sad pictures, I carry my eyes back to the actual situation of our dear country, what do I see there? Everywhere commerce and the arts are flourishing; everywhere new means of communication, like so many new arteries in the body of the state, establish within it new relations. Our great industrial centres have recovered all their activity; religion, more consolidated, smiles in all hearts; our ports are full, confidence is born again, and France breathes once more!'' (the councillor)

``Besides,'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
added Rodolphe,
``perhaps from the world's point of view they are right.'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)

``How so?'' (she)
she (Emma) asked.

``What!'' (he)
said he (Rodolphe).
``Do you not know that there are souls constantly tormented? They need by turns to dream and to act, the purest passions and the most turbulent joys, and thus they fling themselves into all sorts of fantasies, of follies.'' (she)

Then she (Emma) looked at him (Rodolphe) as one looks at a traveller who has voyaged over strange lands, and went on--

``We have not even this distraction, we poor women!'' (a traveller)

``A sad distraction, for happiness isn't found in it.'' (unknown)

``But is it ever found?'' (she)
she (Emma) asked.

``Yes; one day it comes,'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) answered.

``And this is what you have understood,'' (the councillor)
said the councillor.

``You, farmers, agricultural labourers! you pacific pioneers of a work that belongs wholly to civilization! you, men of progress and morality, you have understood, I say, that political storms are even more redoubtable than atmospheric disturbances!'' (unknown)

``It comes one day,'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
repeated Rodolphe,
``one day suddenly, and when one is despairing of it. Then the horizon expands; it is as if a voice cried, `It is here!' You feel the need of confiding the whole of your life, of giving everything, sacrificing everything to this being. There is no need for explanations; they understand one another. They have seen each other in dreams!'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)

-LRB-And he (Rodolphe) looked at her (Emma).-RRB-

``In fine, here it is, this treasure so sought after, here before you. It glitters, it flashes; yet one still doubts, one does not believe it; one remains dazzled, as if one went out from darkness into light.'' (he)

And as he (Rodolphe) ended Rodolphe suited the action to the word. He (Rodolphe) passed his (Rodolphe) hand over his (Rodolphe) face, like a man seized with giddiness. Then he (Rodolphe) let it fall on Emma's. She (Emma) took hers away.

``And who would be surprised at it, gentlemen? He (your) only who is so blind, so plunged -LRB-I do not fear to say it-RRB-, so plunged in the prejudices of another age as still to misunderstand the spirit of agricultural populations. Where, indeed, is to be found more patriotism than in the country, greater devotion to the public welfare, more intelligence, in a word? And, gentlemen, I do not mean that superficial intelligence, vain ornament of idle minds, but rather that profound and balanced intelligence that applies itself above all else to useful objects, thus contributing to the good of all, to the common amelioration and to the support of the state, born of respect for law and the practice of duty--'' (unknown)

``Ah! again!'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
said Rodolphe.
``Always `duty.' I am sick of the word. They are a lot of old blockheads in flannel vests and of old women with foot-warmers and rosaries who constantly drone into our ears `Duty, duty!' Ah! by Jove! one's duty is to feel what is great, cherish the beautiful, and not accept all the conventions of society with the ignominy that it imposes upon us.'' (unknown)

``Yet--yet--'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)
objected Madame Bovary.

``No, no! Why cry out against the passions? Are they not the one beautiful thing on the earth, the source of heroism, of enthusiasm, of poetry, music, the arts, of everything, in a word?'' (unknown)

``But one must,'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma,
``to some extent bow to the opinion of the world and accept its moral code.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

``Ah! but there are two,'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) replied.
``The small, the conventional, that of men, that which constantly changes, that brays out so loudly, that makes such a commotion here below, of the earth earthly, like the mass of imbeciles you see down there. But the other, the eternal, that is about us and above, like the landscape that surrounds us, and the blue heavens that give us light.'' (Monsieur Lieuvain/Lieuvain)

Monsieur Lieuvain had just wiped his (Rodolphe) mouth with a pocket-handkerchief. He (Rodolphe) continued--

``And what should I do here gentlemen, pointing out to you the uses of agriculture? Who supplies our wants? Who provides our means of subsistence? Is it not the agriculturist? The agriculturist, gentlemen, who, sowing with laborious hand the fertile furrows of the country, brings forth the corn, which, being ground, is made into a powder by means of ingenious machinery, comes out thence under the name of flour, and from there, transported to our cities, is soon delivered at the baker's, who makes it into food for poor and rich alike. Again, is it not the agriculturist who fattens, for our clothes, his (baker) abundant flocks in the pastures? For how should we clothe ourselves, how nourish ourselves, without the agriculturist? And, gentlemen, is it even necessary to go so far for examples? Who has not frequently reflected on all the momentous things that we get out of that modest animal, the ornament of poultry-yards, that provides us at once with a soft pillow for our bed, with succulent flesh for our tables, and eggs? But I should never end if I were to enumerate one after the other all the different products which the earth, well cultivated, like a generous mother, lavishes upon her (mother) children. Here it is the vine, elsewhere the apple tree for cider, there colza, farther on cheeses and flax. Gentlemen, let us not forget flax, which has made such great strides of late years, and to which I will more particularly call your attention.'' (He)

He (Rodolphe) had no need to call it, for all the mouths of the multitude were wide open, as if to drink in his (Rodolphe) words. Tuvache by his (Rodolphe) side listened to him (Rodolphe) with staring eyes. Monsieur Derozerays from time to time softly closed his (Rodolphe) eyelids, and farther on the chemist, with his (Rodolphe) son Napoleon between his (Rodolphe) knees, put his (Rodolphe) hand behind his (Rodolphe) ear in order not to lose a syllable. The chins of the other members of the jury went slowly up and down in their waistcoats in sign of approval. The firemen at the foot of the platform rested on their bayonets; and Binet, motionless, stood with out-turned elbows, the point of his (Rodolphe) sabre in the air. Perhaps he (Rodolphe) could hear, but certainly he (Rodolphe) could see nothing, because of the visor of his (Rodolphe) helmet, that fell down on his (Rodolphe) nose. His (Rodolphe) lieutenant, the youngest son of Monsieur Tuvache, had a bigger one, for his (Rodolphe) was enormous, and shook on his (Rodolphe) head, and from it an end of his (Rodolphe) cotton scarf peeped out. He (Rodolphe) smiled beneath it with a perfectly infantine sweetness, and his (Rodolphe) pale little face, whence drops were running, wore an expression of enjoyment and sleepiness.

The square as far as the houses was crowded with people. One saw folk leaning on their elbows at all the windows, others standing at doors, and Justin, in front of the chemist's shop, seemed quite transfixed by the sight of what he (Justin) was looking at. In spite of the silence Monsieur Lieuvain's voice was lost in the air. It reached you in fragments of phrases, and interrupted here and there by the creaking of chairs in the crowd; then you suddenly heard the long bellowing of an ox, or else the bleating of the lambs, who answered one another at street corners. In fact, the cowherds and shepherds had driven their beasts thus far, and these lowed from time to time, while with their tongues they tore down some scrap of foliage that hung above their mouths.

Rodolphe had drawn nearer to Emma, and said to her (Emma) in a low voice, speaking rapidly--

``Does not this conspiracy of the world revolt you? Is there a single sentiment it does not condemn? The noblest instincts, the purest sympathies are persecuted, slandered; and if at length two poor souls do meet, all is so organised that they cannot blend together. Yet they will make the attempt; they will flutter their wings; they will call upon each other. Oh! no matter. Sooner or later, in six months, ten years, they will come together, will love; for fate has decreed it, and they are born one for the other.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

His (Rodolphe) arms were folded across his (Rodolphe) knees, and thus lifting his (Rodolphe) face towards Emma, close by her (Emma), he (Rodolphe) looked fixedly at her (Emma). She (Emma) noticed in his (Rodolphe) eyes small golden lines radiating from black pupils; she (Emma) even smelt the perfume of the pomade that made his (Rodolphe) hair glossy.

Then a faintness came over her (Emma); she (Emma) recalled the Viscount who had waltzed with her (Emma) at Vaubyessard, and his (Rodolphe) beard exhaled like this air an odour of vanilla and citron, and mechanically she (Emma) half-closed her (Emma) eyes the better to breathe it in. But in making this movement, as she (Emma) leant back in her (Emma) chair, she (Emma) saw in the distance, right on the line of the horizon, the old diligence, the

``Hirondelle,'' (she)
that was slowly descending the hill of Leux, dragging after it a long trail of dust. It was in this yellow carriage that Leon had so often come back to her (Emma), and by this route down there that he (Leon) had gone for ever. She (Emma) fancied she (Emma) saw him (Leon) opposite at his (Leon) windows; then all grew confused; clouds gathered; it seemed to her (Emma) that she (Emma) was again turning in the waltz under the light of the lustres on the arm of the Viscount, and that Leon was not far away, that he (Leon) was coming; and yet all the time she (Emma) was conscious of the scent of Rodolphe's head by her (Emma) side. This sweetness of sensation pierced through her (Emma) old desires, and these, like grains of sand under a gust of wind, eddied to and fro in the subtle breath of the perfume which suffused her (Emma) soul. She (Emma) opened wide her (Emma) nostrils several times to drink in the freshness of the ivy round the capitals. She (Emma) took off her (Emma) gloves, she (Emma) wiped her (Emma) hands, then fanned her (Emma) face with her (Emma) handkerchief, while athwart the throbbing of her (Emma) temples she (Emma) heard the murmur of the crowd and the voice of the councillor intoning his (councillor) phrases. He (councillor) said--``Continue, persevere; listen neither to the suggestions of routine, nor to the over-hasty councils of a rash empiricism.

``Apply yourselves, above all, to the amelioration of the soil, to good manures, to the development of the equine, bovine, ovine, and porcine races. Let these shows be to you pacific arenas, where the victor in leaving it will hold forth a hand to the vanquished, and will fraternise with him (victor) in the hope of better success. And you, aged servants, humble domestics, whose hard labour no Government up to this day has taken into consideration, come hither to receive the reward of your silent virtues, and be assured that the state henceforward has its eye upon you; that it encourages you, protects you; that it will accede to your just demands, and alleviate as much as in it lies the burden of your painful sacrifices.'' (Monsieur Lieuvain/Lieuvain)

Monsieur Lieuvain then sat down; Monsieur Derozerays got up, beginning another speech. His (councillor) was not perhaps so florid as that of the councillor, but it recommended itself by a more direct style, that is to say, by more special knowledge and more elevated considerations. Thus the praise of the Government took up less space in it; religion and agriculture more. He (councillor) showed in it the relations of these two, and how they had always contributed to civilisation. Rodolphe with Madame Bovary was talking dreams, presentiments, magnetism. Going back to the cradle of society, the orator painted those fierce times when men lived on acorns in the heart of woods. Then they had left off the skins of beasts, had put on cloth, tilled the soil, planted the vine. Was this a good, and in this discovery was there not more of injury than of gain? Monsieur Derozerays set himself this problem. From magnetism little by little Rodolphe had come to affinities, and while the president was citing Cincinnatus and his (president) plough, Diocletian, planting his (president) cabbages, and the Emperors of China inaugurating the year by the sowing of seed, the young man was explaining to the young woman that these irresistible attractions find their cause in some previous state of existence.

``Thus we,'' (he)
he (man) said,
``why did we come to know one another? What chance willed it? It was because across the infinite, like two streams that flow but to unite; our special bents of mind had driven us towards each other.'' (he)

And he (man) seized her (woman) hand; she (woman) did not withdraw it.

``For good farming generally!'' (the president)
cried the president.

``Just now, for example, when I went to your house.'' (unknown)

``To Monsieur Bizat of Quincampoix.'' (unknown)

``Did I know I should accompany you?'' (unknown)

``Seventy francs.'' (unknown)
