``A hundred times I wished to go; and I followed you--I remained.'' (unknown)

``Manures!'' (unknown)

``And I shall remain to-night, to-morrow, all other days, all my life!'' (unknown)

``To Monsieur Caron of Argueil, a gold medal!'' (unknown)

``For I have never in the society of any other person found so complete a charm.'' (unknown)

``To Monsieur Bain of Givry-Saint-Martin.'' (unknown)

``And I shall carry away with me the remembrance of you.'' (unknown)

``For a merino ram!'' (unknown)

``But you will forget me; I shall pass away like a shadow.'' (unknown)

``To Monsieur Belot of Notre-Dame.'' (unknown)

``Oh, no! I shall be something in your thought, in your life, shall I not?'' (unknown)

``Porcine race; prizes--equal, to Messrs. Leherisse and Cullembourg, sixty francs!'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)

Rodolphe was pressing her (woman) hand, and he (Rodolphe) felt it all warm and quivering like a captive dove that wants to fly away; but, whether she (woman) was trying to take it away or whether she (woman) was answering his (Rodolphe) pressure; she (woman) made a movement with her (woman) fingers. He (Rodolphe) exclaimed--

``Oh, I thank you! You do not repulse me! You are good! You understand that I am yours! Let me look at you; let me contemplate you!'' (He)

A gust of wind that blew in at the window ruffled the cloth on the table, and in the square below all the great caps of the peasant women were uplifted by it like the wings of white butterflies fluttering.

``Use of oil-cakes,'' (the president)
continued the president. He (president) was hurrying on:
``Flemish manure-flax-growing-drainage-long leases-domestic service.'' (He)

Rodolphe was no longer speaking. They looked at one another. A supreme desire made their dry lips tremble, and wearily, without an effort, their fingers intertwined.

``Catherine Nicaise Elizabeth Leroux, of Sassetot-la-Guerriere, for fifty-four years of service at the same farm, a silver medal--value, twenty-five francs!'' (unknown)

``Where is Catherine Leroux?'' (the councillor)
repeated the councillor.

She (woman) did not present herself, and one could hear voices whispering--

``Go up!'' (She)

``Don't be afraid!'' (unknown)

``Oh, how stupid she (Leroux) is!'' (unknown)

``Well, is she (Leroux) there?'' (unknown)
cried Tuvache.

``Yes; here she (Leroux) is.'' (unknown)

``Then let her (Leroux) come up!'' (a woman)

Then there came forward on the platform a little old woman with timid bearing, who seemed to shrink within her (woman) poor clothes. On her (woman) feet she (woman) wore heavy wooden clogs, and from her (woman) hips hung a large blue apron. Her (woman) pale face framed in a borderless cap was more wrinkled than a withered russet apple. And from the sleeves of her (woman) red jacket looked out two large hands with knotty joints, the dust of barns, the potash of washing the grease of wools had so encrusted, roughened, hardened these that they seemed dirty, although they had been rinsed in clear water; and by dint of long service they remained half open, as if to bear humble witness for themselves of so much suffering endured. Something of monastic rigidity dignified her (woman) face. Nothing of sadness or of emotion weakened that pale look. In her (woman) constant living with animals she (woman) had caught their dumbness and their calm. It was the first time that she (woman) found herself in the midst of so large a company, and inwardly scared by the flags, the drums, the gentlemen in frock-coats, and the order of the councillor, she (woman) stood motionless, not knowing whether to advance or run away, nor why the crowd was pushing her (woman) and the jury were smiling at her (woman).

Thus stood before these radiant bourgeois this half-century of servitude.

``Approach, venerable Catherine Nicaise Elizabeth Leroux!'' (the councillor Approach)
said the councillor, who had taken the list of prize-winners from the president; and, looking at the piece of paper and the old woman by turns, he (president) repeated in a fatherly tone--
``Approach! approach!'' (he)

``Are you deaf?'' (Monsieur Tuvache/Tuvache)
said Tuvache, fidgeting in his (president) armchair; and he (president) began shouting in her (woman) ear,
``Fifty-four years of service. A silver medal! Twenty-five francs! For you!'' (he)

Then, when she (woman) had her (woman) medal, she (woman) looked at it, and a smile of beatitude spread over her (woman) face; and as she (woman) walked away they could hear her (woman) muttering

``I'll give it to our cure up home, to say some masses for me!'' (she)

``What fanaticism!'' (the chemist)
exclaimed the chemist, leaning across to the notary.

The meeting was over, the crowd dispersed, and now that the speeches had been read, each one fell back into his (chemist) place again, and everything into the old grooves; the masters bullied the servants, and these struck the animals, indolent victors, going back to the stalls, a green-crown on their horns.

The National Guards, however, had gone up to the first floor of the town hall with buns spitted on their bayonets, and the drummer of the battalion carried a basket with bottles. Madame Bovary took Rodolphe's arm; he (Rodolphe) saw her (Guards) home; they separated at her (Guards) door; then he (Rodolphe) walked about alone in the meadow while he (Rodolphe) waited for the time of the banquet.

The feast was long, noisy, ill served; the guests were so crowded that they could hardly move their elbows; and the narrow planks used for forms almost broke down under their weight. They ate hugely. Each one stuffed himself on his (Rodolphe) own account. Sweat stood on every brow, and a whitish steam, like the vapour of a stream on an autumn morning, floated above the table between the hanging lamps. Rodolphe, leaning against the calico of the tent was thinking so earnestly of Emma that he (Rodolphe) heard nothing. Behind him (Rodolphe) on the grass the servants were piling up the dirty plates, his (Rodolphe) neighbours were talking; he (Rodolphe) did not answer them; they filled his (Rodolphe) glass, and there was silence in his (Rodolphe) thoughts in spite of the growing noise. He (Rodolphe) was dreaming of what she (Emma) had said, of the line of her (Emma) lips; her (Emma) face, as in a magic mirror, shone on the plates of the shakos, the folds of her (Emma) gown fell along the walls, and days of love unrolled to all infinity before him (Rodolphe) in the vistas of the future.

He (Rodolphe) saw her (Emma) again in the evening during the fireworks, but she (Emma) was with her (Emma) husband, Madame Homais, and the druggist, who was worrying about the danger of stray rockets, and every moment he (husband) left the company to go and give some advice to Binet.

The pyrotechnic pieces sent to Monsieur Tuvache had, through an excess of caution, been shut up in his (husband) cellar, and so the damp powder would not light, and the principal set piece, that was to represent a dragon biting his (husband) tail, failed completely. Now and then a meagre Roman-candle went off; then the gaping crowd sent up a shout that mingled with the cry of the women, whose waists were being squeezed in the darkness. Emma silently nestled against Charles's shoulder; then, raising her (Emma) chin, she (Emma) watched the luminous rays of the rockets against the dark sky. Rodolphe gazed at her (Emma) in the light of the burning lanterns.

They went out one by one. The stars shone out. A few crops of rain began to fall. She (Emma) knotted her (Emma) fichu round her (Emma) bare head.

At this moment the councillor's carriage came out from the inn.

His (councillor) coachman, who was drunk, suddenly dozed off, and one could see from the distance, above the hood, between the two lanterns, the mass of his (councillor) body, that swayed from right to left with the giving of the traces.

``Truly,'' (the druggist)
said the druggist,
``one ought to proceed most rigorously against drunkenness! I should like to see written up weekly at the door of the town hall on a board ad hoc* the names of all those who during the week got intoxicated on alcohol. Besides, with regard to statistics, one would thus have, as it were, public records that one could refer to in case of need. But excuse me!'' (the druggist)

*Specifically for that.

And he (councillor) once more ran off to the captain. The latter was going back to see his (councillor) lathe again.

``Perhaps you would not do ill,'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
Homais said to him (councillor),
``to send one of your men, or to go yourself--'' (him)

``Leave me alone!'' (him)
answered the tax-collector.
``It's all right!'' (unknown)

``Do not be uneasy,'' (the druggist)
said the druggist, when he (councillor) returned to his (councillor) friends.
``Monsieur Binet has assured me that all precautions have been taken. No sparks have fallen; the pumps are full. Let us go to rest.'' (unknown)

``Ma foi! I want it,'' (Madame Homais)
said Madame Homais, yawning at large.
``But never mind; we've had a beautiful day for our fete.'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)

Rodolphe repeated in a low voice, and with a tender look,

``Oh, yes! very beautiful!'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)

And having bowed to one another, they separated.

Two days later, in the

``Final de Rouen,'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
there was a long article on the show. Homais had composed it with verve the very next morning.

``Why these festoons, these flowers, these garlands? Whither hurries this crowd like the waves of a furious sea under the torrents of a tropical sun pouring its heat upon our heads?'' (he)

Then he (Rodolphe) spoke of the condition of the peasants. Certainly the Government was doing much, but not enough.

``Courage!'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) cried to it;
``a thousand reforms are indispensable; let us accomplish them!'' (he)
Then touching on the entry of the councillor, he (councillor) did not forget
``the martial air of our militia;'' (he)
nor
``our most merry village maidens;'' (he)
nor the
``bald-headed old men like patriarchs who were there, and of whom some, the remnants of our phalanxes, still felt their hearts beat at the manly sound of the drums.'' (he)
He (councillor) cited himself among the first of the members of the jury, and he (councillor) even called attention in a note to the fact that Monsieur Homais, chemist, had sent a memoir on cider to the agricultural society.

When he (chemist) came to the distribution of the prizes, he (chemist) painted the joy of the prize-winners in dithyrambic strophes. ``The father embraced the son, the brother the brother, the husband his (brother) consort. More than one showed his (brother) humble medal with pride; and no doubt when he (brother) got home to his (brother) good housewife, he (brother) hung it up weeping on the modest walls of his (brother) cot.

``About six o’clock a banquet prepared in the meadow of Monsieur Leigeard brought together the principal personages of the fete. The greatest cordiality reigned here. Divers toasts were proposed: Monsieur Lieuvain, the King; Monsieur Tuvache, the Prefect; Monsieur Derozerays, Agriculture; Monsieur Homais, Industry and the Fine Arts, those twin sisters; Monsieur Leplichey, Progress. In the evening some brilliant fireworks on a sudden illumined the air. One would have called it a veritable kaleidoscope, a real operatic scene; and for a moment our little locality might have thought itself transported into the midst of a dream of the `Thousand and One Nights.' Let us state that no untoward event disturbed this family meeting.'' (he)
And he (chemist) added
``Only the absence of the clergy was remarked. No doubt the priests understand progress in another fashion. Just as you please, messieurs the followers of Loyola!'' (he)

Chapter Nine

Six weeks passed. Rodolphe did not come again. At last one evening he (Rodolphe) appeared.

The day after the show he (Rodolphe) had said to himself--

``We mustn't go back too soon; that would be a mistake.'' (he)

And at the end of a week he (Rodolphe) had gone off hunting. After the hunting he (Rodolphe) had thought it was too late, and then he (Rodolphe) reasoned thus--

``If from the first day she (We) loved me, she (We) must from impatience to see me again love me more. Let's go on with it!'' (he)

And he (Rodolphe) knew that his (Rodolphe) calculation had been right when, on entering the room, he (Rodolphe) saw Emma turn pale.

She (Emma) was alone. The day was drawing in. The small muslin curtain along the windows deepened the twilight, and the gilding of the barometer, on which the rays of the sun fell, shone in the looking-glass between the meshes of the coral.

Rodolphe remained standing, and Emma hardly answered his (Rodolphe) first conventional phrases.

``I,'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) said,
``have been busy. I have been ill.'' (he)

``Seriously?'' (she)
she (Emma) cried.

``Well,'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
said Rodolphe, sitting down at her (Emma) side on a footstool,
``no; it was because I did not want to come back.'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)

``Why?'' (unknown)

``Can you not guess?'' (He)

He (Rodolphe) looked at her (Emma) again, but so hard that she (Emma) lowered her (Emma) head, blushing. He (Rodolphe) went on--

``Emma!'' (He)

``Sir,'' (she)
she (Emma) said, drawing back a little.

``Ah! you see,'' (he)
replied he (Rodolphe) in a melancholy voice,
``that I was right not to come back; for this name, this name that fills my whole soul, and that escaped me, you forbid me to use! Madame Bovary! why all the world calls you thus! Besides, it is not your name; it is the name of another!'' (he)

He (Rodolphe) repeated,

``of another!'' (He)
And he (Rodolphe) hid his (Rodolphe) face in his (Rodolphe) hands.

``Yes, I think of you constantly. The memory of you drives me to despair. Ah! forgive me! I will leave you! Farewell! I will go far away, so far that you will never hear of me again; and yet--to-day--I know not what force impelled me towards you. For one does not struggle against Heaven; one cannot resist the smile of angels; one is carried away by that which is beautiful, charming, adorable.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

It was the first time that Emma had heard such words spoken to herself, and her (Emma) pride, like one who reposes bathed in warmth, expanded softly and fully at this glowing language.

``But if I did not come,'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) continued,
``if I could not see you, at least I have gazed long on all that surrounds you. At night-every night-I arose; I came hither; I watched your house, its glimmering in the moon, the trees in the garden swaying before your window, and the little lamp, a gleam shining through the window-panes in the darkness. Ah! you never knew that there, so near you, so far from you, was a poor wretch!'' (he)

She (Emma) turned towards him (Rodolphe) with a sob.

``Oh, you are good!'' (she)
she (Emma) said.

``No, I love you, that is all! You do not doubt that! Tell me--one word--only one word!'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)

And Rodolphe imperceptibly glided from the footstool to the ground; but a sound of wooden shoes was heard in the kitchen, and he (Rodolphe) noticed the door of the room was not closed.

``How kind it would be of you,'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) went on, rising,
``if you would humour a whim of mine.'' (he)
It was to go over her (Emma) house; he (Rodolphe) wanted to know it; and Madame Bovary seeing no objection to this, they both rose, when Charles came in.

``Good morning, doctor,'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
Rodolphe said to him (Rodolphe).

The doctor, flattered at this unexpected title, launched out into obsequious phrases. Of this the other took advantage to pull himself together a little.

``Madame was speaking to me,'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) then said,
``about her (I) health.'' (he)

Charles interrupted him (Charles); he (Charles) had indeed a thousand anxieties; his (Charles) wife's palpitations of the heart were beginning again. Then Rodolphe asked if riding would not be good.

``Certainly! excellent! just the thing! There's an idea! You ought to follow it up.'' (she)

And as she (wife) objected that she (wife) had no horse, Monsieur Rodolphe offered one. She (wife) refused his (Rodolphe) offer; he (Rodolphe) did not insist. Then to explain his (Rodolphe) visit he (Rodolphe) said that his (Rodolphe) ploughman, the man of the blood-letting, still suffered from giddiness.

``I'll call around,'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)
said Bovary.

``No, no! I'll send him (doctor) to you; we'll come; that will be more convenient for you.'' (unknown)

``Ah! very good! I thank you.'' (unknown)

And as soon as they were alone,

``Why don't you accept Monsieur Boulanger's kind offer?'' (She)

She (wife) assumed a sulky air, invented a thousand excuses, and finally declared that perhaps it would look odd.

``Well, what the deuce do I care for that?'' (Charles)
said Charles, making a pirouette.
``Health before everything! You are wrong.'' (unknown)

``And how do you think I can ride when I haven't got a habit?'' (unknown)

``You must order one,'' (he)
he (Charles) answered.

The riding-habit decided her (wife).

When the habit was ready, Charles wrote to Monsieur Boulanger that his (Charles) wife was at his (Charles) command, and that they counted on his (Charles) good-nature.

The next day at noon Rodolphe appeared at Charles's door with two saddle-horses. One had pink rosettes at his (Charles) ears and a deerskin side-saddle.

Rodolphe had put on high soft boots, saying to himself that no doubt she (wife) had never seen anything like them. In fact, Emma was charmed with his (Rodolphe) appearance as he (Rodolphe) stood on the landing in his (Rodolphe) great velvet coat and white corduroy breeches. She (Emma) was ready; she (Emma) was waiting for him (Rodolphe).

Justin escaped from the chemist's to see her (Emma) start, and the chemist also came out. He (chemist) was giving Monsieur Boulanger a little good advice.

``An accident happens so easily. Be careful! Your horses perhaps are mettlesome.'' (She)

She (Emma) heard a noise above her (Emma); it was Felicite drumming on the windowpanes to amuse little Berthe. The child blew her (Emma) a kiss; her (Emma) mother answered with a wave of her (Emma) whip.

``A pleasant ride!'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
cried Monsieur Homais.
``Prudence! above all, prudence!'' (he)
And he (Boulanger) flourished his (Boulanger) newspaper as he (Boulanger) saw them disappear.

As soon as he (Boulanger) felt the ground, Emma's horse set off at a gallop.

Rodolphe galloped by her (Emma) side. Now and then they exchanged a word. Her (Emma) figure slightly bent, her (Emma) hand well up, and her (Emma) right arm stretched out, she (Emma) gave herself up to the cadence of the movement that rocked her (Emma) in her (Emma) saddle. At the bottom of the hill Rodolphe gave his (Rodolphe) horse its head; they started together at a bound, then at the top suddenly the horses stopped, and her (Emma) large blue veil fell about her (Emma).

It was early in October. There was fog over the land. Hazy clouds hovered on the horizon between the outlines of the hills; others, rent asunder, floated up and disappeared. Sometimes through a rift in the clouds, beneath a ray of sunshine, gleamed from afar the roots of Yonville, with the gardens at the water's edge, the yards, the walls and the church steeple. Emma half closed her (Emma) eyes to pick out her (Emma) house, and never had this poor village where she (Emma) lived appeared so small. From the height on which they were the whole valley seemed an immense pale lake sending off its vapour into the air. Clumps of trees here and there stood out like black rocks, and the tall lines of the poplars that rose above the mist were like a beach stirred by the wind.

By the side, on the turf between the pines, a brown light shimmered in the warm atmosphere. The earth, ruddy like the powder of tobacco, deadened the noise of their steps, and with the edge of their shoes the horses as they walked kicked the fallen fir cones in front of them.

Rodolphe and Emma thus went along the skirt of the wood. She (Emma) turned away from time to time to avoid his (Rodolphe) look, and then she (Emma) saw only the pine trunks in lines, whose monotonous succession made her (Emma) a little giddy. The horses were panting; the leather of the saddles creaked.

Just as they were entering the forest the sun shone out.

``God protects us!'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
said Rodolphe.

``Do you think so?'' (she)
she (Emma) said.

``Forward! forward!'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) continued.

He (Rodolphe)

``tchk'd'' (He)
with his (Rodolphe) tongue. The two beasts set off at a trot.

Long ferns by the roadside caught in Emma's stirrup.

Rodolphe leant forward and removed them as they rode along. At other times, to turn aside the branches, he (Rodolphe) passed close to her (Emma), and Emma felt his (Rodolphe) knee brushing against her (Emma) leg. The sky was now blue, the leaves no longer stirred. There were spaces full of heather in flower, and plots of violets alternated with the confused patches of the trees that were grey, fawn, or golden coloured, according to the nature of their leaves. Often in the thicket was heard the fluttering of wings, or else the hoarse, soft cry of the ravens flying off amidst the oaks.

They dismounted. Rodolphe fastened up the horses. She (Emma) walked on in front on the moss between the paths. But her (Emma) long habit got in her (Emma) way, although she (Emma) held it up by the skirt; and Rodolphe, walking behind her (Emma), saw between the black cloth and the black shoe the fineness of her (Emma) white stocking, that seemed to him (Rodolphe) as if it were a part of her (Emma) nakedness.

She (Emma) stopped.

``I am tired,'' (she)
she (Emma) said.

``Come, try again,'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) went on.
``Courage!'' (she)

Then some hundred paces farther on she (Emma) again stopped, and through her (Emma) veil, that fell sideways from her (Emma) man's hat over her (Emma) hips, her (Emma) face appeared in a bluish transparency as if she (Emma) were floating under azure waves.

``But where are we going?'' (He)

He (man) did not answer. She (Emma) was breathing irregularly. Rodolphe looked round him (Rodolphe) biting his (Rodolphe) moustache. They came to a larger space where the coppice had been cut. They sat down on the trunk of a fallen tree, and Rodolphe began speaking to her (Emma) of his (Rodolphe) love. He (Rodolphe) did not begin by frightening her (Emma) with compliments. He (Rodolphe) was calm, serious, melancholy.

Emma listened to him (Rodolphe) with bowed head, and stirred the bits of wood on the ground with the tip of her (Emma) foot. But at the words,

``Are not our destinies now one?'' (unknown)

``Oh, no!'' (she)
she (Emma) replied.
``You know that well. It is impossible!'' (She)
She (Emma) rose to go. He (Rodolphe) seized her (Emma) by the wrist. She (Emma) stopped. Then, having gazed at him (Rodolphe) for a few moments with an amorous and humid look, she (Emma) said hurriedly--

``Ah! do not speak of it again! Where are the horses? Let us go back.'' (she)

He (Rodolphe) made a gesture of anger and annoyance. She (Emma) repeated:

``Where are the horses? Where are the horses?'' (She)

Then smiling a strange smile, his (Rodolphe) pupil fixed, his (Rodolphe) teeth set, he (Rodolphe) advanced with outstretched arms. She (Emma) recoiled trembling. She (Emma) stammered:

``Oh, you frighten me! You hurt me! Let me go!'' (She)

``If it must be,'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) went on, his (Rodolphe) face changing; and he (Rodolphe) again became respectful, caressing, timid. She (Emma) gave him (Rodolphe) her (Emma) arm. They went back. He (Rodolphe) said--

``What was the matter with you? Why? I do not understand. You were mistaken, no doubt. In my soul you are as a Madonna on a pedestal, in a place lofty, secure, immaculate. But I need you to live! I must have your eyes, your voice, your thought! Be my friend, my sister, my angel!'' (He)

And he (Rodolphe) put out his (Rodolphe) arm round her (Emma) waist. She (Emma) feebly tried to disengage herself. He (Rodolphe) supported her (Emma) thus as they walked along.

But they heard the two horses browsing on the leaves.

``Oh! one moment!'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
said Rodolphe.
``Do not let us go! Stay!'' (He)

He (Rodolphe) drew her (Emma) farther on to a small pool where duckweeds made a greenness on the water. Faded water lilies lay motionless between the reeds. At the noise of their steps in the grass, frogs jumped away to hide themselves.

``I am wrong! I am wrong!'' (she)
she (Emma) said.
``I am mad to listen to you!'' (unknown)

``Why? Emma! Emma!'' (unknown)

``Oh, Rodolphe!'' (the woman)
said the young woman slowly, leaning on his (Rodolphe) shoulder.

The cloth of her (Emma) habit caught against the velvet of his (Rodolphe) coat. She (Emma) threw back her (Emma) white neck, swelling with a sigh, and faltering, in tears, with a long shudder and hiding her (Emma) face, she (Emma) gave herself up to him (Rodolphe)--

The shades of night were falling; the horizontal sun passing between the branches dazzled the eyes. Here and there around her (Emma), in the leaves or on the ground, trembled luminous patches, as it hummingbirds flying about had scattered their feathers. Silence was everywhere; something sweet seemed to come forth from the trees; she (Emma) felt her (Emma) heart, whose beating had begun again, and the blood coursing through her (Emma) flesh like a stream of milk. Then far away, beyond the wood, on the other hills, she (Emma) heard a vague prolonged cry, a voice which lingered, and in silence she (Emma) heard it mingling like music with the last pulsations of her (Emma) throbbing nerves. Rodolphe, a cigar between his (Rodolphe) lips, was mending with his (Rodolphe) penknife one of the two broken bridles.

They returned to Yonville by the same road. On the mud they saw again the traces of their horses side by side, the same thickets, the same stones to the grass; nothing around them seemed changed; and yet for her (Emma) something had happened more stupendous than if the mountains had moved in their places. Rodolphe now and again bent forward and took her (Emma) hand to kiss it.

She (Emma) was charming on horseback--upright, with her (Emma) slender waist, her (Emma) knee bent on the mane of her (Emma) horse, her (Emma) face somewhat flushed by the fresh air in the red of the evening.

On entering Yonville she (Emma) made her (Emma) horse prance in the road. People looked at her (Emma) from the windows.

At dinner her (Emma) husband thought she (Emma) looked well, but she (Emma) pretended not to hear him (husband) when he (husband) inquired about her (Emma) ride, and she (Emma) remained sitting there with her (Emma) elbow at the side of her (Emma) plate between the two lighted candles.

``Emma!'' (he)
he (husband) said.

``What?'' (unknown)

``Well, I spent the afternoon at Monsieur Alexandre's. He (Alexandre) has an old cob, still very fine, only a little broken-kneed, and that could be bought; I am sure, for a hundred crowns.'' (He)
He (husband) added,
``And thinking it might please you, I have bespoken it--bought it. Have I done right? Do tell me?'' (He)

She (Emma) nodded her (Emma) head in assent; then a quarter of an hour later--

``Are you going out to-night?'' (She)
she (Emma) asked.

``Yes. Why?'' (unknown)

``Oh, nothing, nothing, my dear!'' (she)

And as soon as she (Emma) had got rid of Charles she (Emma) went and shut herself up in her (Emma) room.

At first she (Emma) felt stunned; she (Emma) saw the trees, the paths, the ditches, Rodolphe, and she (Emma) again felt the pressure of his (Rodolphe) arm, while the leaves rustled and the reeds whistled.

But when she (Emma) saw herself in the glass she (Emma) wondered at her (Emma) face. Never had her (Emma) eyes been so large, so black, of so profound a depth. Something subtle about her (Emma) being transfigured her (Emma). She (Emma) repeated,

``I have a lover! a lover!'' (She)
delighting at the idea as if a second puberty had come to her (Emma). So at last she (Emma) was to know those joys of love, that fever of happiness of which she (Emma) had despaired! She (Emma) was entering upon marvels where all would be passion, ecstasy, delirium. An azure infinity encompassed her (Emma), the heights of sentiment sparkled under her (Emma) thought, and ordinary existence appeared only afar off, down below in the shade, through the interspaces of these heights.

Then she (Emma) recalled the heroines of the books that she (Emma) had read, and the lyric legion of these adulterous women began to sing in her (Emma) memory with the voice of sisters that charmed her (Emma). She (Emma) became herself, as it were, an actual part of these imaginings, and realised the love-dream of her (Emma) youth as she (Emma) saw herself in this type of amorous women whom she (Emma) had so envied. Besides, Emma felt a satisfaction of revenge. Had she (Emma) not suffered enough? But now she (Emma) triumphed, and the love so long pent up burst forth in full joyous bubblings. She (Emma) tasted it without remorse, without anxiety, without trouble.

The day following passed with a new sweetness. They made vows to one another She (Emma) told him (Emma) of her (Emma) sorrows. Rodolphe interrupted her (Emma) with kisses; and she (Emma) looking at him (Rodolphe) through half-closed eyes, asked him (Rodolphe) to call her (Emma) again by her (Emma) name--to say that he (Rodolphe) loved her (Emma) They were in the forest, as yesterday, in the shed of some woodenshoe maker. The walls were of straw, and the roof so low they had to stoop. They were seated side by side on a bed of dry leaves.

From that day forth they wrote to one another regularly every evening. Emma placed her (Emma) letter at the end of the garden, by the river, in a fissure of the wall. Rodolphe came to fetch it, and put another there, that she (Emma) always found fault with as too short.

One morning, when Charles had gone out before day break, she (Emma) was seized with the fancy to see Rodolphe at once. She (Emma) would go quickly to La Huchette, stay there an hour, and be back again at Yonville while everyone was still asleep. This idea made her (Emma) pant with desire, and she (Emma) soon found herself in the middle of the field, walking with rapid steps, without looking behind her (Emma).

Day was just breaking. Emma from afar recognised her (Emma) lover's house. Its two dove-tailed weathercocks stood out black against the pale dawn.

Beyond the farmyard there was a detached building that she (Emma) thought must be the chateau She (Emma) entered--it was if the doors at her (Emma) approach had opened wide of their own accord. A large straight staircase led up to the corridor. Emma raised the latch of a door, and suddenly at the end of the room she (Emma) saw a man sleeping. It was Rodolphe. She (Emma) uttered a cry.

``You here? You here?'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) repeated.
``How did you manage to come? Ah! your dress is damp.'' (unknown)

``I love you,'' (she)
she (Emma) answered, throwing her (Emma) arms about his (Rodolphe) neck.

This first piece of daring successful, now every time Charles went out early Emma dressed quickly and slipped on tiptoe down the steps that led to the waterside.

But when the plank for the cows was taken up, she (Emma) had to go by the walls alongside of the river; the bank was slippery; in order not to fall she (Emma) caught hold of the tufts of faded wallflowers. Then she (Emma) went across ploughed fields, in which she (Emma) sank, stumbling; and clogging her (Emma) thin shoes. Her (Emma) scarf, knotted round her (Emma) head, fluttered to the wind in the meadows. She (Emma) was afraid of the oxen; she (Emma) began to run; she (Emma) arrived out of breath, with rosy cheeks, and breathing out from her (Emma) whole person a fresh perfume of sap, of verdure, of the open air. At this hour Rodolphe still slept. It was like a spring morning coming into his (Rodolphe) room.

The yellow curtains along the windows let a heavy, whitish light enter softly. Emma felt about, opening and closing her (Emma) eyes, while the drops of dew hanging from her (Emma) hair formed, as it were, a topaz aureole around her (Emma) face. Rodolphe, laughing, drew her (Emma) to him (Rodolphe), and pressed her (Emma) to his (Rodolphe) breast.

Then she (Emma) examined the apartment, opened the drawers of the tables, combed her (Emma) hair with his (Rodolphe) comb, and looked at herself in his (Rodolphe) shaving-glass. Often she (Emma) even put between her (Emma) teeth the big pipe that lay on the table by the bed, amongst lemons and pieces of sugar near a bottle of water.

It took them a good quarter of an hour to say goodbye. Then Emma cried. She (Emma) would have wished never to leave Rodolphe. Something stronger than herself forced her (Emma) to him (Rodolphe); so much so, that one day, seeing her (Emma) come unexpectedly, he (Rodolphe) frowned as one put out.

``What is the matter with you?'' (she)
she (Emma) said.
``Are you ill? Tell me!'' (he)

At last he (Rodolphe) declared with a serious air that her (Emma) visits were becoming imprudent--that she (Emma) was compromising herself.

Chapter Ten

Gradually Rodolphe's fears took possession of her (Emma). At first, love had intoxicated her (Emma); and she (Emma) had thought of nothing beyond. But now that he (Rodolphe) was indispensable to her (Emma) life, she (Emma) feared to lose anything of this, or even that it should be disturbed. When she (Emma) came back from his (Rodolphe) house she (Emma) looked all about her (Emma), anxiously watching every form that passed in the horizon, and every village window from which she (Emma) could be seen. She (Emma) listened for steps, cries, the noise of the ploughs, and she (Emma) stopped short, white, and trembling more than the aspen leaves swaying overhead.

One morning as she (Emma) was thus returning, she (Emma) suddenly thought she (Emma) saw the long barrel of a carbine that seemed to be aimed at her (Emma). It stuck out sideways from the end of a small tub half-buried in the grass on the edge of a ditch. Emma, half-fainting with terror, nevertheless walked on, and a man stepped out of the tub like a Jack-in-the-box. He (man) had gaiters buckled up to the knees, his (man) cap pulled down over his (man) eyes, trembling lips, and a red nose. It was Captain Binet lying in ambush for wild ducks.

``You ought to have called out long ago!'' (he)
he (Captain) exclaimed;
``When one sees a gun, one should always give warning.'' (he)

The tax-collector was thus trying to hide the fright he (Captain) had had, for a prefectorial order having prohibited duckhunting except in boats, Monsieur Binet, despite his (Captain) respect for the laws, was infringing them, and so he (Captain) every moment expected to see the rural guard turn up. But this anxiety whetted his (guard) pleasure, and, all alone in his (guard) tub, he (guard) congratulated himself on his (guard) luck and on his (guard) cuteness. At sight of Emma he (guard) seemed relieved from a great weight, and at once entered upon a conversation.

``It isn't warm; it's nipping.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

Emma answered nothing. He (guard) went on--

``And you're out so early?'' (He)

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Emma) said stammering;
``I am just coming from the nurse where my child is.'' (she)

``Ah! very good! very good! For myself, I am here, just as you see me, since break of day; but the weather is so muggy, that unless one had the bird at the mouth of the gun--'' (she)

``Good evening, Monsieur Binet,'' (she)
she (Emma) interrupted him (guard), turning on her (Emma) heel.

``Your servant, madame,'' (he)
he (guard) replied drily; and he (guard) went back into his (guard) tub.

Emma regretted having left the tax-collector so abruptly. No doubt he (guard) would form unfavourable conjectures. The story about the nurse was the worst possible excuse, everyone at Yonville knowing that the little Bovary had been at home with her (nurse) parents for a year. Besides, no one was living in this direction; this path led only to La Huchette. Binet, then, would guess whence she (nurse) came, and he (guard) would not keep silence; he (guard) would talk, that was certain. She (nurse) remained until evening racking her (nurse) brain with every conceivable lying project, and had constantly before her (nurse) eyes that imbecile with the game-bag.

Charles after dinner, seeing her (nurse) gloomy, proposed, by way of distraction, to take her (nurse) to the chemist's, and the first person she (nurse) caught sight of in the shop was the taxcollector again. He (chemist) was standing in front of the counter, lit up by the gleams of the red bottle, and was saying--

``Please give me half an ounce of vitriol.'' (He)

``Justin,'' (the druggist)
cried the druggist,
``bring us the sulphuric acid.'' (the druggist)
Then to Emma, who was going up to Madame Homais' room,
``No, stay here; it isn't worth while going up; she (me) is just coming down. Warm yourself at the stove in the meantime. Excuse me. Good-day, doctor,'' (Madame Homais)
-LRB-for the chemist much enjoyed pronouncing the word
``doctor,'' (the chemist)
as if addressing another by it reflected on himself some of the grandeur that he (chemist) found in it-RRB-.
``Now, take care not to upset the mortars! You'd better fetch some chairs from the little room; you know very well that the arm-chairs are not to be taken out of the drawing-room.'' (he)

And to put his (chemist) arm-chair back in its place he (chemist) was darting away from the counter, when Binet asked him (chemist) for half an ounce of sugar acid.

``Sugar acid!'' (the chemist)
said the chemist contemptuously,
``don't know it; I'm ignorant of it! But perhaps you want oxalic acid. It is oxalic acid, isn't it?'' (the chemist)

Binet explained that he (chemist) wanted a corrosive to make himself some copperwater with which to remove rust from his (chemist) hunting things.

Emma shuddered. The chemist began saying--

``Indeed the weather is not propitious on account of the damp.'' (The chemist)

``Nevertheless,'' (the tax-collector)
replied the tax-collector, with a sly look,
``there are people who like it.'' (the tax-collector)

She (Emma) was stifling.

``And give me--'' (unknown)

``Will he (Sugar) never go?'' (she)
thought she (Emma).

``Half an ounce of resin and turpentine, four ounces of yellow wax, and three half ounces of animal charcoal, if you please, to clean the varnished leather of my togs.'' (The druggist)

The druggist was beginning to cut the wax when Madame Homais appeared, Irma in her (Irma) arms, Napoleon by her (Irma) side, and Athalie following. She (Irma) sat down on the velvet seat by the window, and the lad squatted down on a footstool, while his (lad) eldest sister hovered round the jujube box near her (sister) papa. The latter was filling funnels and corking phials, sticking on labels, making up parcels. Around him (lad) all were silent; only from time to time, were heard the weights jingling in the balance, and a few low words from the chemist giving directions to his (chemist) pupil.

``And how's the little woman?'' (Madame Homais)
suddenly asked Madame Homais.

``Silence!'' (husband)
exclaimed her (sister) husband, who was writing down some figures in his (chemist) waste-book.

``Why didn't you bring her (woman)?'' (she)
she (sister) went on in a low voice.

``Hush! hush!'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma, pointing with her (Emma) finger to the druggist.

But Binet, quite absorbed in looking over his (chemist) bill, had probably heard nothing. At last he (chemist) went out. Then Emma, relieved, uttered a deep sigh.

``How hard you are breathing!'' (Madame Homais)
said Madame Homais.

``Well, you see, it's rather warm,'' (she)
she (Emma) replied.

So the next day they talked over how to arrange their rendezvous. Emma wanted to bribe her (Emma) servant with a present, but it would be better to find some safe house at Yonville. Rodolphe promised to look for one.

All through the winter, three or four times a week, in the dead of night he (Rodolphe) came to the garden. Emma had on purpose taken away the key of the gate, which Charles thought lost.

To call her (Emma), Rodolphe threw a sprinkle of sand at the shutters. She (Emma) jumped up with a start; but sometimes he (Rodolphe) had to wait, for Charles had a mania for chatting by the fireside, and he (Charles) would not stop. She (Emma) was wild with impatience; if her (Emma) eyes could have done it, she (Emma) would have hurled him (Charles) out at the window. At last she (Emma) would begin to undress, then take up a book, and go on reading very quietly as if the book amused her (Emma). But Charles, who was in bed, called to her (Emma) to come too.

``Come, now, Emma,'' (he)
he (Charles) said,
``it is time.'' (he)

``Yes, I am coming,'' (she)
she (Emma) answered.

Then, as the candles dazzled him (Charles); he (Charles) turned to the wall and fell asleep. She (Emma) escaped, smiling, palpitating, undressed. Rodolphe had a large cloak; he (Rodolphe) wrapped her (Emma) in it, and putting his (Rodolphe) arm round her (Emma) waist, he (Rodolphe) drew her (Emma) without a word to the end of the garden.

It was in the arbour, on the same seat of old sticks where formerly Leon had looked at her (Emma) so amorously on the summer evenings. She (Emma) never thought of him (Leon) now.

The stars shone through the leafless jasmine branches. Behind them they heard the river flowing, and now and again on the bank the rustling of the dry reeds. Masses of shadow here and there loomed out in the darkness, and sometimes, vibrating with one movement, they rose up and swayed like immense black waves pressing forward to engulf them. The cold of the nights made them clasp closer; the sighs of their lips seemed to them deeper; their eyes that they could hardly see, larger; and in the midst of the silence low words were spoken that fell on their souls sonorous, crystalline, and that reverberated in multiplied vibrations.

When the night was rainy, they took refuge in the consulting-room between the cart-shed and the stable. She (their) lighted one of the kitchen candles that she (their) had hidden behind the books. Rodolphe settled down there as if at home. The sight of the library, of the bureau, of the whole apartment, in fine, excited his (Rodolphe) merriment, and he (Rodolphe) could not refrain from making jokes about Charles, which rather embarrassed Emma. She (Emma) would have liked to see him (Charles) more serious, and even on occasions more dramatic; as, for example, when she (Emma) thought she (Emma) heard a noise of approaching steps in the alley.

``Someone is coming!'' (she)
she (Emma) said.

He (Charles) blew out the light.

``Have you your pistols?'' (unknown)

``Why?'' (unknown)

``Why, to defend yourself,'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
replied Emma.

``From your husband? Oh, poor devil!'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)
And Rodolphe finished his (Rodolphe) sentence with a gesture that said,
``I could crush him (devil) with a flip of my finger.'' (Rodolphe/Monsieur Boulanger/Monsieur Rodolphe)

She (Emma) was wonder-stricken at his (Rodolphe) bravery, although she (Emma) felt in it a sort of indecency and a naive coarseness that scandalised her (Emma).

Rodolphe reflected a good deal on the affair of the pistols. If she (Emma) had spoken seriously, it was very ridiculous, he (Rodolphe) thought, even odious; for he (Rodolphe) had no reason to hate the good Charles, not being what is called devoured by jealousy; and on this subject Emma had taken a great vow that he (Charles) did not think in the best of taste.

Besides, she (Emma) was growing very sentimental. She (Emma) had insisted on exchanging miniatures; they had cut off handfuls of hair, and now she (Emma) was asking for a ring--a real wedding-ring, in sign of an eternal union. She (Emma) often spoke to him (Charles) of the evening chimes, of the voices of nature. Then she (Emma) talked to him (Charles) of her (Emma) mother--hers! and of his (Charles) mother--his (Charles)! Rodolphe had lost his (Rodolphe) twenty years ago. Emma none the less consoled him (Rodolphe) with caressing words as one would have done a lost child, and she (Emma) sometimes even said to him (Rodolphe), gazing at the moon--

``I am sure that above there together they approve of our love.'' (him)

But she (Emma) was so pretty. He (Rodolphe) had possessed so few women of such ingenuousness. This love without debauchery was a new experience for him (Rodolphe), and, drawing him (Rodolphe) out of his (Rodolphe) lazy habits, caressed at once his (Rodolphe) pride and his (Rodolphe) sensuality. Emma's enthusiasm, which his (Rodolphe) bourgeois good sense disdained, seemed to him (Rodolphe) in his (Rodolphe) heart of hearts charming, since it was lavished on him (Rodolphe). Then, sure of being loved, he (Rodolphe) no longer kept up appearances, and insensibly his (Rodolphe) ways changed.

He (Rodolphe) had no longer, as formerly, words so gentle that they made her (Emma) cry, nor passionate caresses that made her (Emma) mad, so that their great love, which engrossed her (Emma) life, seemed to lessen beneath her (Emma) like the water of a stream absorbed into its channel, and she (Emma) could see the bed of it. She (Emma) would not believe it; she (Emma) redoubled in tenderness, and Rodolphe concealed his (Rodolphe) indifference less and less.

She (Emma) did not know if she (Emma) regretted having yielded to him (Rodolphe), or whether she (Emma) did not wish, on the contrary, to enjoy him (Rodolphe) the more. The humiliation of feeling herself weak was turning to rancour, tempered by their voluptuous pleasures. It was not affection; it was like a continual seduction. He (Rodolphe) subjugated her (Emma); she (Emma) almost feared him (Rodolphe).

Appearances, nevertheless, were calmer than ever, Rodolphe having succeeded in carrying out the adultery after his (Rodolphe) own fancy; and at the end of six months, when the spring-time came, they were to one another like a married couple, tranquilly keeping up a domestic flame.

It was the time of year when old Rouault sent his (Rouault) turkey in remembrance of the setting of his (Rouault) leg. The present always arrived with a letter. Emma cut the string that tied it to the basket, and read the following lines:--

``My Dear Children--I hope this will find you well, and that this one will be as good as the others. For it seems to me a little more tender, if I may venture to say so, and heavier. But next time, for a change, I'll give you a turkeycock, unless you have a preference for some dabs; and send me back the hamper, if you please, with the two old ones. I have had an accident with my cart-sheds, whose covering flew off one windy night among the trees. The harvest has not been overgood either. Finally, I don't know when I shall come to see you. It is so difficult now to leave the house since I am alone, my poor Emma.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

Here there was a break in the lines, as if the old fellow had dropped his (fellow) pen to dream a little while.

``For myself, I am very well, except for a cold I caught the other day at the fair at Yvetot, where I had gone to hire a shepherd, having turned away mine because he (shepherd) was too dainty. How we are to be pitied with such a lot of thieves! Besides, he (shepherd) was also rude. I heard from a pedlar, who, travelling through your part of the country this winter, had a tooth drawn, that Bovary was as usual working hard. That doesn't surprise me; and he (shepherd) showed me his (shepherd) tooth; we had some coffee together. I asked him (shepherd) if he (shepherd) had seen you, and he (shepherd) said not, but that he (shepherd) had seen two horses in the stables, from which I conclude that business is looking up. So much the better, my dear children, and may God send you every imaginable happiness! It grieves me not yet to have seen my dear little grand-daughter, Berthe Bovary. I have planted an Orleans plum-tree for her (grand-daughter) in the garden under your room, and I won't have it touched unless it is to have jam made for her (grand-daughter) by and bye, that I will keep in the cupboard for her (grand-daughter) when she (grand-daughter) comes.

``Good-bye, my dear children. I kiss you, my girl, you too, my son-in-law, and the little one on both cheeks. I am, with best compliments, your loving father.

``Theodore Rouault.'' (She)

She (Emma) held the coarse paper in her (Emma) fingers for some minutes. The spelling mistakes were interwoven one with the other, and Emma followed the kindly thought that cackled right through it like a hen half hidden in the hedge of thorns. The writing had been dried with ashes from the hearth, for a little grey powder slipped from the letter on to her (Emma) dress, and she (Emma) almost thought she (Emma) saw her (Emma) father bending over the hearth to take up the tongs. How long since she (Emma) had been with him (father), sitting on the footstool in the chimney-corner, where she (Emma) used to burn the end of a bit of wood in the great flame of the sea-sedges! She (Emma) remembered the summer evenings all full of sunshine. The colts neighed when anyone passed by, and galloped, galloped. Under her (Emma) window there was a beehive, and sometimes the bees wheeling round in the light struck against her (Emma) window like rebounding balls of gold. What happiness there had been at that time, what freedom, what hope! What an abundance of illusions! Nothing was left of them now. She (Emma) had got rid of them all in her (Emma) soul's life, in all her (Emma) successive conditions of life, maidenhood, her (Emma) marriage, and her (Emma) love--thus constantly losing them all her (Emma) life through, like a traveller who leaves something of his (traveller) wealth at every inn along his (traveller) road.

But what then, made her (Emma) so unhappy? What was the extraordinary catastrophe that had transformed her (Emma)? And she (Emma) raised her (Emma) head, looking round as if to seek the cause of that which made her (Emma) suffer.

An April ray was dancing on the china of the whatnot; the fire burned; beneath her (Emma) slippers she (Emma) felt the softness of the carpet; the day was bright, the air warm, and she (Emma) heard her (Emma) child shouting with laughter.

In fact, the little girl was just then rolling on the lawn in the midst of the grass that was being turned. She (girl) was lying flat on her (girl) stomach at the top of a rick. The servant was holding her (girl) by her (girl) skirt. Lestiboudois was raking by her (girl) side, and every time he (servant) came near she (girl) lent forward, beating the air with both her (girl) arms.

``Bring her (girl) to me,'' (mother)
said her (girl) mother, rushing to embrace her (girl).
``How I love you, my poor child! How I love you!'' (she)

Then noticing that the tips of her (girl) ears were rather dirty, she (girl) rang at once for warm water, and washed her (girl), changed her (girl) linen, her (girl) stockings, her (girl) shoes, asked a thousand questions about her (girl) health, as if on the return from a long journey, and finally, kissing her (girl) again and crying a little, she (girl) gave her (girl) back to the servant, who stood quite thunderstricken at this excess of tenderness.

That evening Rodolphe found her (girl) more serious than usual.

``That will pass over,'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) concluded;
``it's a whim:'' (he)

And he (Rodolphe) missed three rendezvous running. When he (Rodolphe) did come, she (girl) showed herself cold and almost contemptuous.

``Ah! you're losing your time, my lady!'' (he)

And he (Rodolphe) pretended not to notice her (girl) melancholy sighs, nor the handkerchief she (girl) took out.

Then Emma repented. She (Emma) even asked herself why she (Emma) detested Charles; if it had not been better to have been able to love him (Charles)? But he (Charles) gave her (Emma) no opportunities for such a revival of sentiment, so that she (Emma) was much embarrassed by her (Emma) desire for sacrifice, when the druggist came just in time to provide her (Emma) with an opportunity.

Chapter Eleven

He (Charles) had recently read a eulogy on a new method for curing club-foot, and as he (Charles) was a partisan of progress, he (Charles) conceived the patriotic idea that Yonville, in order to keep to the fore, ought to have some operations for strephopody or club-foot.

``For,'' (he)
said he (Charles) to Emma,
``what risk is there? See--'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
-LRB-and he (Charles) enumerated on his (Charles) fingers the advantages of the attempt-RRB-,
``success, almost certain relief and beautifying of the patient, celebrity acquired by the operator. Why, for example, should not your husband relieve poor Hippolyte of the `Lion d’Or'? Note that he (husband) would not fail to tell about his (husband) cure to all the travellers, and then'' (he)
-LRB-Homais lowered his (Charles) voice and looked round him (Charles)-RRB-
``who is to prevent me from sending a short paragraph on the subject to the paper? Eh! goodness me! an article gets about; it is talked of; it ends by making a snowball! And who knows? who knows?'' (him)

In fact, Bovary might succeed. Nothing proved to Emma that he (Charles) was not clever; and what a satisfaction for her (Emma) to have urged him (Charles) to a step by which his (Charles) reputation and fortune would be increased! She (Emma) only wished to lean on something more solid than love.

Charles, urged by the druggist and by her (Emma), allowed himself to be persuaded. He (Charles) sent to Rouen for Dr. Duval's volume, and every evening, holding his (Charles) head between both hands, plunged into the reading of it.

While he (Charles) was studying equinus, varus, and valgus, that is to say, katastrephopody, endostrephopody, and exostrephopody -LRB-or better, the various turnings of the foot downwards, inwards, and outwards, with the hypostrephopody and anastrephopody-RRB-, otherwise torsion downwards and upwards, Monsier Homais, with all sorts of arguments, was exhorting the lad at the inn to submit to the operation.

``You will scarcely feel, probably, a slight pain; it is a simple prick, like a little blood-letting, less than the extraction of certain corns.'' (Hippolyte)

Hippolyte, reflecting, rolled his (lad) stupid eyes.

``However,'' (the chemist)
continued the chemist,
``it doesn't concern me. It's for your sake, for pure humanity! I should like to see you, my friend, rid of your hideous caudication, together with that waddling of the lumbar regions which, whatever you say, must considerably interfere with you in the exercise of your calling.'' (the chemist)

Then Homais represented to him (lad) how much jollier and brisker he (lad) would feel afterwards, and even gave him (lad) to understand that he (lad) would be more likely to please the women; and the stable-boy began to smile heavily. Then he (lad) attacked him (lad) through his (lad) vanity:

``Aren't you a man? Hang it! what would you have done if you had had to go into the army, to go and fight beneath the standard? Ah! Hippolyte!'' (him)

And Homais retired, declaring that he (lad) could not understand this obstinacy, this blindness in refusing the benefactions of science.

The poor fellow gave way, for it was like a conspiracy. Binet, who never interfered with other people's business, Madame Lefrancois, Artemise, the neighbours, even the mayor, Monsieur Tuvache--everyone persuaded him (mayor), lectured him (mayor), shamed him (mayor); but what finally decided him (mayor) was that it would cost him (mayor) nothing. Bovary even undertook to provide the machine for the operation. This generosity was an idea of Emma's, and Charles consented to it, thinking in his (Charles) heart of hearts that his (Charles) wife was an angel.

So by the advice of the chemist, and after three fresh starts, he (Charles) had a kind of box made by the carpenter, with the aid of the locksmith, that weighed about eight pounds, and in which iron, wood, sheer-iron, leather, screws, and nuts had not been spared.

But to know which of Hippolyte's tendons to cut, it was necessary first of all to find out what kind of club-foot he (locksmith) had.

He (locksmith) had a foot forming almost a straight line with the leg, which, however, did not prevent it from being turned in, so that it was an equinus together with something of a varus, or else a slight varus with a strong tendency to equinus. But with this equinus, wide in foot like a horse's hoof, with rugose skin, dry tendons, and large toes, on which the black nails looked as if made of iron, the clubfoot ran about like a deer from morn till night. He (locksmith) was constantly to be seen on the Place, jumping round the carts, thrusting his (locksmith) limping foot forwards. He (locksmith) seemed even stronger on that leg than the other. By dint of hard service it had acquired, as it were, moral qualities of patience and energy; and when he (locksmith) was given some heavy work, he (locksmith) stood on it in preference to its fellow.

Now, as it was an equinus, it was necessary to cut the tendon of Achilles, and, if need were, the anterior tibial muscle could be seen to afterwards for getting rid of the varus; for the doctor did not dare to risk both operations at once; he (doctor) was even trembling already for fear of injuring some important region that he (doctor) did not know.

Neither Ambrose Pare, applying for the first time since Celsus, after an interval of fifteen centuries, a ligature to an artery, nor Dupuytren, about to open an abscess in the brain, nor Gensoul when he (Ambrose) first took away the superior maxilla, had hearts that trembled, hands that shook, minds so strained as Monsieur Bovary when he (Ambrose) approached Hippolyte, his (Ambrose) tenotome between his (Ambrose) fingers. And as at hospitals, near by on a table lay a heap of lint, with waxed thread, many bandages--a pyramid of bandages--every bandage to be found at the druggist's. It was Monsieur Homais who since morning had been organising all these preparations, as much to dazzle the multitude as to keep up his (Ambrose) illusions. Charles pierced the skin; a dry crackling was heard. The tendon was cut, the operation over. Hippolyte could not get over his (Charles) surprise, but bent over Bovary's hands to cover them with kisses.

``Come, be calm,'' (the druggist)
said the druggist;
``later on you will show your gratitude to your benefactor.'' (the druggist)

And he (Charles) went down to tell the result to five or six inquirers who were waiting in the yard, and who fancied that Hippolyte would reappear walking properly. Then Charles, having buckled his (Charles) patient into the machine, went home, where Emma, all anxiety, awaited him (Charles) at the door. She (Emma) threw herself on his (Charles) neck; they sat down to table; he (Charles) ate much, and at dessert he (Charles) even wanted to take a cup of coffee, a luxury he (Charles) only permitted himself on Sundays when there was company.

The evening was charming, full of prattle, of dreams together. They talked about their future fortune, of the improvements to be made in their house; he (Charles) saw people's estimation of him (Charles) growing, his (Charles) comforts increasing, his (Charles) wife always loving him (Charles); and she (wife) was happy to refresh herself with a new sentiment, healthier, better, to feel at last some tenderness for this poor fellow who adored her (wife). The thought of Rodolphe for one moment passed through her (wife) mind, but her (wife) eyes turned again to Charles; she (wife) even noticed with surprise that he (Charles) had not bad teeth.

They were in bed when Monsieur Homais, in spite of the servant, suddenly entered the room, holding in his (servant) hand a sheet of paper just written. It was the paragraph he (servant) intended for the

``Fanal de Rouen.'' (he)
He (servant) brought it for them to read.

``Read it yourself,'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)
said Bovary.

He (servant) read--

```Despite the prejudices that still invest a part of the face of Europe like a net, the light nevertheless begins to penetrate our country places. Thus on Tuesday our little town of Yonville found itself the scene of a surgical operation which is at the same time an act of loftiest philanthropy. Monsieur Bovary, one of our most distinguished practitioners--'''

``Oh, that is too much! too much!'' (practitioners)
said Charles, choking with emotion.

``No, no! not at all! What next!'' (a man)

```--Performed an operation on a club-footed man.' I have not used the scientific term, because you know in a newspaper everyone would not perhaps understand. The masses must--'''

``No doubt,'' (The masses)
said Bovary;
``go on!'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)

``I proceed,'' (the chemist)
said the chemist. ```Monsieur Bovary, one of our most distinguished practitioners, performed an operation on a club-footed man called Hippolyte Tautain, stableman for the last twenty-five years at the hotel of the
``Lion d’Or,'' (stableman)
kept by Widow Lefrancois, at the Place d’Armes. The novelty of the attempt, and the interest incident to the subject, had attracted such a concourse of persons that there was a veritable obstruction on the threshold of the establishment. The operation, moreover, was performed as if by magic, and barely a few drops of blood appeared on the skin, as though to say that the rebellious tendon had at last given way beneath the efforts of art. The patient, strangely enough--we affirm it as an eye-witness--complained of no pain. His (eye-witness) condition up to the present time leaves nothing to be desired. Everything tends to show that his (eye-witness) convelescence will be brief; and who knows even if at our next village festivity we shall not see our good Hippolyte figuring in the bacchic dance in the midst of a chorus of joyous boon-companions, and thus proving to all eyes by his (eye-witness) verve and his (eye-witness) capers his (eye-witness) complete cure? Honour, then, to the generous savants! Honour to those indefatigable spirits who consecrate their vigils to the amelioration or to the alleviation of their kind! Honour, thrice honour! Is it not time to cry that the blind shall see, the deaf hear, the lame walk? But that which fanaticism formerly promised to its elect, science now accomplishes for all men. We shall keep our readers informed as to the successive phases of this remarkable cure.'''

This did not prevent Mere Lefrancois, from coming five days after, scared, and crying out--

``Help! he (benefactor) is dying! I am going crazy!'' (Mere Lefrancois)

Charles rushed to the

``Lion d’Or,'' (Charles)
and the chemist, who caught sight of him (Charles) passing along the Place hatless, abandoned his (Charles) shop. He (Charles) appeared himself breathless, red, anxious, and asking everyone who was going up the stairs--

``Why, what's the matter with our interesting strephopode?'' (everyone)

The strephopode was writhing in hideous convulsions, so that the machine in which his (Charles) leg was enclosed was knocked against the wall enough to break it.

With many precautions, in order not to disturb the position of the limb, the box was removed, and an awful sight presented itself. The outlines of the foot disappeared in such a swelling that the entire skin seemed about to burst, and it was covered with ecchymosis, caused by the famous machine. Hippolyte had already complained of suffering from it. No attention had been paid to him (Charles); they had to acknowledge that he (Charles) had not been altogether wrong, and he (Charles) was freed for a few hours. But, hardly had the oedema gone down to some extent, than the two savants thought fit to put back the limb in the apparatus, strapping it tighter to hasten matters. At last, three days after, Hippolyte being unable to endure it any longer, they once more removed the machine, and were much surprised at the result they saw. The livid tumefaction spread over the leg, with blisters here and there, whence there oozed a black liquid. Matters were taking a serious turn. Hippolyte began to worry himself, and Mere Lefrancois, had him (Lefrancois) installed in the little room near the kitchen, so that he (Lefrancois) might at least have some distraction.

But the tax-collector, who dined there every day, complained bitterly of such companionship. Then Hippolyte was removed to the billiard-room. He (Lefrancois) lay there moaning under his (Lefrancois) heavy coverings, pale with long beard, sunken eyes, and from time to time turning his (Lefrancois) perspiring head on the dirty pillow, where the flies alighted. Madame Bovary went to see him (Lefrancois). She (Lefrancois) brought him (Lefrancois) linen for his (Lefrancois) poultices; she (Lefrancois) comforted, and encouraged him (Lefrancois). Besides, he (Lefrancois) did not want for company, especially on market-days, when the peasants were knocking about the billiard-balls round him (Lefrancois), fenced with the cues, smoked, drank, sang, and brawled.

``How are you?'' (him)
they said, clapping him (Lefrancois) on the shoulder.
``Ah! you're not up to much, it seems, but it's your own fault. You should do this! do that!'' (him)
And then they told him (Lefrancois) stories of people who had all been cured by other remedies than his (Lefrancois). Then by way of consolation they added--

``You give way too much! Get up! You coddle yourself like a king! All the same, old chap, you don't smell nice!'' (unknown)

Gangrene, in fact, was spreading more and more. Bovary himself turned sick at it. He (Lefrancois) came every hour, every moment. Hippolyte looked at him (Lefrancois) with eyes full of terror, sobbing--

``When shall I get well? Oh, save me! How unfortunate I am! How unfortunate I am!'' (him)

And the doctor left, always recommending him (doctor) to diet himself.

``Don't listen to him (chap), my lad,'' (Mere Lefrancois)
said Mere Lefrancois,
``Haven't they tortured you enough already? You'll grow still weaker. Here! swallow this.'' (Mere Lefrancois)

And she (it) gave him (Lefrancois) some good beef-tea, a slice of mutton, a piece of bacon, and sometimes small glasses of brandy, that he (Lefrancois) had not the strength to put to his (Lefrancois) lips.

Abbe Bournisien, hearing that he (Lefrancois) was growing worse, asked to see him (Lefrancois). He (Lefrancois) began by pitying his (Lefrancois) sufferings, declaring at the same time that he (Lefrancois) ought to rejoice at them since it was the will of the Lord, and take advantage of the occasion to reconcile himself to Heaven.

``For,'' (unknown)
said the ecclesiastic in a paternal tone,
``you rather neglected your duties; you were rarely seen at divine worship. How many years is it since you approached the holy table? I understand that your work, that the whirl of the world may have kept you from care for your salvation. But now is the time to reflect. Yet don't despair. I have known great sinners, who, about to appear before God -LRB-you are not yet at this point I know-RRB-, had implored His (God) mercy, and who certainly died in the best frame of mind. Let us hope that, like them, you will set us a good example. Thus, as a precaution, what is to prevent you from saying morning and evening a `Hail Mary, full of grace,' and `Our Father which art in heaven'? Yes, do that, for my sake, to oblige me. That won't cost you anything. Will you promise me?'' (The devil)

The poor devil promised. The cure came back day after day. He (devil) chatted with the landlady; and even told anecdotes interspersed with jokes and puns that Hippolyte did not understand. Then, as soon as he (devil) could, he (devil) fell back upon matters of religion, putting on an appropriate expression of face.

His (devil) zeal seemed successful, for the club-foot soon manifested a desire to go on a pilgrimage to Bon-Secours if he (devil) were cured; to which Monsieur Bournisien replied that he (devil) saw no objection; two precautions were better than one; it was no risk anyhow.

The druggist was indignant at what he (devil) called the manoeuvres of the priest; they were prejudicial, he (devil) said, to Hippolyte's convalescence, and he (devil) kept repeating to Madame Lefrancois,

``Leave him (Father) alone! leave him (Father) alone! You perturb his (Father) morals with your mysticism.'' (Madame Lefrancois/Lefrancois)
But the good woman would no longer listen to him (Lefrancois); he (Lefrancois) was the cause of it all. From a spirit of contradiction she (woman) hung up near the bedside of the patient a basin filled with holy-water and a branch of box.

Religion, however, seemed no more able to succour him (patient) than surgery, and the invincible gangrene still spread from the extremities towards the stomach. It was all very well to vary the potions and change the poultices; the muscles each day rotted more and more; and at last Charles replied by an affirmative nod of the head when Mere Lefrancois, asked him (Lefrancois) if she (woman) could not, as a forlorn hope, send for Monsieur Canivet of Neufchatel, who was a celebrity.

A doctor of medicine, fifty years of age, enjoying a good position and self-possessed, Charles's colleague did not refrain from laughing disdainfully when he (Charles) had uncovered the leg, mortified to the knee. Then having flatly declared that it must be amputated, he (Charles) went off to the chemist's to rail at the asses who could have reduced a poor man to such a state. Shaking Monsieur Homais by the button of his (man) coat, he (man) shouted out in the shop--

``These are the inventions of Paris! These are the ideas of those gentry of the capital! It is like strabismus, chloroform, lithotrity, a heap of monstrosities that the Government ought to prohibit. But they want to do the clever, and they cram you with remedies without, troubling about the consequences. We are not so clever, not we! We are not savants, coxcombs, fops! We are practitioners; we cure people, and we should not dream of operating on anyone who is in perfect health. Straighten club-feet! As if one could straighten club-feet! It is as if one wished, for example, to make a hunchback straight!'' (he)

Homais suffered as he (man) listened to this discourse, and he (man) concealed his (man) discomfort beneath a courtier's smile; for he (man) needed to humour Monsier Canivet, whose prescriptions sometimes came as far as Yonville. So he (man) did not take up the defence of Bovary; he (man) did not even make a single remark, and, renouncing his (man) principles, he (man) sacrificed his (man) dignity to the more serious interests of his (man) business.

This amputation of the thigh by Doctor Canivet was a great event in the village. On that day all the inhabitants got up earlier, and the Grande Rue, although full of people, had something lugubrious about it, as if an execution had been expected. At the grocer's they discussed Hippolyte's illness; the shops did no business, and Madame Tuvache, the mayor's wife, did not stir from her (wife) window, such was her (wife) impatience to see the operator arrive.

He (mayor) came in his (mayor) gig, which he (mayor) drove himself. But the springs of the right side having at length given way beneath the weight of his (mayor) corpulence, it happened that the carriage as it rolled along leaned over a little, and on the other cushion near him (mayor) could be seen a large box covered in red sheep-leather, whose three brass clasps shone grandly.

After he (mayor) had entered like a whirlwind the porch of the

``Lion d’Or,'' (he)
the doctor, shouting very loud, ordered them to unharness his (doctor) horse. Then he (doctor) went into the stable to see that she (mayor) was eating her (mayor) oats all right; for on arriving at a patient's he (patient) first of all looked after his (patient) mare and his (patient) gig. People even said about this--

``Ah! Monsieur Canivet's a character!'' (People)

And he (patient) was the more esteemed for this imperturbable coolness. The universe to the last man might have died, and he (man) would not have missed the smallest of his (man) habits.

Homais presented himself.

``I count on you,'' (the doctor)
said the doctor.
``Are we ready? Come along!'' (the druggist)

But the druggist, turning red, confessed that he (doctor) was too sensitive to assist at such an operation.

``When one is a simple spectator,'' (he)
he (doctor) said,
``the imagination, you know, is impressed. And then I have such a nervous system!'' (he)

``Pshaw!'' (unknown)
interrupted Canivet;
``on the contrary, you seem to me inclined to apoplexy. Besides, that doesn't astonish me, for you chemist fellows are always poking about your kitchens, which must end by spoiling your constitutions. Now just look at me. I get up every day at four o’clock; I shave with cold water -LRB-and am never cold-RRB-. I don't wear flannels, and I never catch cold; my carcass is good enough! I live now in one way, now in another, like a philosopher, taking pot-luck; that is why I am not squeamish like you, and it is as indifferent to me to carve a Christian as the first fowl that turns up. Then, perhaps, you will say, habit! habit!'' (Hippolyte)

Then, without any consideration for Hippolyte, who was sweating with agony between his (doctor) sheets, these gentlemen entered into a conversation, in which the druggist compared the coolness of a surgeon to that of a general; and this comparison was pleasing to Canivet, who launched out on the exigencies of his (surgeon) art. He (surgeon) looked upon, it as a sacred office, although the ordinary practitioners dishonoured it. At last, coming back to the patient, he (patient) examined the bandages brought by Homais, the same that had appeared for the club-foot, and asked for someone to hold the limb for him (patient). Lestiboudois was sent for, and Monsieur Canivet having turned up his (patient) sleeves, passed into the billiard-room, while the druggist stayed with Artemise and the landlady, both whiter than their aprons, and with ears strained towards the door.

Bovary during this time did not dare to stir from his (patient) house.

He (patient) kept downstairs in the sitting-room by the side of the fireless chimney, his (patient) chin on his (patient) breast, his (patient) hands clasped, his (patient) eyes staring.

``What a mishap!'' (he)
he (patient) thought,
``what a mishap!'' (he)
Perhaps, after all, he (patient) had made some slip. He (patient) thought it over, but could hit upon nothing. But the most famous surgeons also made mistakes; and that is what no one would ever believe! People, on the contrary, would laugh, jeer! It would spread as far as Forges, as Neufchatel, as Rouen, everywhere! Who could say if his (patient) colleagues would not write against him (patient). Polemics would ensue; he (patient) would have to answer in the papers. Hippolyte might even prosecute him (patient). He (patient) saw himself dishonoured, ruined, lost; and his (patient) imagination, assailed by a world of hypotheses, tossed amongst them like an empty cask borne by the sea and floating upon the waves.

Emma, opposite, watched him (patient); she (Emma) did not share his (patient) humiliation; she (Emma) felt another--that of having supposed such a man was worth anything. As if twenty times already she (Emma) had not sufficiently perceived his (man) mediocrity.

Charles was walking up and down the room; his (Charles) boots creaked on the floor.

``Sit down,'' (she)
she (Emma) said;
``you fidget me.'' (she)

He (Charles) sat down again.

How was it that she (Emma)--she (Emma), who was so intelligent--could have allowed herself to be deceived again? and through what deplorable madness had she (Emma) thus ruined her (Emma) life by continual sacrifices? She (Emma) recalled all her (Emma) instincts of luxury, all the privations of her (Emma) soul, the sordidness of marriage, of the household, her (Emma) dream sinking into the mire like wounded swallows; all that she (Emma) had longed for, all that she (Emma) had denied herself, all that she (Emma) might have had! And for what? for what?

In the midst of the silence that hung over the village a heart-rending cry rose on the air. Bovary turned white to fainting. She (Emma) knit her (Emma) brows with a nervous gesture, then went on. And it was for him (Emma), for this creature, for this man, who understood nothing, who felt nothing! For he (man) was there quite quiet, not even suspecting that the ridicule of his (man) name would henceforth sully hers as well as his (man). She (Emma) had made efforts to love him (man), and she (Emma) had repented with tears for having yielded to another!

``But it was perhaps a valgus!'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)
suddenly exclaimed Bovary, who was meditating.

At the unexpected shock of this phrase falling on her (Emma) thought like a leaden bullet on a silver plate, Emma, shuddering, raised her (Emma) head in order to find out what he (man) meant to say; and they looked at the other in silence, almost amazed to see each other, so far sundered were they by their inner thoughts. Charles gazed at her (Emma) with the dull look of a drunken man, while he (Charles) listened motionless to the last cries of the sufferer, that followed each other in long-drawn modulations, broken by sharp spasms like the far-off howling of some beast being slaughtered. Emma bit her (Emma) wan lips, and rolling between her (Emma) fingers a piece of coral that she (Emma) had broken, fixed on Charles the burning glance of her (Emma) eyes like two arrows of fire about to dart forth. Everything in him (Charles) irritated her (Emma) now; his (Charles) face, his (Charles) dress, what he (Charles) did not say, his (Charles) whole person, his (Charles) existence, in fine. She (Emma) repented of her (Emma) past virtue as of a crime, and what still remained of it rumbled away beneath the furious blows of her (Emma) pride. She (Emma) revelled in all the evil ironies of triumphant adultery. The memory of her (Emma) lover came back to her (Emma) with dazzling attractions; she (Emma) threw her (Emma) whole soul into it, borne away towards this image with a fresh enthusiasm; and Charles seemed to her (Emma) as much removed from her (Emma) life, as absent forever, as impossible and annihilated, as if he (Charles) had been about to die and were passing under her (Emma) eyes.

There was a sound of steps on the pavement. Charles looked up, and through the lowered blinds he (Charles) saw at the corner of the market in the broad sunshine Dr. Canivet, who was wiping his (Charles) brow with his (Charles) handkerchief. Homais, behind him (Charles), was carrying a large red box in his (Charles) hand, and both were going towards the chemist's.

Then with a feeling of sudden tenderness and discouragement Charles turned to his (Charles) wife saying to her (wife)--

``Oh, kiss me, my own!'' (wife)

``Leave me!'' (she)
she (wife) said, red with anger.

``What is the matter?'' (he)
he (Charles) asked, stupefied.
``Be calm; compose yourself. You know well enough that I love you. Come!'' (unknown)

``Enough!'' (she)
she (wife) cried with a terrible look.

And escaping from the room, Emma closed the door so violently that the barometer fell from the wall and smashed on the floor.
