Then her (captain) remembrance of the novel helping her (captain) to understand the libretto, she (captain) followed the story phrase by phrase, while vague thoughts that came back to her (captain) dispersed at once again with the bursts of music. She (captain) gave herself up to the lullaby of the melodies, and felt all her (captain) being vibrate as if the violin bows were drawn over her (captain) nerves. She (captain) had not eyes enough to look at the costumes, the scenery, the actors, the painted trees that shook when anyone walked, and the velvet caps, cloaks, swords--all those imaginary things that floated amid the harmony as in the atmosphere of another world. But a young woman stepped forward, throwing a purse to a squire in green. She (woman) was left alone, and the flute was heard like the murmur of a fountain or the warbling of birds. Lucie attacked her (woman) cavatina in G major bravely. She (woman) plained of love; she (woman) longed for wings. Emma, too, fleeing from life, would have liked to fly away in an embrace. Suddenly Edgar-Lagardy appeared.

He (Lucie) had that splendid pallor that gives something of the majesty of marble to the ardent races of the South. His (Lucie) vigorous form was tightly clad in a brown-coloured doublet; a small chiselled poniard hung against his (Lucie) left thigh, and he (Lucie) cast round laughing looks showing his (Lucie) white teeth. They said that a Polish princess having heard him (Lucie) sing one night on the beach at Biarritz, where he (Lucie) mended boats, had fallen in love with him (Lucie). She (princess) had ruined herself for him (Lucie). He (Lucie) had deserted her (princess) for other women, and this sentimental celebrity did not fail to enhance his (celebrity) artistic reputation. The diplomatic mummer took care always to slip into his (celebrity) advertisements some poetic phrase on the fascination of his (celebrity) person and the susceptibility of his (celebrity) soul. A fine organ, imperturbable coolness, more temperament than intelligence, more power of emphasis than of real singing, made up the charm of this admirable charlatan nature, in which there was something of the hairdresser and the toreador.

From the first scene he (charlatan) evoked enthusiasm. He (charlatan) pressed Lucy in his (charlatan) arms, he (charlatan) left her (Lucy), he (charlatan) came back, he (charlatan) seemed desperate; he (charlatan) had outbursts of rage, then elegiac gurglings of infinite sweetness, and the notes escaped from his (charlatan) bare neck full of sobs and kisses. Emma leant forward to see him (charlatan), clutching the velvet of the box with her (Emma) nails. She (Emma) was filling her (Emma) heart with these melodious lamentations that were drawn out to the accompaniment of the double-basses, like the cries of the drowning in the tumult of a tempest. She (Emma) recognised all the intoxication and the anguish that had almost killed her (Emma). The voice of a prima donna seemed to her (Emma) to be but echoes of her (Emma) conscience, and this illusion that charmed her (Emma) as some very thing of her (Emma) own life. But no one on earth had loved her (Emma) with such love. He (Emma) had not wept like Edgar that last moonlit night when they said,

``To-morrow! to-morrow!'' (Edgar)
The theatre rang with cheers; they recommenced the entire movement; the lovers spoke of the flowers on their tomb, of vows, exile, fate, hopes; and when they uttered the final adieu, Emma gave a sharp cry that mingled with the vibrations of the last chords.

``But why,'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)
asked Bovary,
``does that gentleman persecute her (they)?'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)

``No, no!'' (she)
she (Emma) answered;
``he (gentleman) is her (they) lover!'' (she)

``Yet he (gentleman) vows vengeance on her (they) family, while the other one who came on before said, `I love Lucie and she (they) loves me!' Besides, he (Lucie) went off with her (they) father arm in arm. For he (Lucie) certainly is her (they) father, isn't he (father)--the ugly little man with a cock's feather in his (father) hat?'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

Despite Emma's explanations, as soon as the recitative duet began in which Gilbert lays bare his (Gilbert) abominable machinations to his (Gilbert) master Ashton, Charles, seeing the false troth-ring that is to deceive Lucie, thought it was a love-gift sent by Edgar. He (Edgar) confessed, moreover, that he (Edgar) did not understand the story because of the music, which interfered very much with the words.

``What does it matter?'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma.
``Do be quiet!'' (unknown)

``Yes, but you know,'' (he)
he (Edgar) went on, leaning against her (Emma) shoulder,
``I like to understand things.'' (he)

``Be quiet! be quiet!'' (she)
she (Emma) cried impatiently.

Lucie advanced, half supported by her (Emma) women, a wreath of orange blossoms in her (Emma) hair, and paler than the white satin of her (Emma) gown. Emma dreamed of her (Emma) marriage day; she (Emma) saw herself at home again amid the corn in the little path as they walked to the church. Oh, why had not she (Emma), like this woman, resisted, implored? She (Emma), on the contrary, had been joyous, without seeing the abyss into which she (Emma) was throwing herself. Ah! if in the freshness of her (Emma) beauty, before the soiling of marriage and the disillusions of adultery, she (Emma) could have anchored her (Emma) life upon some great, strong heart, then virtue, tenderness, voluptuousness, and duty blending, she (Emma) would never have fallen from so high a happiness. But that happiness, no doubt, was a lie invented for the despair of all desire. She (Emma) now knew the smallness of the passions that art exaggerated. So, striving to divert her (Emma) thoughts, Emma determined now to see in this reproduction of her (Emma) sorrows only a plastic fantasy, well enough to please the eye, and she (Emma) even smiled internally with disdainful pity when at the back of the stage under the velvet hangings a man appeared in a black cloak.

His (man) large Spanish hat fell at a gesture he (man) made, and immediately the instruments and the singers began the sextet. Edgar, flashing with fury, dominated all the others with his (Edgar) clearer voice; Ashton hurled homicidal provocations at him (Ashton) in deep notes; Lucie uttered her (Emma) shrill plaint, Arthur at one side, his (Lucie) modulated tones in the middle register, and the bass of the minister pealed forth like an organ, while the voices of the women repeating his (Lucie) words took them up in chorus delightfully. They were all in a row gesticulating, and anger, vengeance, jealousy, terror, and stupefaction breathed forth at once from their half-opened mouths. The outraged lover brandished his (lover) naked sword; his (lover) guipure ruffle rose with jerks to the movements of his (lover) chest, and he (lover) walked from right to left with long strides, clanking against the boards the silver-gilt spurs of his (lover) soft boots, widening out at the ankles. He (lover), she (Lucie) thought must have an inexhaustible love to lavish it upon the crowd with such effusion. All her (Lucie) small fault-findings faded before the poetry of the part that absorbed her (Lucie); and, drawn towards this man by the illusion of the character, she (Lucie) tried to imagine to herself his (character) life--that life resonant, extraordinary, splendid, and that might have been hers if fate had willed it. They would have known one another, loved one another. With him (character), through all the kingdoms of Europe she (Lucie) would have travelled from capital to capital, sharing his (character) fatigues and his (character) pride, picking up the flowers thrown to him (character), herself embroidering his (character) costumes. Then each evening, at the back of a box, behind the golden trellis-work she (Lucie) would have drunk in eagerly the expansions of this soul that would have sung for her (Lucie) alone; from the stage, even as he (character) acted, he (character) would have looked at her (Lucie). But the mad idea seized her (Lucie) that he (character) was looking at her (Lucie); it was certain. She (Lucie) longed to run to his (character) arms, to take refuge in his (character) strength, as in the incarnation of love itself, and to say to him (character), to cry out,

``Take me away! carry me with you! let us go! Thine, thine! all my ardour and all my dreams!'' (him)

The curtain fell.

The smell of the gas mingled with that of the breaths, the waving of the fans, made the air more suffocating. Emma wanted to go out; the crowd filled the corridors, and she (Emma) fell back in her (Emma) arm-chair with palpitations that choked her (Emma). Charles, fearing that she (Emma) would faint, ran to the refreshment-room to get a glass of barley-water.

He (Charles) had great difficulty in getting back to his (Charles) seat, for his (Charles) elbows were jerked at every step because of the glass he (Charles) held in his (Charles) hands, and he (Charles) even spilt three-fourths on the shoulders of a Rouen lady in short sleeves, who feeling the cold liquid running down to her (lady) loins, uttered cries like a peacock, as if she (lady) were being assassinated. Her (lady) husband, who was a millowner, railed at the clumsy fellow, and while she (lady) was with her (lady) handkerchief wiping up the stains from her (lady) handsome cherry-coloured taffeta gown, he (fellow) angrily muttered about indemnity, costs, reimbursement. At last Charles reached his (Charles) wife, saying to her (wife), quite out of breath--

``Ma foi! I thought I should have had to stay there. There is such a crowd--SUCH a crowd!'' (her)

He (Charles) added--

``Just guess whom I met up there! Monsieur Leon!'' (He)

``Leon?'' (unknown)

``Himself! He (Leon)'s coming along to pay his (Leon) respects.'' (he)
And as he (Charles) finished these words the ex-clerk of Yonville entered the box.

He (Charles) held out his (Charles) hand with the ease of a gentleman; and Madame Bovary extended hers, without doubt obeying the attraction of a stronger will. She (wife) had not felt it since that spring evening when the rain fell upon the green leaves, and they had said good-bye standing at the window. But soon recalling herself to the necessities of the situation, with an effort she (wife) shook off the torpor of her (wife) memories, and began stammering a few hurried words.

``Ah, good-day! What! you here?'' (unknown)

``Silence!'' (unknown)
cried a voice from the pit, for the third act was beginning.

``So you are at Rouen?'' (unknown)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``And since when?'' (unknown)

``Turn them out! turn them out!'' (People)
People were looking at them. They were silent.

But from that moment she (wife) listened no more; and the chorus of the guests, the scene between Ashton and his (Ashton) servant, the grand duet in D major, all were for her (wife) as far off as if the instruments had grown less sonorous and the characters more remote. She (wife) remembered the games at cards at the druggist's, and the walk to the nurse's, the reading in the arbour, the tete-a-tete by the fireside--all that poor love, so calm and so protracted, so discreet, so tender, and that she (nurse) had nevertheless forgotten. And why had he (Ashton) come back? What combination of circumstances had brought him (Ashton) back into her (nurse) life? He (Ashton) was standing behind her (nurse), leaning with his (Ashton) shoulder against the wall of the box; now and again she (nurse) felt herself shuddering beneath the hot breath from his (Ashton) nostrils falling upon her (nurse) hair.

``Does this amuse you?'' (he)
said he (Ashton), bending over her (nurse) so closely that the end of his (Ashton) moustache brushed her (nurse) cheek. She (nurse) replied carelessly--

``Oh, dear me, no, not much.'' (She)

Then he (Ashton) proposed that they should leave the theatre and go and take an ice somewhere.

``Oh, not yet; let us stay,'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)
said Bovary.
``Her (you) hair's undone; this is going to be tragic.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

But the mad scene did not at all interest Emma, and the acting of the singer seemed to her (Emma) exaggerated.

``She (you) screams too loud,'' (she)
said she (Emma), turning to Charles, who was listening.

``Yes--a little,'' (he)
he (Charles) replied, undecided between the frankness of his (Charles) pleasure and his (Charles) respect for his (Charles) wife's opinion.

Then with a sigh Leon said--

``The heat is--'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)

``Unbearable! Yes!'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)

``Do you feel unwell?'' (unknown)
asked Bovary.

``Yes, I am stifling; let us go.'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)

Monsieur Leon put her (wife) long lace shawl carefully about her (wife) shoulders, and all three went off to sit down in the harbour, in the open air, outside the windows of a cafe.

First they spoke of her (wife) illness, although Emma interrupted Charles from time to time, for fear, she (wife) said, of boring Monsieur Leon; and the latter told them that he (Leon) had come to spend two years at Rouen in a large office, in order to get practice in his (Leon) profession, which was different in Normandy and Paris. Then he (Leon) inquired after Berthe, the Homais, Mere Lefrancois, and as they had, in the husband's presence, nothing more to say to one another, the conversation soon came to an end.

People coming out of the theatre passed along the pavement, humming or shouting at the top of their voices,

``O bel ange, ma Lucie!*'' (People)
Then Leon, playing the dilettante, began to talk music. He (Leon) had seen Tambourini, Rubini, Persiani, Grisi, and, compared with them, Lagardy, despite his (Leon) grand outbursts, was nowhere.

*Oh beautiful angel, my Lucie.

``Yet,'' (Charles)
interrupted Charles, who was slowly sipping his (Charles) rum-sherbet,
``they say that he (Lucie) is quite admirable in the last act. I regret leaving before the end, because it was beginning to amuse me.'' (Charles)

``Why,'' (the clerk)
said the clerk,
``he (Lucie) will soon give another performance.'' (the clerk)

But Charles replied that they were going back next day.

``Unless,'' (he)
he (Charles) added, turning to his (Charles) wife,
``you would like to stay alone, kitten?'' (wife)

And changing his (Charles) tactics at this unexpected opportunity that presented itself to his (Charles) hopes, the young man sang the praises of Lagardy in the last number. It was really superb, sublime. Then Charles insisted--

``You would get back on Sunday. Come, make up your mind. You are wrong if you feel that this is doing you the least good.'' (Charles)

The tables round them, however, were emptying; a waiter came and stood discreetly near them. Charles, who understood, took out his (Charles) purse; the clerk held back his (Charles) arm, and did not forget to leave two more pieces of silver that he (Charles) made chink on the marble.

``I am really sorry,'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)
said Bovary,
``about the money which you are--'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)

The other made a careless gesture full of cordiality, and taking his (Charles) hat said--

``It is settled, isn't it? To-morrow at six o’clock?'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)

Charles explained once more that he (Charles) could not absent himself longer, but that nothing prevented Emma--

``But,'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
she (Emma) stammered, with a strange smile,
``I am not sure--'' (she)

``Well, you must think it over. We'll see. Night brings counsel.'' (she)
Then to Leon, who was walking along with them,
``Now that you are in our part of the world, I hope you'll come and ask us for some dinner now and then.'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)

The clerk declared he (Leon) would not fail to do so, being obliged, moreover, to go to Yonville on some business for his (Leon) office. And they parted before the Saint-Herbland Passage just as the clock in the cathedral struck half-past eleven.

Part III

Chapter One

Monsieur Leon, while studying law, had gone pretty often to the dancing-rooms, where he (Leon) was even a great success amongst the grisettes, who thought he (Leon) had a distinguished air. He (Leon) was the best-mannered of the students; he (Leon) wore his (Leon) hair neither too long nor too short, didn't spend all his (Leon) quarter's money on the first day of the month, and kept on good terms with his (Leon) professors. As for excesses, he (Leon) had always abstained from them, as much from cowardice as from refinement.

Often when he (Leon) stayed in his (Leon) room to read, or else when sitting of an evening under the lime-trees of the Luxembourg, he (Leon) let his (Leon) Code fall to the ground, and the memory of Emma came back to him (Leon). But gradually this feeling grew weaker, and other desires gathered over it, although it still persisted through them all. For Leon did not lose all hope; there was for him (Leon), as it were, a vague promise floating in the future, like a golden fruit suspended from some fantastic tree.

Then, seeing her (Emma) again after three years of absence his (Leon) passion reawakened. He (Leon) must, he (Leon) thought, at last make up his (Leon) mind to possess her (Emma). Moreover, his (Leon) timidity had worn off by contact with his (Leon) gay companions, and he (Leon) returned to the provinces despising everyone who had not with varnished shoes trodden the asphalt of the boulevards. By the side of a Parisienne in her (Emma) laces, in the drawing-room of some illustrious physician, a person driving his (physician) carriage and wearing many orders, the poor clerk would no doubt have trembled like a child; but here, at Rouen, on the harbour, with the wife of this small doctor he (doctor) felt at his (doctor) ease, sure beforehand he (doctor) would shine. Self-possession depends on its environment. We don't speak on the first floor as on the fourth; and the wealthy woman seems to have, about her (woman), to guard her (woman) virtue, all her (woman) banknotes, like a cuirass in the lining of her (woman) corset.

On leaving the Bovarys the night before, Leon had followed them through the streets at a distance; then having seen them stop at the

``Croix-Rouge,'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
he (Leon) turned on his (Leon) heel, and spent the night meditating a plan.

So the next day about five o’clock he (Leon) walked into the kitchen of the inn, with a choking sensation in his (Leon) throat, pale cheeks, and that resolution of cowards that stops at nothing.

``The gentleman isn't in,'' (a servant)
answered a servant.

This seemed to him (servant) a good omen. He (servant) went upstairs.

She (woman) was not disturbed at his (servant) approach; on the contrary, she (woman) apologised for having neglected to tell him (servant) where they were staying.

``Oh, I divined it!'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
said Leon.

He (Leon) pretended he (Leon) had been guided towards her (woman) by chance, by, instinct. She (woman) began to smile; and at once, to repair his (Leon) folly, Leon told her (woman) that he (Leon) had spent his (Leon) morning in looking for her (woman) in all the hotels in the town one after the other.

``So you have made up your mind to stay?'' (he)
he (Leon) added.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (woman) said,
``and I am wrong. One ought not to accustom oneself to impossible pleasures when there are a thousand demands upon one.'' (she)

``Oh, I can imagine!'' (unknown)

``Ah! no; for you, you are a man!'' (men)

But men too had had their trials, and the conversation went off into certain philosophical reflections. Emma expatiated much on the misery of earthly affections, and the eternal isolation in which the heart remains entombed.

To show off, or from a naive imitation of this melancholy which called forth his (Leon), the young man declared that he (Leon) had been awfully bored during the whole course of his (Leon) studies. The law irritated him (Leon), other vocations attracted him (Leon), and his (Leon) mother never ceased worrying him (Leon) in every one of her (mother) letters. As they talked they explained more and more fully the motives of their sadness, working themselves up in their progressive confidence. But they sometimes stopped short of the complete exposition of their thought, and then sought to invent a phrase that might express it all the same. She (mother) did not confess her (mother) passion for another; he (Leon) did not say that he (Leon) had forgotten her (mother).

Perhaps he (Leon) no longer remembered his (Leon) suppers with girls after masked balls; and no doubt she (mother) did not recollect the rendezvous of old when she (mother) ran across the fields in the morning to her (mother) lover's house. The noises of the town hardly reached them, and the room seemed small, as if on purpose to hem in their solitude more closely. Emma, in a dimity dressing-gown, leant her (Emma) head against the back of the old arm-chair; the yellow wall-paper formed, as it were, a golden background behind her (Emma), and her (Emma) bare head was mirrored in the glass with the white parting in the middle, and the tip of her (Emma) ears peeping out from the folds of her (Emma) hair.

``But pardon me!'' (she)
she (Emma) said.
``It is wrong of me. I weary you with my eternal complaints.'' (unknown)

``No, never, never!'' (unknown)

``If you knew,'' (she)
she (Emma) went on, raising to the ceiling her (Emma) beautiful eyes, in which a tear was trembling,
``all that I had dreamed!'' (she)

``And I! Oh, I too have suffered! Often I went out; I went away. I dragged myself along the quays, seeking distraction amid the din of the crowd without being able to banish the heaviness that weighed upon me. In an engraver's shop on the boulevard there is an Italian print of one of the Muses. She (me) is draped in a tunic, and she (me) is looking at the moon, with forget-me-nots in her (me) flowing hair. Something drove me there continually; I stayed there hours together.'' (unknown)
Then in a trembling voice,
``She (me) resembled you a little.'' (Madame)

Madame Bovary turned away her (Emma) head that he (Emma) might not see the irrepressible smile she (Emma) felt rising to her (Emma) lips.

``Often,'' (he)
he (Emma) went on,
``I wrote you letters that I tore up.'' (he)

She (Emma) did not answer. He (Emma) continued--

``I sometimes fancied that some chance would bring you. I thought I recognised you at street-corners, and I ran after all the carriages through whose windows I saw a shawl fluttering, a veil like yours.'' (He)

She (Emma) seemed resolved to let him (Emma) go on speaking without interruption. Crossing her (Emma) arms and bending down her (Emma) face, she (Emma) looked at the rosettes on her (Emma) slippers, and at intervals made little movements inside the satin of them with her (Emma) toes.

At last she (Emma) sighed.

``But the most wretched thing, is it not--is to drag out, as I do, a useless existence. If our pains were only of some use to someone, we should find consolation in the thought of the sacrifice.'' (He)

He (Emma) started off in praise of virtue, duty, and silent immolation, having himself an incredible longing for self-sacrifice that he (Emma) could not satisfy.

``I should much like,'' (she)
she (Emma) said,
``to be a nurse at a hospital.'' (she)

``Alas! men have none of these holy missions, and I see nowhere any calling--unless perhaps that of a doctor.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

With a slight shrug of her (Emma) shoulders, Emma interrupted him (Emma) to speak of her (Emma) illness, which had almost killed her (Emma). What a pity! She (Emma) should not be suffering now! Leon at once envied the calm of the tomb, and one evening he (Leon) had even made his (Leon) will, asking to be buried in that beautiful rug with velvet stripes he (Leon) had received from her (Emma). For this was how they would have wished to be, each setting up an ideal to which they were now adapting their past life. Besides, speech is a rolling-mill that always thins out the sentiment.

But at this invention of the rug she (Emma) asked,

``But why?'' (she)

``Why?'' (He)
He (Leon) hesitated.
``Because I loved you so!'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
And congratulating himself at having surmounted the difficulty, Leon watched her (Emma) face out of the corner of his (Leon) eyes.

It was like the sky when a gust of wind drives the clouds across. The mass of sad thoughts that darkened them seemed to be lifted from her (Emma) blue eyes; her (Emma) whole face shone. He (Leon) waited. At last she (Emma) replied--

``I always suspected it.'' (she)

Then they went over all the trifling events of that far-off existence, whose joys and sorrows they had just summed up in one word. They recalled the arbour with clematis, the dresses she (Emma) had worn, the furniture of her (Emma) room, the whole of her (Emma) house.

``And our poor cactuses, where are they?'' (unknown)

``The cold killed them this winter.'' (unknown)

``Ah! how I have thought of them, do you know? I often saw them again as of yore, when on the summer mornings the sun beat down upon your blinds, and I saw your two bare arms passing out amongst the flowers.'' (unknown)

``Poor friend!'' (she)
she (Emma) said, holding out her (Emma) hand to him (Leon).

Leon swiftly pressed his (Leon) lips to it. Then, when he (Leon) had taken a deep breath--

``At that time you were to me I know not what incomprehensible force that took captive my life. Once, for instance, I went to see you; but you, no doubt, do not remember it.'' (he)

``I do,'' (she)
she (Emma) said;
``go on.'' (she)

``You were downstairs in the ante-room, ready to go out, standing on the last stair; you were wearing a bonnet with small blue flowers; and without any invitation from you, in spite of myself, I went with you. Every moment, however, I grew more and more conscious of my folly, and I went on walking by you, not daring to follow you completely, and unwilling to leave you. When you went into a shop, I waited in the street, and I watched you through the window taking off your gloves and counting the change on the counter. Then you rang at Madame Tuvache's; you were let in, and I stood like an idiot in front of the great heavy door that had closed after you.'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)

Madame Bovary, as she (Emma) listened to him (Leon), wondered that she (Emma) was so old. All these things reappearing before her (Emma) seemed to widen out her (Emma) life; it was like some sentimental immensity to which she (Emma) returned; and from time to time she (Emma) said in a low voice, her (Emma) eyes half closed--

``Yes, it is true--true--true!'' (she)

They heard eight strike on the different clocks of the Beauvoisine quarter, which is full of schools, churches, and large empty hotels. They no longer spoke, but they felt as they looked upon each other a buzzing in their heads, as if something sonorous had escaped from the fixed eyes of each of them. They were hand in hand now, and the past, the future, reminiscences and dreams, all were confounded in the sweetness of this ecstasy. Night was darkening over the walls, on which still shone, half hidden in the shade, the coarse colours of four bills representing four scenes from the

``Tour de Nesle,'' (unknown)
with a motto in Spanish and French at the bottom. Through the sash-window a patch of dark sky was seen between the pointed roofs.

She (them) rose to light two wax-candles on the drawers, then she (them) sat down again.

``Well!'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
said Leon.

``Well!'' (she)
she (them) replied.

He (Leon) was thinking how to resume the interrupted conversation, when she (them) said to him (Leon)--

``How is it that no one until now has ever expressed such sentiments to me?'' (him)

The clerk said that ideal natures were difficult to understand. He (Leon) from the first moment had loved her (them), and he (Leon) despaired when he (Leon) thought of the happiness that would have been theirs, if thanks to fortune, meeting her (them) earlier, they had been indissolubly bound to one another.

``I have sometimes thought of it,'' (she)
she (them) went on.

``What a dream!'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
murmured Leon. And fingering gently the blue binding of her (them) long white sash, he (Leon) added,
``And who prevents us from beginning now?'' (he)

``No, my friend,'' (she)
she (them) replied;
``I am too old; you are too young. Forget me! Others will love you; you will love them.'' (she)

``Not as you!'' (he)
he (Leon) cried.

``What a child you are! Come, let us be sensible. I wish it.'' (She)

She (them) showed him (Leon) the impossibility of their love, and that they must remain, as formerly, on the simple terms of a fraternal friendship.

Was she (them) speaking thus seriously? No doubt Emma did not herself know, quite absorbed as she (Emma) was by the charm of the seduction, and the necessity of defending herself from it; and contemplating the young man with a moved look, she (Emma) gently repulsed the timid caresses that his (man) trembling hands attempted.

``Ah! forgive me!'' (he)
he (man) cried, drawing back.

Emma was seized with a vague fear at this shyness, more dangerous to her (Emma) than the boldness of Rodolphe when he (Rodolphe) advanced to her (Emma) open-armed. No man had ever seemed to her (Emma) so beautiful. An exquisite candour emanated from his (man) being. He (man) lowered his (man) long fine eyelashes, that curled upwards. His (man) cheek, with the soft skin reddened, she (Emma) thought, with desire of her (Emma) person, and Emma felt an invincible longing to press her (Emma) lips to it. Then, leaning towards the clock as if to see the time--

``Ah! how late it is!'' (she)
she (Emma) said;
``how we do chatter!'' (she)

He (man) understood the hint and took up his (man) hat.

``It has even made me forget the theatre. And poor Bovary has left me here especially for that. Monsieur Lormeaux, of the Rue Grand-Pont, was to take me and his (I) wife.'' (she)

And the opportunity was lost, as she (Emma) was to leave the next day.

``Really!'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
said Leon.

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``But I must see you again,'' (he)
he (Leon) went on.
``I wanted to tell you--'' (unknown)

``What?'' (unknown)

``Something--important--serious. Oh, no! Besides, you will not go; it is impossible. If you should--listen to me. Then you have not understood me; you have not guessed--'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

``Yet you speak plainly,'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma.

``Ah! you can jest. Enough! enough! Oh, for pity's sake, let me see you once--only once!'' (unknown)

``Well--'' (She)
She (Emma) stopped; then, as if thinking better of it,
``Oh, not here!'' (She)

``Where you will.'' (unknown)

``Will you--'' (She)
She (Emma) seemed to reflect; then abruptly,
``To-morrow at eleven o’clock in the cathedral.'' (She)

``I shall be there,'' (he)
he (Leon) cried, seizing her (Emma) hands, which she (Emma) disengaged.

And as they were both standing up, he (Leon) behind her (Emma), and Emma with her (Emma) head bent, he (Leon) stooped over her (Emma) and pressed long kisses on her (Emma) neck.

``You are mad! Ah! you are mad!'' (she)
she (Emma) said, with sounding little laughs, while the kisses multiplied.

Then bending his (Leon) head over her (Emma) shoulder, he (Leon) seemed to beg the consent of her (Emma) eyes. They fell upon him (Leon) full of an icy dignity.

Leon stepped back to go out. He (Leon) stopped on the threshold; then he (Leon) whispered with a trembling voice,

``Tomorrow!'' (he)

She (Emma) answered with a nod, and disappeared like a bird into the next room.

In the evening Emma wrote the clerk an interminable letter, in which she (Emma) cancelled the rendezvous; all was over; they must not, for the sake of their happiness, meet again. But when the letter was finished, as she (Emma) did not know Leon's address, she (Emma) was puzzled.

``I'll give it to him (you) myself,'' (she)
she (Emma) said;
``he (you) will come.'' (she)

The next morning, at the open window, and humming on his (Leon) balcony, Leon himself varnished his (Leon) pumps with several coatings. He (Leon) put on white trousers, fine socks, a green coat, emptied all the scent he (Leon) had into his (Leon) handkerchief, then having had his (Leon) hair curled, he (Leon) uncurled it again, in order to give it a more natural elegance.

``It is still too early,'' (he)
he (Leon) thought, looking at the hairdresser's cuckoo-clock, that pointed to the hour of nine. He (Leon) read an old fashion journal, went out, smoked a cigar, walked up three streets, thought it was time, and went slowly towards the porch of Notre Dame.

It was a beautiful summer morning. Silver plate sparkled in the jeweller's windows, and the light falling obliquely on the cathedral made mirrors of the corners of the grey stones; a flock of birds fluttered in the grey sky round the trefoil bell-turrets; the square, resounding with cries, was fragrant with the flowers that bordered its pavement, roses, jasmines, pinks, narcissi, and tube-roses, unevenly spaced out between moist grasses, catmint, and chickweed for the birds; the fountains gurgled in the centre, and under large umbrellas, amidst melons, piled up in heaps, flower-women, bare-headed, were twisting paper round bunches of violets.

The young man took one. It was the first time that he (man) had bought flowers for a woman, and his (man) breast, as he (man) smelt them, swelled with pride, as if this homage that he (man) meant for another had recoiled upon himself.

But he (man) was afraid of being seen; he (man) resolutely entered the church. The beadle, who was just then standing on the threshold in the middle of the left doorway, under the

``Dancing Marianne,'' (The beadle rapier)
with feather cap, and rapier dangling against his (beadle) calves, came in, more majestic than a cardinal, and as shining as a saint on a holy pyx.

He (saint) came towards Leon, and, with that smile of wheedling benignity assumed by ecclesiastics when they question children--

``The gentleman, no doubt, does not belong to these parts? The gentleman would like to see the curiosities of the church?'' (children)

``No!'' (unknown)
said the other.

And he (Leon) first went round the lower aisles. Then he (Leon) went out to look at the Place. Emma was not coming yet. He (Leon) went up again to the choir.

The nave was reflected in the full fonts with the beginning of the arches and some portions of the glass windows. But the reflections of the paintings, broken by the marble rim, were continued farther on upon the flag-stones, like a many-coloured carpet. The broad daylight from without streamed into the church in three enormous rays from the three opened portals. From time to time at the upper end a sacristan passed, making the oblique genuflexion of devout persons in a hurry. The crystal lustres hung motionless. In the choir a silver lamp was burning, and from the side chapels and dark places of the church sometimes rose sounds like sighs, with the clang of a closing grating, its echo reverberating under the lofty vault.

Leon with solemn steps walked along by the walls. Life had never seemed so good to him (Leon). She (sacristan) would come directly, charming, agitated, looking back at the glances that followed her (sacristan), and with her (sacristan) flounced dress, her (sacristan) gold eyeglass, her (sacristan) thin shoes, with all sorts of elegant trifles that he (Leon) had never enjoyed, and with the ineffable seduction of yielding virtue. The church like a huge boudoir spread around her (sacristan); the arches bent down to gather in the shade the confession of her (sacristan) love; the windows shone resplendent to illumine her (sacristan) face, and the censers would burn that she (sacristan) might appear like an angel amid the fumes of the sweet-smelling odours.

But she (sacristan) did not come. He (angel) sat down on a chair, and his (angel) eyes fell upon a blue stained window representing boatmen carrying baskets. He (angel) looked at it long, attentively, and he (angel) counted the scales of the fishes and the button-holes of the doublets, while his (angel) thoughts wandered off towards Emma.

The beadle, standing aloof, was inwardly angry at this individual who took the liberty of admiring the cathedral by himself. He (individual) seemed to him (individual) to be conducting himself in a monstrous fashion, to be robbing him (individual) in a sort, and almost committing sacrilege.

But a rustle of silk on the flags, the tip of a bonnet, a lined cloak--it was she (Emma)! Leon rose and ran to meet her (Emma).

Emma was pale. She (Emma) walked fast.

``Read!'' (she)
she (Emma) said, holding out a paper to him (Leon).
``Oh, no!'' (she)

And she (Emma) abruptly withdrew her (Emma) hand to enter the chapel of the Virgin, where, kneeling on a chair, she (Emma) began to pray.

The young man was irritated at this bigot fancy; then he (man) nevertheless experienced a certain charm in seeing her (Emma), in the middle of a rendezvous, thus lost in her (Emma) devotions, like an Andalusian marchioness; then he (man) grew bored, for she (Emma) seemed never coming to an end.

Emma prayed, or rather strove to pray, hoping that some sudden resolution might descend to her (Emma) from heaven; and to draw down divine aid she (Emma) filled full her (Emma) eyes with the splendours of the tabernacle. She (Emma) breathed in the perfumes of the full-blown flowers in the large vases, and listened to the stillness of the church, that only heightened the tumult of her (Emma) heart.

She (Emma) rose, and they were about to leave, when the beadle came forward, hurriedly saying--

``Madame, no doubt, does not belong to these parts? Madame would like to see the curiosities of the church?'' (the beadle)

``Oh, no!'' (the clerk)
cried the clerk.

``Why not?'' (she)
said she (clerk). For she (clerk) clung with her (clerk) expiring virtue to the Virgin, the sculptures, the tombs--anything.

Then, in order to proceed

``by rule,'' (the beadle)
the beadle conducted them right to the entrance near the square, where, pointing out with his (beadle) cane a large circle of block-stones without inscription or carving--

``This,'' (the beadle)
he (beadle) said majestically,
``is the circumference of the beautiful bell of Ambroise. It weighed forty thousand pounds. There was not its equal in all Europe. The workman who cast it died of the joy--'' (he)

``Let us go on,'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
said Leon.

The old fellow started off again; then, having got back to the chapel of the Virgin, he (fellow) stretched forth his (fellow) arm with an all-embracing gesture of demonstration, and, prouder than a country squire showing you his (fellow) espaliers, went on--

``This simple stone covers Pierre de Breze, lord of Varenne and of Brissac, grand marshal of Poitou, and governor of Normandy, who died at the battle of Montlhery on the 16th of July, 1465.'' (he)

Leon bit his (Leon) lips, fuming.

``And on the right, this gentleman all encased in iron, on the prancing horse, is his (gentleman) grandson, Louis de Breze, lord of Breval and of Montchauvet, Count de Maulevrier, Baron de Mauny, chamberlain to the king, Knight of the Order, and also governor of Normandy; died on the 23rd of July, 1531--a Sunday, as the inscription specifies; and below, this figure, about to descend into the tomb, portrays the same person. It is not possible, is it, to see a more perfect representation of annihilation?'' (Madame)

Madame Bovary put up her (Leon) eyeglasses. Leon, motionless, looked at her (Leon), no longer even attempting to speak a single word, to make a gesture, so discouraged was he (Leon) at this two-fold obstinacy of gossip and indifference.

The everlasting guide went on--

``Near him (governor), this kneeling woman who weeps is his (governor) spouse, Diane de Poitiers, Countess de Breze, Duchess de Valentinois, born in 1499, died in 1566, and to the left, the one with the child is the Holy Virgin. Now turn to this side; here are the tombs of the Ambroise. They were both cardinals and archbishops of Rouen. That one was minister under Louis XII. He (Louis) did a great deal for the cathedral. In his (Louis) will he (Louis) left thirty thousand gold crowns for the poor.'' (he)

And without stopping, still talking, he (Leon) pushed them into a chapel full of balustrades, some put away, and disclosed a kind of block that certainly might once have been an ill-made statue.

``Truly,'' (he)
he (Leon) said with a groan,
``it adorned the tomb of Richard Coeur de Lion, King of England and Duke of Normandy. It was the Calvinists, sir, who reduced it to this condition. They had buried it for spite in the earth, under the episcopal seat of Monsignor. See! this is the door by which Monsignor passes to his (Monsignor) house. Let us pass on quickly to see the gargoyle windows.'' (he)

But Leon hastily took some silver from his (Leon) pocket and seized Emma's arm. The beadle stood dumfounded, not able to understand this untimely munificence when there were still so many things for the stranger to see. So calling him (stranger) back, he (stranger) cried--

``Sir! sir! The steeple! the steeple!'' (he)

``No, thank you!'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
said Leon.

``You are wrong, sir! It is four hundred and forty feet high, nine less than the great pyramid of Egypt. It is all cast; it--'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)

Leon was fleeing, for it seemed to him (Leon) that his (Leon) love, that for nearly two hours now had become petrified in the church like the stones, would vanish like a vapour through that sort of truncated funnel, of oblong cage, of open chimney that rises so grotesquely from the cathedral like the extravagant attempt of some fantastic brazier.

``But where are we going?'' (she)
she (stranger) said.

Making no answer, he (Leon) walked on with a rapid step; and Madame Bovary was already, dipping her (stranger) finger in the holy water when behind them they heard a panting breath interrupted by the regular sound of a cane. Leon turned back.

``Sir!'' (unknown)

``What is it?'' (he)

And he (Leon) recognised the beadle, holding under his (Leon) arms and balancing against his (Leon) stomach some twenty large sewn volumes. They were works

``which treated of the cathedral.'' (unknown)

``Idiot!'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
growled Leon, rushing out of the church.

A lad was playing about the close.

``Go and get me a cab!'' (The child)

The child bounded off like a ball by the Rue Quatre-Vents; then they were alone a few minutes, face to face, and a little embarrassed.

``Ah! Leon! Really--I don't know--if I ought,'' (she)
she (stranger) whispered. Then with a more serious air,
``Do you know, it is very improper--'' (unknown)

``How so?'' (the clerk)
replied the clerk.
``It is done at Paris.'' (her)

And that, as an irresistible argument, decided her (stranger).

Still the cab did not come. Leon was afraid she (stranger) might go back into the church. At last the cab appeared.

``At all events, go out by the north porch,'' (the beadle)
cried the beadle, who was left alone on the threshold,
``so as to see the Resurrection, the Last Judgment, Paradise, King David, and the Condemned in Hell-flames.'' (the beadle)

``Where to, sir?'' (the coachman)
asked the coachman.

``Where you like,'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
said Leon, forcing Emma into the cab.

And the lumbering machine set out. It went down the Rue Grand-Pont, crossed the Place des Arts, the Quai Napoleon, the Pont Neuf, and stopped short before the statue of Pierre Corneille.

``Go on,'' (unknown)
cried a voice that came from within.

The cab went on again, and as soon as it reached the Carrefour Lafayette, set off down-hill, and entered the station at a gallop.

``No, straight on!'' (unknown)
cried the same voice.

The cab came out by the gate, and soon having reached the Cours, trotted quietly beneath the elm-trees. The coachman wiped his (Pierre) brow, put his (Pierre) leather hat between his (Pierre) knees, and drove his (Pierre) carriage beyond the side alley by the meadow to the margin of the waters.

It went along by the river, along the towing-path paved with sharp pebbles, and for a long while in the direction of Oyssel, beyond the isles.

But suddenly it turned with a dash across Quatremares, Sotteville, La Grande-Chaussee, the Rue d’Elbeuf, and made its third halt in front of the Jardin des Plantes.

``Get on, will you?'' (unknown)
cried the voice more furiously.

And at once resuming its course, it passed by Saint-Sever, by the Quai'des Curandiers, the Quai aux Meules, once more over the bridge, by the Place du Champ de Mars, and behind the hospital gardens, where old men in black coats were walking in the sun along the terrace all green with ivy. It went up the Boulevard Bouvreuil, along the Boulevard Cauchoise, then the whole of Mont-Riboudet to the Deville hills.

It came back; and then, without any fixed plan or direction, wandered about at hazard. The cab was seen at Saint-Pol, at Lescure, at Mont Gargan, at La Rougue-Marc and Place du Gaillardbois; in the Rue Maladrerie, Rue Dinanderie, before Saint-Romain, Saint-Vivien, Saint-Maclou, Saint-Nicaise--in front of the Customs, at the

``Vieille Tour,'' (unknown)
the
``Trois Pipes,'' (unknown)
and the Monumental Cemetery. From time to time the coachman, on his (coachman) box cast despairing eyes at the public-houses. He (coachman) could not understand what furious desire for locomotion urged these individuals never to wish to stop. He (coachman) tried to now and then, and at once exclamations of anger burst forth behind him (coachman). Then he (coachman) lashed his (coachman) perspiring jades afresh, but indifferent to their jolting, running up against things here and there, not caring if he (coachman) did, demoralised, and almost weeping with thirst, fatigue, and depression.

And on the harbour, in the midst of the drays and casks, and in the streets, at the corners, the good folk opened large wonder-stricken eyes at this sight, so extraordinary in the provinces, a cab with blinds drawn, and which appeared thus constantly shut more closely than a tomb, and tossing about like a vessel.

Once in the middle of the day, in the open country, just as the sun beat most fiercely against the old plated lanterns, a bared hand passed beneath the small blinds of yellow canvas, and threw out some scraps of paper that scattered in the wind, and farther off lighted like white butterflies on a field of red clover all in bloom.

At about six o’clock the carriage stopped in a back street of the Beauvoisine Quarter, and a woman got out, who walked with her (woman) veil down, and without turning her (woman) head.

Chapter Two

On reaching the inn, Madame Bovary was surprised not to see the diligence. Hivert, who had waited for her (woman) fifty-three minutes, had at last started.

Yet nothing forced her (woman) to go; but she (woman) had given her (woman) word that she (woman) would return that same evening. Moreover, Charles expected her (woman), and in her (woman) heart she (woman) felt already that cowardly docility that is for some women at once the chastisement and atonement of adultery.

She (woman) packed her (woman) box quickly, paid her (woman) bill, took a cab in the yard, hurrying on the driver, urging him (driver) on, every moment inquiring about the time and the miles traversed. He (driver) succeeded in catching up the

``Hirondelle'' (He)
as it neared the first houses of Quincampoix.

Hardly was she (woman) seated in her (woman) corner than she (woman) closed her (woman) eyes, and opened them at the foot of the hill, when from afar she (woman) recognised Felicite, who was on the lookout in front of the farrier's shop. Hivert pulled in his (farrier) horses and, the servant, climbing up to the window, said mysteriously--

``Madame, you must go at once to Monsieur Homais. It's for something important.'' (the servant)

The village was silent as usual. At the corner of the streets were small pink heaps that smoked in the air, for this was the time for jam-making, and everyone at Yonville prepared his (farrier) supply on the same day. But in front of the chemist's shop one might admire a far larger heap, and that surpassed the others with the superiority that a laboratory must have over ordinary stores, a general need over individual fancy.

She (everyone) went in. The large arm-chair was upset, and even the

``Fanal de Rouen'' (She)
lay on the ground, outspread between two pestles. She (everyone) pushed open the lobby door, and in the middle of the kitchen, amid brown jars full of picked currants, of powdered sugar and lump sugar, of the scales on the table, and of the pans on the fire, she (everyone) saw all the Homais, small and large, with aprons reaching to their chins, and with forks in their hands. Justin was standing up with bowed head, and the chemist was screaming--

``Who told you to go and fetch it in the Capharnaum.'' (the chemist)

``What is it? What is the matter?'' (unknown)

``What is it?'' (the druggist)
replied the druggist.
``We are making preserves; they are simmering; but they were about to boil over, because there is too much juice, and I ordered another pan. Then he (it), from indolence, from laziness, went and took, hanging on its nail in my laboratory, the key of the Capharnaum.'' (the druggist)

It was thus the druggist called a small room under the leads, full of the utensils and the goods of his (chemist) trade. He (chemist) often spent long hours there alone, labelling, decanting, and doing up again; and he (chemist) looked upon it not as a simple store, but as a veritable sanctuary, whence there afterwards issued, elaborated by his (chemist) hands, all sorts of pills, boluses, infusions, lotions, and potions, that would bear far and wide his (chemist) celebrity. No one in the world set foot there, and he (chemist) respected it so, that he (chemist) swept it himself. Finally, if the pharmacy, open to all comers, was the spot where he (chemist) displayed his (chemist) pride, the Capharnaum was the refuge where, egoistically concentrating himself, Homais delighted in the exercise of his (chemist) predilections, so that Justin's thoughtlessness seemed to him (chemist) a monstrous piece of irreverence, and, redder than the currants, he (chemist) repeated--

``Yes, from the Capharnaum! The key that locks up the acids and caustic alkalies! To go and get a spare pan! a pan with a lid! and that I shall perhaps never use! Everything is of importance in the delicate operations of our art! But, devil take it! one must make distinctions, and not employ for almost domestic purposes that which is meant for pharmaceutical! It is as if one were to carve a fowl with a scalpel; as if a magistrate--'' (he)

``Now be calm,'' (Madame Homais)
said Madame Homais.

And Athalie, pulling at his (chemist) coat, cried

``Papa! papa!'' (Athalie)

``No, let me alone,'' (the druggist)
went on the druggist
``let me alone, hang it! My word! One might as well set up for a grocer. That's it! go it! respect nothing! break, smash, let loose the leeches, burn the mallow-paste, pickle the gherkins in the window jars, tear up the bandages!'' (the druggist)

``I thought you had--'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma.

``Presently! Do you know to what you exposed yourself? Didn't you see anything in the corner, on the left, on the third shelf? Speak, answer, articulate something.'' (unknown)

``I--don't--know,'' (the fellow)
stammered the young fellow.

``Ah! you don't know! Well, then, I do know! You saw a bottle of blue glass, sealed with yellow wax, that contains a white powder, on which I have even written `Dangerous!' And do you know what is in it? Arsenic! And you go and touch it! You take a pan that was next to it!'' (unknown)

``Next to it!'' (Madame Homais)
cried Madame Homais, clasping her (Emma) hands.
``Arsenic! You might have poisoned us all.'' (the children)

And the children began howling as if they already had frightful pains in their entrails.

``Or poison a patient!'' (the druggist)
continued the druggist.
``Do you want to see me in the prisoner's dock with criminals, in a court of justice? To see me dragged to the scaffold? Don't you know what care I take in managing things, although I am so thoroughly used to it? Often I am horrified myself when I think of my responsibility; for the Government persecutes us, and the absurd legislation that rules us is a veritable Damocles' sword over our heads.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

Emma no longer dreamed of asking what they wanted her (Emma) for, and the druggist went on in breathless phrases--

``That is your return for all the kindness we have shown you! That is how you recompense me for the really paternal care that I lavish on you! For without me where would you be? What would you be doing? Who provides you with food, education, clothes, and all the means of figuring one day with honour in the ranks of society? But you must pull hard at the oar if you're to do that, and get, as, people say, callosities upon your hands. Fabricando fit faber, age quod agis.*'' (the druggist)

* The worker lives by working, do what he (worker) will.

He (worker) was so exasperated he (worker) quoted Latin. He (worker) would have quoted Chinese or Greenlandish had he (worker) known those two languages, for he (worker) was in one of those crises in which the whole soul shows indistinctly what it contains, like the ocean, which, in the storm, opens itself from the seaweeds on its shores down to the sands of its abysses.

And he (worker) went on--

``I am beginning to repent terribly of having taken you up! I should certainly have done better to have left you to rot in your poverty and the dirt in which you were born. Oh, you'll never be fit for anything but to herd animals with horns! You have no aptitude for science! You hardly know how to stick on a label! And there you are, dwelling with me snug as a parson, living in clover, taking your ease!'' (he)

But Emma, turning to Madame Homais,

``I was told to come here--'' (Madame Homais)

``Oh, dear me!'' (Madame Homais)
interrupted the good woman, with a sad air,
``how am I to tell you? It is a misfortune!'' (the woman)

She (Emma) could not finish, the druggist was thundering--

``Empty it! Clean it! Take it back! Be quick!'' (the druggist)

And seizing Justin by the collar of his (Justin) blouse, he (Justin) shook a book out of his (Justin) pocket. The lad stooped, but Homais was the quicker, and, having picked up the volume, contemplated it with staring eyes and open mouth.

``CONJUGAL--LOVE!'' (he)
he (Justin) said, slowly separating the two words.
``Ah! very good! very good! very pretty! And illustrations! Oh, this is too much!'' (Madame)

Madame Homais came forward.

``No, do not touch it!'' (The children)

The children wanted to look at the pictures.

``Leave the room,'' (he)
he (Justin) said imperiously; and they went out.

First he (Justin) walked up and down with the open volume in his (Justin) hand, rolling his (Justin) eyes, choking, tumid, apoplectic. Then he (Justin) came straight to his (Justin) pupil, and, planting himself in front of him (Justin) with crossed arms--

``Have you every vice, then, little wretch? Take care! you are on a downward path. Did not you reflect that this infamous book might fall in the hands of my children, kindle a spark in their minds, tarnish the purity of Athalie, corrupt Napoleon. He (Napoleon) is already formed like a man. Are you quite sure, anyhow, that they have not read it? Can you certify to me--'' (him)

``But really, sir,'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma,
``you wished to tell me--'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

``Ah, yes! madame. Your father-in-law is dead.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

In fact, Monsieur Bovary senior had expired the evening before suddenly from an attack of apoplexy as he (Justin) got up from table, and by way of greater precaution, on account of Emma's sensibility, Charles had begged Homais to break the horrible news to her (Emma) gradually. Homais had thought over his (Charles) speech; he (Charles) had rounded, polished it, made it rhythmical; it was a masterpiece of prudence and transitions, of subtle turns and delicacy; but anger had got the better of rhetoric.

Emma, giving up all chance of hearing any details, left the pharmacy; for Monsieur Homais had taken up the thread of his (Charles) vituperations. However, he (Charles) was growing calmer, and was now grumbling in a paternal tone whilst he (Charles) fanned himself with his (Charles) skull-cap.

``It is not that I entirely disapprove of the work. Its author was a doctor! There are certain scientific points in it that it is not ill a man should know, and I would even venture to say that a man must know. But later--later! At any rate, not till you are man yourself and your temperament is formed.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

When Emma knocked at the door. Charles, who was waiting for her (Emma), came forward with open arms and said to her (Emma) with tears in his (Charles) voice--

``Ah! my dear!'' (her)

And he (Charles) bent over her (Emma) gently to kiss her (Emma). But at the contact of his (Charles) lips the memory of the other seized her (Emma), and she (Emma) passed her (Emma) hand over her (Emma) face shuddering.

But she (Emma) made answer,

``Yes, I know, I know!'' (she)

He (Charles) showed her (Emma) the letter in which his (Charles) mother told the event without any sentimental hypocrisy. She (Emma) only regretted her (Emma) husband had not received the consolations of religion, as he (husband) had died at Daudeville, in the street, at the door of a cafe after a patriotic dinner with some ex-officers.

Emma gave him (husband) back the letter; then at dinner, for appearance's sake, she (Emma) affected a certain repugnance. But as he (husband) urged her (Emma) to try, she (Emma) resolutely began eating, while Charles opposite her (Emma) sat motionless in a dejected attitude.

Now and then he (Charles) raised his (Charles) head and gave her (Emma) a long look full of distress. Once he (Charles) sighed,

``I should have liked to see him (man) again!'' (he)

She (Emma) was silent. At last, understanding that she (Emma) must say something,

``How old was your father?'' (she)
she (Emma) asked.

``Fifty-eight.'' (unknown)

``Ah!'' (unknown)

And that was all.

A quarter of an hour after he (Charles) added,

``My poor mother! what will become of her (mother) now?'' (he)

She (Emma) made a gesture that signified she (Emma) did not know. Seeing her (Emma) so taciturn, Charles imagined her (Emma) much affected, and forced himself to say nothing, not to reawaken this sorrow which moved him (Charles). And, shaking off his (Charles) own--

``Did you enjoy yourself yesterday?'' (he)
he (Charles) asked.

``Yes.'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)

When the cloth was removed, Bovary did not rise, nor did Emma; and as she (Emma) looked at him (Charles), the monotony of the spectacle drove little by little all pity from her (Emma) heart. He (Charles) seemed to her (Emma) paltry, weak, a cipher--in a word, a poor thing in every way. How to get rid of him (Charles)? What an interminable evening! Something stupefying like the fumes of opium seized her (Emma).

They heard in the passage the sharp noise of a wooden leg on the boards. It was Hippolyte bringing back Emma's luggage. In order to put it down he (Charles) described painfully a quarter of a circle with his (Charles) stump.

``He (father) doesn't even remember any more about it,'' (she)
she (Emma) thought, looking at the poor devil, whose coarse red hair was wet with perspiration.

Bovary was searching at the bottom of his (devil) purse for a centime, and without appearing to understand all there was of humiliation for him (devil) in the mere presence of this man, who stood there like a personified reproach to his (man) incurable incapacity.

``Hallo! you've a pretty bouquet,'' (he)
he (man) said, noticing Leon's violets on the chimney.

``Yes,'' (she)
she (Emma) replied indifferently;
``it's a bouquet I bought just now from a beggar.'' (she)

Charles picked up the flowers, and freshening his (Charles) eyes, red with tears, against them, smelt them delicately.

She (Emma) took them quickly from his (Charles) hand and put them in a glass of water.

The next day Madame Bovary senior arrived. She (Emma) and her (Emma) son wept much. Emma, on the pretext of giving orders, disappeared. The following day they had a talk over the mourning. They went and sat down with their workboxes by the waterside under the arbour.

Charles was thinking of his (Charles) father, and was surprised to feel so much affection for this man, whom till then he (man) had thought he (man) cared little about. Madame Bovary senior was thinking of her (Emma) husband. The worst days of the past seemed enviable to her (Emma). All was forgotten beneath the instinctive regret of such a long habit, and from time to time whilst she (Emma) sewed, a big tear rolled along her (Emma) nose and hung suspended there a moment. Emma was thinking that it was scarcely forty-eight hours since they had been together, far from the world, all in a frenzy of joy, and not having eyes enough to gaze upon each other. She (Emma) tried to recall the slightest details of that past day. But the presence of her (Emma) husband and mother-in-law worried her (Emma). She (Emma) would have liked to hear nothing, to see nothing, so as not to disturb the meditation on her (Emma) love, that, do what she (Emma) would, became lost in external sensations.

She (Emma) was unpicking the lining of a dress, and the strips were scattered around her (Emma). Madame Bovary senior was plying her (Emma) scissor without looking up, and Charles, in his (Charles) list slippers and his (Charles) old brown surtout that he (Charles) used as a dressing-gown, sat with both hands in his (Charles) pockets, and did not speak either; near them Berthe, in a little white pinafore, was raking sand in the walks with her (Emma) spade. Suddenly she (Emma) saw Monsieur Lheureux, the linendraper, come in through the gate.

He (Charles) came to offer his (Charles) services

``under the sad circumstances.'' (He)
Emma answered that she (Emma) thought she (Emma) could do without. The shopkeeper was not to be beaten.

``I beg your pardon,'' (he)
he (shopkeeper) said,
``but I should like to have a private talk with you.'' (he)
Then in a low voice,
``It's about that affair--you know.'' (Charles)

Charles crimsoned to his (Charles) ears.

``Oh, yes! certainly.'' (wife)
And in his (Charles) confusion, turning to his (Charles) wife,
``Couldn't you, my darling?'' (wife)

She (wife) seemed to understand him (Charles), for she (wife) rose; and Charles said to his (Charles) mother,

``It is nothing particular. No doubt, some household trifle.'' (mother)
He (Charles) did not want her (wife) to know the story of the bill, fearing her (wife) reproaches.

As soon as they were alone, Monsieur Lheureux in sufficiently clear terms began to congratulate Emma on the inheritance, then to talk of indifferent matters, of the espaliers, of the harvest, and of his (Charles) own health, which was always so-so, always having ups and downs. In fact, he (Charles) had to work devilish hard, although he (Charles) didn't make enough, in spite of all people said, to find butter for his (Charles) bread.

Emma let him (Charles) talk on. She (Emma) had bored herself so prodigiously the last two days.

``And so you're quite well again?'' (he)
he (Charles) went on.
``Ma foi! I saw your husband in a sad state. He (husband)'s a good fellow, though we did have a little misunderstanding.'' (She)

She (Emma) asked what misunderstanding, for Charles had said nothing of the dispute about the goods supplied to her (Emma).

``Why, you know well enough,'' (Lheureux/Monsieur Lheureux)
cried Lheureux.
``It was about your little fancies--the travelling trunks.'' (He)

He (Charles) had drawn his (Charles) hat over his (Charles) eyes, and, with his (Charles) hands behind his (Charles) back, smiling and whistling, he (Charles) looked straight at her (Emma) in an unbearable manner. Did he (Charles) suspect anything?

She (Emma) was lost in all kinds of apprehensions. At last, however, he (Charles) went on--

``We made it up, all the same, and I've come again to propose another arrangement.'' (he)

This was to renew the bill Bovary had signed. The doctor, of course, would do as he (doctor) pleased; he (doctor) was not to trouble himself, especially just now, when he (doctor) would have a lot of worry.

``And he (husband) would do better to give it over to someone else--to you, for example. With a power of attorney it could be easily managed, and then we -LRB-you and I-RRB- would have our little business transactions together.'' (She)

She (Emma) did not understand. He (doctor) was silent. Then, passing to his (doctor) trade, Lheureux declared that madame must require something. He (doctor) would send her (Emma) a black barege, twelve yards, just enough to make a gown.

``The one you've on is good enough for the house, but you want another for calls. I saw that the very moment that I came in. I've the eye of an American!'' (He)

He (doctor) did not send the stuff; he (doctor) brought it. Then he (doctor) came again to measure it; he (doctor) came again on other pretexts, always trying to make himself agreeable, useful,

``enfeoffing himself,'' (he)
as Homais would have said, and always dropping some hint to Emma about the power of attorney. He (attorney) never mentioned the bill; she (Emma) did not think of it. Charles, at the beginning of her (Emma) convalescence, had certainly said something about it to her (Emma), but so many emotions had passed through her (Emma) head that she (Emma) no longer remembered it. Besides, she (Emma) took care not to talk of any money questions. Madame Bovary seemed surprised at this, and attributed the change in her (Emma) ways to the religious sentiments she (Emma) had contracted during her (Emma) illness.

But as soon as she (Emma) was gone, Emma greatly astounded Bovary by her (Emma) practical good sense. It would be necessary to make inquiries, to look into mortgages, and see if there were any occasion for a sale by auction or a liquidation. She (Emma) quoted technical terms casually, pronounced the grand words of order, the future, foresight, and constantly exaggerated the difficulties of settling his (Emma) father's affairs so much, that at last one day she (Emma) showed him (Emma) the rough draft of a power of attorney to manage and administer his (attorney) business, arrange all loans, sign and endorse all bills, pay all sums, etc.. She (Emma) had profited by Lheureux's lessons. Charles naively asked her (Emma) where this paper came from.

``Monsieur Guillaumin'' (she)
; and with the utmost coolness she (Emma) added,
``I don't trust him (attorney) overmuch. Notaries have such a bad reputation. Perhaps we ought to consult--we only know--no one.'' (she)

``Unless Leon--'' (Charles)
replied Charles, who was reflecting. But it was difficult to explain matters by letter. Then she (Emma) offered to make the journey, but he (Charles) thanked her (Emma). She (Emma) insisted. It was quite a contest of mutual consideration. At last she (Emma) cried with affected waywardness--

``No, I will go!'' (she)

``How good you are!'' (he)
he (Charles) said, kissing her (Emma) forehead.

The next morning she (Emma) set out in the

``Hirondelle'' (she)
to go to Rouen to consult Monsieur Leon, and she (Emma) stayed there three days.

Chapter Three

They were three full, exquisite days--a true honeymoon. They were at the Hotel-de-Boulogne, on the harbour; and they lived there, with drawn blinds and closed doors, with flowers on the floor, and iced syrups were brought them early in the morning.

Towards evening they took a covered boat and went to dine on one of the islands. It was the time when one hears by the side of the dockyard the caulking-mallets sounding against the hull of vessels. The smoke of the tar rose up between the trees; there were large fatty drops on the water, undulating in the purple colour of the sun, like floating plaques of Florentine bronze.

They rowed down in the midst of moored boats, whose long oblique cables grazed lightly against the bottom of the boat. The din of the town gradually grew distant; the rolling of carriages, the tumult of voices, the yelping of dogs on the decks of vessels. She (Florentine) took off her (Florentine) bonnet, and they landed on their island.

They sat down in the low-ceilinged room of a tavern, at whose door hung black nets. They ate fried smelts, cream and cherries. They lay down upon the grass; they kissed behind the poplars; and they would fain, like two Robinsons, have lived for ever in this little place, which seemed to them in their beatitude the most magnificent on earth. It was not the first time that they had seen trees, a blue sky, meadows; that they had heard the water flowing and the wind blowing in the leaves; but, no doubt, they had never admired all this, as if Nature had not existed before, or had only begun to be beautiful since the gratification of their desires.

At night they returned. The boat glided along the shores of the islands. They sat at the bottom, both hidden by the shade, in silence. The square oars rang in the iron thwarts, and, in the stillness, seemed to mark time, like the beating of a metronome, while at the stern the rudder that trailed behind never ceased its gentle splash against the water.

Once the moon rose; they did not fail to make fine phrases, finding the orb melancholy and full of poetry. She (their) even began to sing--

``One night, do you remember, we were sailing,'' (She)
etc..

Her (their) musical but weak voice died away along the waves, and the winds carried off the trills that Leon heard pass like the flapping of wings about him (Leon).

She (their) was opposite him (Leon), leaning against the partition of the shallop, through one of whose raised blinds the moon streamed in. Her (their) black dress, whose drapery spread out like a fan, made her (their) seem more slender, taller. Her (their) head was raised, her (their) hands clasped, her (their) eyes turned towards heaven. At times the shadow of the willows hid her (their) completely; then she (their) reappeared suddenly, like a vision in the moonlight.

Leon, on the floor by her (their) side, found under his (Leon) hand a ribbon of scarlet silk. The boatman looked at it, and at last said--

``Perhaps it belongs to the party I took out the other day. A lot of jolly folk, gentlemen and ladies, with cakes, champagne, cornets--everything in style! There was one especially, a tall handsome man with small moustaches, who was that funny! And they all kept saying, `Now tell us something, Adolphe--Dolpe,' I think.'' (The boatman)

She (their) shivered.

``You are in pain?'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
asked Leon, coming closer to her (their).

``Oh, it's nothing! No doubt, it is only the night air.'' (unknown)

``And who doesn't want for women, either,'' (the sailor)
softly added the sailor, thinking he (sailor) was paying the stranger a compliment.

Then, spitting on his (sailor) hands, he (sailor) took the oars again.

Yet they had to part. The adieux were sad. He (sailor) was to send his (sailor) letters to Mere Rollet, and she (their) gave him (sailor) such precise instructions about a double envelope that he (sailor) admired greatly her (their) amorous astuteness.

``So you can assure me it is all right?'' (she)
she (their) said with her (their) last kiss.

``Yes, certainly.'' (unknown)

``But why,'' (he)
he (sailor) thought afterwards as he (sailor) came back through the streets alone,
``is she (it) so very anxious to get this power of attorney?'' (he)

Chapter Four

Leon soon put on an air of superiority before his (Leon) comrades, avoided their company, and completely neglected his (Leon) work.

He (Leon) waited for her (their) letters; he (Leon) re-read them; he (Leon) wrote to her (their). He (Leon) called her (their) to mind with all the strength of his (Leon) desires and of his (Leon) memories. Instead of lessening with absence, this longing to see her (their) again grew, so that at last on Saturday morning he (Leon) escaped from his (Leon) office.

When, from the summit of the hill, he (Leon) saw in the valley below the church-spire with its tin flag swinging in the wind, he (Leon) felt that delight mingled with triumphant vanity and egoistic tenderness that millionaires must experience when they come back to their native village.

He (Leon) went rambling round her (their) house. A light was burning in the kitchen. He (Leon) watched for her (their) shadow behind the curtains, but nothing appeared.

Mere Lefrancois, when she (their) saw him (Lefrancois), uttered many exclamations. She (their) thought he (Lefrancois)

``had grown and was thinner,'' (he)
while Artemise, on the contrary, thought him (Lefrancois) stouter and darker.

He (Lefrancois) dined in the little room as of yore, but alone, without the tax-gatherer; for Binet, tired of waiting for the

``Hirondelle,'' (Binet/Monsieur Binet)
had definitely put forward his (Lefrancois) meal one hour, and now he (Lefrancois) dined punctually at five, and yet he (Lefrancois) declared usually the rickety old concern
``was late.'' (he)

Leon, however, made up his (Leon) mind, and knocked at the doctor's door. Madame was in her (their) room, and did not come down for a quarter of an hour. The doctor seemed delighted to see him (doctor), but he (doctor) never stirred out that evening, nor all the next day.

He (doctor) saw her (their) alone in the evening, very late, behind the garden in the lane; in the lane, as she (their) had the other one! It was a stormy night, and they talked under an umbrella by lightning flashes.

Their separation was becoming intolerable.

``I would rather die!'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma. She (Emma) was writhing in his (doctor) arms, weeping.
``Adieu! adieu! When shall I see you again?'' (she)

They came back again to embrace once more, and it was then that she (Emma) promised him (doctor) to find soon, by no matter what means, a regular opportunity for seeing one another in freedom at least once a week. Emma never doubted she (Emma) should be able to do this. Besides, she (Emma) was full of hope. Some money was coming to her (Emma).

On the strength of it she (Emma) bought a pair of yellow curtains with large stripes for her (Emma) room, whose cheapness Monsieur Lheureux had commended; she (Emma) dreamed of getting a carpet, and Lheureux, declaring that it wasn't

``drinking the sea,'' (Lheureux/Monsieur Lheureux)
politely undertook to supply her (Emma) with one. She (Emma) could no longer do without his (Emma) services. Twenty times a day she (Emma) sent for him (Emma), and he (Emma) at once put by his (Emma) business without a murmur. People could not understand either why Mere Rollet breakfasted with her (Emma) every day, and even paid her (Emma) private visits.

It was about this time, that is to say, the beginning of winter, that she (Emma) seemed seized with great musical fervour.

One evening when Charles was listening to her (Emma), she (Emma) began the same piece four times over, each time with much vexation, while he (Charles), not noticing any difference, cried--

``Bravo! very goodl You are wrong to stop. Go on!'' (he)

``Oh, no; it is execrable! My fingers are quite rusty.'' (he)

The next day he (Charles) begged her (Emma) to play him (Charles) something again.

``Very well; to please you!'' (Charles)

And Charles confessed she (Emma) had gone off a little. She (Emma) played wrong notes and blundered; then, stopping short--

``Ah! it is no use. I ought to take some lessons; but--'' (She)
She (Emma) bit her (Emma) lips and added,
``Twenty francs a lesson, that's too dear!'' (She)

``Yes, so it is--rather,'' (Charles)
said Charles, giggling stupidly.
``But it seems to me that one might be able to do it for less; for there are artists of no reputation, and who are often better than the celebrities.'' (unknown)

``Find them!'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma.

The next day when he (Charles) came home he (Charles) looked at her (Emma) shyly, and at last could no longer keep back the words.

``How obstinate you are sometimes! I went to Barfucheres to-day. Well, Madame Liegard assured me that her (it) three young ladies who are at La Misericorde have lessons at fifty sous apiece, and that from an excellent mistress!'' (She)

She (Emma) shrugged her (Emma) shoulders and did not open her (Emma) piano again. But when she (Emma) passed by it -LRB-if Bovary were there-RRB-, she (Emma) sighed--

``Ah! my poor piano!'' (she)

And when anyone came to see her (Emma), she (Emma) did not fail to inform them she (Emma) had given up music, and could not begin again now for important reasons. Then people commiserated her (Emma)--

``What a pity! she (mistress) had so much talent!'' (people)

They even spoke to Bovary about it. They put him (Charles) to shame, and especially the chemist.

``You are wrong. One should never let any of the faculties of nature lie fallow. Besides, just think, my good friend, that by inducing madame to study; you are economising on the subsequent musical education of your child. For my own part, I think that mothers ought themselves to instruct their children. That is an idea of Rousseau's, still rather new perhaps, but that will end by triumphing, I am certain of it, like mothers nursing their own children and vaccination.'' (Charles)

So Charles returned once more to this question of the piano. Emma replied bitterly that it would be better to sell it. This poor piano, that had given her (Emma) vanity so much satisfaction--to see it go was to Bovary like the indefinable suicide of a part of herself.

``If you liked,'' (he)
he (Charles) said,
``a lesson from time to time, that wouldn't after all be very ruinous.'' (he)

``But lessons,'' (she)
she (Emma) replied,
``are only of use when followed up.'' (she)

And thus it was she (Emma) set about obtaining her (Emma) husband's permission to go to town once a week to see her (Emma) lover. At the end of a month she (Emma) was even considered to have made considerable progress.

Chapter Five

She (Emma) went on Thursdays. She (Emma) got up and dressed silently, in order not to awaken Charles, who would have made remarks about her (Emma) getting ready too early. Next she (Emma) walked up and down, went to the windows, and looked out at the Place. The early dawn was broadening between the pillars of the market, and the chemist's shop, with the shutters still up, showed in the pale light of the dawn the large letters of his (chemist) signboard.

When the clock pointed to a quarter past seven, she (Emma) went off to the

``Lion d’Or,'' (she)
whose door Artemise opened yawning. The girl then made up the coals covered by the cinders, and Emma remained alone in the kitchen. Now and again she (Emma) went out.
