Hivert was leisurely harnessing his (chemist) horses, listening, moreover, to Mere Lefrancois, who, passing her (Emma) head and nightcap through a grating, was charging him (Lefrancois) with commissions and giving him (Lefrancois) explanations that would have confused anyone else. Emma kept beating the soles of her (Emma) boots against the pavement of the yard.

At last, when he (Lefrancois) had eaten his (Lefrancois) soup, put on his (Lefrancois) cloak, lighted his (Lefrancois) pipe, and grasped his (Lefrancois) whip, he (Lefrancois) calmly installed himself on his (Lefrancois) seat.

The

``Hirondelle'' (passengers)
started at a slow trot, and for about a mile stopped here and there to pick up passengers who waited for it, standing at the border of the road, in front of their yard gates.

Those who had secured seats the evening before kept it waiting; some even were still in bed in their houses. Hivert called, shouted, swore; then he (Lefrancois) got down from his (Lefrancois) seat and went and knocked loudly at the doors. The wind blew through the cracked windows.

The four seats, however, filled up. The carriage rolled off; rows of apple-trees followed one upon another, and the road between its two long ditches, full of yellow water, rose, constantly narrowing towards the horizon.

Emma knew it from end to end; she (Emma) knew that after a meadow there was a sign-post, next an elm, a barn, or the hut of a lime-kiln tender. Sometimes even, in the hope of getting some surprise, she (Emma) shut her (Emma) eyes, but she (Emma) never lost the clear perception of the distance to be traversed.

At last the brick houses began to follow one another more closely, the earth resounded beneath the wheels, the

``Hirondelle'' (unknown)
glided between the gardens, where through an opening one saw statues, a periwinkle plant, clipped yews, and a swing. Then on a sudden the town appeared. Sloping down like an amphitheatre, and drowned in the fog, it widened out beyond the bridges confusedly. Then the open country spread away with a monotonous movement till it touched in the distance the vague line of the pale sky. Seen thus from above, the whole landscape looked immovable as a picture; the anchored ships were massed in one corner, the river curved round the foot of the green hills, and the isles, oblique in shape, lay on the water, like large, motionless, black fishes. The factory chimneys belched forth immense brown fumes that were blown away at the top. One heard the rumbling of the foundries, together with the clear chimes of the churches that stood out in the mist. The leafless trees on the boulevards made violet thickets in the midst of the houses, and the roofs, all shining with the rain, threw back unequal reflections, according to the height of the quarters in which they were. Sometimes a gust of wind drove the clouds towards the Saint Catherine hills, like aerial waves that broke silently against a cliff.

A giddiness seemed to her (Catherine) to detach itself from this mass of existence, and her (Catherine) heart swelled as if the hundred and twenty thousand souls that palpitated there had all at once sent into it the vapour of the passions she (Catherine) fancied theirs. Her (Catherine) love grew in the presence of this vastness, and expanded with tumult to the vague murmurings that rose towards her (Catherine). She (Catherine) poured it out upon the square, on the walks, on the streets, and the old Norman city outspread before her (Catherine) eyes as an enormous capital, as a Babylon into which she (Catherine) was entering. She (Catherine) leant with both hands against the window, drinking in the breeze; the three horses galloped, the stones grated in the mud, the diligence rocked, and Hivert, from afar, hailed the carts on the road, while the bourgeois who had spent the night at the Guillaume woods came quietly down the hill in their little family carriages.

They stopped at the barrier; Emma undid her (Emma) overshoes, put on other gloves, rearranged her (Emma) shawl, and some twenty paces farther she (Emma) got down from the

``Hirondelle.'' (she)

The town was then awakening. Shop-boys in caps were cleaning up the shop-fronts, and women with baskets against their hips, at intervals uttered sonorous cries at the corners of streets. She (Emma) walked with downcast eyes, close to the walls, and smiling with pleasure under her (Emma) lowered black veil.

For fear of being seen, she (Emma) did not usually take the most direct road. She (Emma) plunged into dark alleys, and, all perspiring, reached the bottom of the Rue Nationale, near the fountain that stands there. It is the quarter for theatres, public-houses, and whores. Often a cart would pass near her (Emma), bearing some shaking scenery. Waiters in aprons were sprinkling sand on the flagstones between green shrubs. It all smelt of absinthe, cigars, and oysters.

She (Emma) turned down a street; she (Emma) recognised him (Emma) by his (Emma) curling hair that escaped from beneath his (Emma) hat.

Leon walked along the pavement. She (Emma) followed him (Leon) to the hotel. He (Leon) went up, opened the door, entered--What an embrace!

Then, after the kisses, the words gushed forth. They told each other the sorrows of the week, the presentiments, the anxiety for the letters; but now everything was forgotten; they gazed into each other's faces with voluptuous laughs, and tender names.

The bed was large, of mahogany, in the shape of a boat. The curtains were in red levantine, that hung from the ceiling and bulged out too much towards the bell-shaped bedside; and nothing in the world was so lovely as her (they) brown head and white skin standing out against this purple colour, when, with a movement of shame, she (they) crossed her (they) bare arms, hiding her (they) face in her (they) hands.

The warm room, with its discreet carpet, its gay ornaments, and its calm light, seemed made for the intimacies of passion. The curtain-rods, ending in arrows, their brass pegs, and the great balls of the fire-dogs shone suddenly when the sun came in. On the chimney between the candelabra there were two of those pink shells in which one hears the murmur of the sea if one holds them to the ear.

How they loved that dear room, so full of gaiety, despite its rather faded splendour! They always found the furniture in the same place, and sometimes hairpins, that she (They) had forgotten the Thursday before, under the pedestal of the clock. They lunched by the fireside on a little round table, inlaid with rosewood. Emma carved, put bits on his (They) plate with all sorts of coquettish ways, and she (Emma) laughed with a sonorous and libertine laugh when the froth of the champagne ran over from the glass to the rings on her (Emma) fingers. They were so completely lost in the possession of each other that they thought themselves in their own house, and that they would live there till death, like two spouses eternally young. They said

``our room,'' (she)
``our carpet,'' (she)
she (Emma) even said
``my slippers,'' (she)
a gift of Leon's, a whim she (Emma) had had. They were pink satin, bordered with swansdown. When she (Emma) sat on his (Leon) knees, her (Emma) leg, then too short, hung in the air, and the dainty shoe, that had no back to it, was held only by the toes to her (Emma) bare foot.

He (Leon) for the first time enjoyed the inexpressible delicacy of feminine refinements. He (Leon) had never met this grace of language, this reserve of clothing, these poses of the weary dove. He (Leon) admired the exaltation of her (Emma) soul and the lace on her (Emma) petticoat. Besides, was she (Emma) not

``a lady'' (she)
and a married woman--a real mistress, in fine?

By the diversity of her (Emma) humour, in turn mystical or mirthful, talkative, taciturn, passionate, careless, she (Emma) awakened in him (Leon) a thousand desires, called up instincts or memories. She (Emma) was the mistress of all the novels, the heroine of all the dramas, the vague

``she (lady)'' (the heroine)
of all the volumes of verse. He (Leon) found again on her (Emma) shoulder the amber colouring of the
``Odalisque Bathing'' (He)
; she (Emma) had the long waist of feudal chatelaines, and she (Emma) resembled the
``Pale Woman of Barcelona.'' (she)
But above all she (Emma) was the Angel!

Often looking at her (Emma), it seemed to him (Angel) that his (Angel) soul, escaping towards her (Emma), spread like a wave about the outline of her (Emma) head, and descended drawn down into the whiteness of her (Emma) breast. He (Angel) knelt on the ground before her (Emma), and with both elbows on her (Emma) knees looked at her (Emma) with a smile, his (Angel) face upturned.

She (Emma) bent over him (Angel), and murmured, as if choking with intoxication--

``Oh, do not move! do not speak! look at me! Something so sweet comes from your eyes that helps me so much!'' (him)

She (Emma) called him (Angel)

``child.'' (him)
``Child, do you love me?'' (she)

And she (Emma) did not listen for his (Angel) answer in the haste of her (Emma) lips that fastened to his (Angel) mouth.

On the clock there was a bronze cupid, who smirked as he (cupid) bent his (cupid) arm beneath a golden garland. They had laughed at it many a time, but when they had to part everything seemed serious to them.

Motionless in front of each other, they kept repeating,

``Till Thursday, till Thursday.'' (she)

Suddenly she (Emma) seized his (cupid) head between her (Emma) hands, kissed him (cupid) hurriedly on the forehead, crying,

``Adieu!'' (him)
and rushed down the stairs.

She (Emma) went to a hairdresser's in the Rue de la Comedie to have her (Emma) hair arranged. Night fell; the gas was lighted in the shop. She (Emma) heard the bell at the theatre calling the mummers to the performance, and she (Emma) saw, passing opposite, men with white faces and women in faded gowns going in at the stage-door.

It was hot in the room, small, and too low where the stove was hissing in the midst of wigs and pomades. The smell of the tongs, together with the greasy hands that handled her (Emma) head, soon stunned her (Emma), and she (Emma) dozed a little in her (Emma) wrapper. Often, as he (men) did her (Emma) hair, the man offered her (Emma) tickets for a masked ball.

Then she (Emma) went away. She (Emma) went up the streets; reached the Croix-Rouge, put on her (Emma) overshoes, that she (Emma) had hidden in the morning under the seat, and sank into her (Emma) place among the impatient passengers. Some got out at the foot of the hill. She (Emma) remained alone in the carriage. At every turning all the lights of the town were seen more and more completely, making a great luminous vapour about the dim houses. Emma knelt on the cushions and her (Emma) eyes wandered over the dazzling light. She (Emma) sobbed; called on Leon, sent him (Leon) tender words and kisses lost in the wind.

On the hillside a poor devil wandered about with his (devil) stick in the midst of the diligences. A mass of rags covered his (devil) shoulders, and an old staved-in beaver, turned out like a basin, hid his (devil) face; but when he (devil) took it off he (devil) discovered in the place of eyelids empty and bloody orbits. The flesh hung in red shreds, and there flowed from it liquids that congealed into green scale down to the nose, whose black nostrils sniffed convulsively. To speak to you he (devil) threw back his (devil) head with an idiotic laugh; then his (devil) bluish eyeballs, rolling constantly, at the temples beat against the edge of the open wound. He (devil) sang a little song as he (devil) followed the carriages--

``Maids an the warmth of a summer day Dream of love, and of love always'' (he)

And all the rest was about birds and sunshine and green leaves.

Sometimes he (devil) appeared suddenly behind Emma, bareheaded, and she (Emma) drew back with a cry. Hivert made fun of him (devil). He (devil) would advise him (devil) to get a booth at the Saint Romain fair, or else ask him (Saint), laughing, how his (Saint) young woman was.

Often they had started when, with a sudden movement, his (Saint) hat entered the diligence through the small window, while he (Saint) clung with his (Saint) other arm to the footboard, between the wheels splashing mud. His (Saint) voice, feeble at first and quavering, grew sharp; it resounded in the night like the indistinct moan of a vague distress; and through the ringing of the bells, the murmur of the trees, and the rumbling of the empty vehicle, it had a far-off sound that disturbed Emma. It went to the bottom of her (Emma) soul, like a whirlwind in an abyss, and carried her (Emma) away into the distances of a boundless melancholy. But Hivert, noticing a weight behind, gave the blind man sharp cuts with his (man) whip. The thong lashed his (man) wounds, and he (man) fell back into the mud with a yell. Then the passengers in the

``Hirondelle'' (the passengers reflection)
ended by falling asleep, some with open mouths, others with lowered chins, leaning against their neighbour's shoulder, or with their arm passed through the strap, oscillating regularly with the jolting of the carriage; and the reflection of the lantern swinging without, on the crupper of the wheeler; penetrating into the interior through the chocolate calico curtains, threw sanguineous shadows over all these motionless people. Emma, drunk with grief, shivered in her (Emma) clothes, feeling her (Emma) feet grow colder and colder, and death in her (Emma) soul.

Charles at home was waiting for her (Emma); the

``Hirondelle'' (Charles)
was always late on Thursdays. Madame arrived at last, and scarcely kissed the child. The dinner was not ready. No matter! She (Emma) excused the servant. This girl now seemed allowed to do just as she (girl) liked.

Often her (girl) husband, noting her (girl) pallor, asked if she (girl) were unwell.

``No,'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma.

``But,'' (he)
he (husband) replied,
``you seem so strange this evening.'' (he)

``Oh, it's nothing! nothing!'' (she)

There were even days when she (Emma) had no sooner come in than she (Emma) went up to her (Emma) room; and Justin, happening to be there, moved about noiselessly, quicker at helping her (Emma) than the best of maids. He (Justin) put the matches ready, the candlestick, a book, arranged her (Emma) nightgown, turned back the bedclothes.

``Come!'' (she)
said she (Emma),
``that will do. Now you can go.'' (she)

For he (Justin) stood there, his (Justin) hands hanging down and his (Justin) eyes wide open, as if enmeshed in the innumerable threads of a sudden reverie.

The following day was frightful, and those that came after still more unbearable, because of her (Emma) impatience to once again seize her (Emma) happiness; an ardent lust, inflamed by the images of past experience, and that burst forth freely on the seventh day beneath Leon's caresses. His (Leon) ardours were hidden beneath outbursts of wonder and gratitude. Emma tasted this love in a discreet, absorbed fashion, maintained it by all the artifices of her (Emma) tenderness, and trembled a little lest it should be lost later on.

She (Emma) often said to him (Leon), with her (Emma) sweet, melancholy voice--

``Ah! you too, you will leave me! You will marry! You will be like all the others.'' (him)

He (Leon) asked,

``What others?'' (He)

``Why, like all men,'' (she)
she (Emma) replied. Then added, repulsing him (Leon) with a languid movement--

``You are all evil!'' (him)

One day, as they were talking philosophically of earthly disillusions, to experiment on his (Leon) jealousy, or yielding, perhaps, to an over-strong need to pour out her (Emma) heart, she (Emma) told him (Leon) that formerly, before him (Leon), she (Emma) had loved someone.

``Not like you,'' (she)
she (Emma) went on quickly, protesting by the head of her (Emma) child that
``nothing had passed between them.'' (child)

The young man believed her (Emma), but none the less questioned her (Emma) to find out what he (man) was.

``He (you) was a ship's captain, my dear.'' (a man)

Was this not preventing any inquiry, and, at the same time, assuming a higher ground through this pretended fascination exercised over a man who must have been of warlike nature and accustomed to receive homage?

The clerk then felt the lowliness of his (man) position; he (man) longed for epaulettes, crosses, titles. All that would please her (clerk)--he (man) gathered that from her (clerk) spendthrift habits.

Emma nevertheless concealed many of these extravagant fancies, such as her (Emma) wish to have a blue tilbury to drive into Rouen, drawn by an English horse and driven by a groom in top-boots. It was Justin who had inspired her (Emma) with this whim, by begging her (Emma) to take him (Justin) into her (Emma) service as valet-de-chambre*, and if the privation of it did not lessen the pleasure of her (Emma) arrival at each rendezvous, it certainly augmented the bitterness of the return.

* Manservant.

Often, when they talked together of Paris, she (Emma) ended by murmuring,

``Ah! how happy we should be there!'' (she)

``Are we not happy?'' (the man)
gently answered the young man passing his (man) hands over her (Emma) hair.

``Yes, that is true,'' (she)
she (Emma) said.
``I am mad. Kiss me!'' (husband)

To her (Emma) husband she (Emma) was more charming than ever. She (Emma) made him (man) pistachio-creams, and played him (man) waltzes after dinner. So he (man) thought himself the most fortunate of men and Emma was without uneasiness, when, one evening suddenly he (man) said--

``It is Mademoiselle Lempereur, isn't it, who gives you lessons?'' (he)

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``Well, I saw her (you) just now,'' (Charles)
Charles went on,
``at Madame Liegeard's. I spoke to her (you) about you, and she (you) doesn't know you.'' (Charles)

This was like a thunderclap. However, she (Emma) replied quite naturally--

``Ah! no doubt she (you) forgot my name.'' (she)

``But perhaps,'' (the doctor)
said the doctor,
``there are several Demoiselles Lempereur at Rouen who are music-mistresses.'' (the doctor)

``Possibly!'' (unknown)
Then quickly--
``But I have my receipts here. See!'' (she)

And she (Emma) went to the writing-table, ransacked all the drawers, rummaged the papers, and at last lost her (Emma) head so completely that Charles earnestly begged her (Emma) not to take so much trouble about those wretched receipts.

``Oh, I will find them,'' (she)
she (Emma) said.

And, in fact, on the following Friday, as Charles was putting on one of his (Charles) boots in the dark cabinet where his (Charles) clothes were kept, he (Charles) felt a piece of paper between the leather and his (Charles) sock. He (Charles) took it out and read--

``Received, for three months' lessons and several pieces of music, the sum of sixty-three francs.--Felicie Lempereur, professor of music.'' (He)

``How the devil did it get into my boots?'' (unknown)

``It must,'' (she)
she (Emma) replied,
``have fallen from the old box of bills that is on the edge of the shelf.'' (she)

From that moment her (Emma) existence was but one long tissue of lies, in which she (Emma) enveloped her (Emma) love as in veils to hide it. It was a want, a mania, a pleasure carried to such an extent that if she (Emma) said she (Emma) had the day before walked on the right side of a road, one might know she (Emma) had taken the left.

One morning, when she (Emma) had gone, as usual, rather lightly clothed, it suddenly began to snow, and as Charles was watching the weather from the window, he (Charles) caught sight of Monsieur Bournisien in the chaise of Monsieur Tuvache, who was driving him (Charles) to Rouen. Then he (Charles) went down to give the priest a thick shawl that he (Charles) was to hand over to Emma as soon as he (Charles) reached the

``Croix-Rouge.'' (he)
When he (Charles) got to the inn, Monsieur Bournisien asked for the wife of the Yonville doctor. The landlady replied that she (landlady) very rarely came to her (landlady) establishment. So that evening, when he (doctor) recognised Madame Bovary in the
``Hirondelle,'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)
the cure told her (landlady) his (doctor) dilemma, without, however, appearing to attach much importance to it, for he (doctor) began praising a preacher who was doing wonders at the Cathedral, and whom all the ladies were rushing to hear.

Still, if he (doctor) did not ask for any explanation, others, later on, might prove less discreet. So she (landlady) thought well to get down each time at the

``Croix-Rouge,'' (she)
so that the good folk of her (landlady) village who saw her (landlady) on the stairs should suspect nothing.

One day, however, Monsieur Lheureux met her (landlady) coming out of the Hotel de Boulogne on Leon's arm; and she (landlady) was frightened, thinking he (Leon) would gossip. He (Leon) was not such a fool. But three days after he (Leon) came to her (landlady) room, shut the door, and said,

``I must have some money.'' (he)

She (landlady) declared she (landlady) could not give him (Leon) any. Lheureux burst into lamentations and reminded her (landlady) of all the kindnesses he (Leon) had shown her (landlady).

In fact, of the two bills signed by Charles, Emma up to the present had paid only one. As to the second, the shopkeeper, at her (Emma) request, had consented to replace it by another, which again had been renewed for a long date. Then he (shopkeeper) drew from his (shopkeeper) pocket a list of goods not paid for; to wit, the curtains, the carpet, the material for the armchairs, several dresses, and divers articles of dress, the bills for which amounted to about two thousand francs.

She (Emma) bowed her (Emma) head. He (shopkeeper) went on--

``But if you haven't any ready money, you have an estate.'' (He)
And he (shopkeeper) reminded her (Emma) of a miserable little hovel situated at Barneville, near Aumale, that brought in almost nothing. It had formerly been part of a small farm sold by Monsieur Bovary senior; for Lheureux knew everything, even to the number of acres and the names of the neighbours.

``If I were in your place,'' (he)
he (shopkeeper) said,
``I should clear myself of my debts, and have money left over.'' (he)

She (Emma) pointed out the difficulty of getting a purchaser. He (shopkeeper) held out the hope of finding one; but she (Emma) asked him (shopkeeper) how she (Emma) should manage to sell it.

``Haven't you your power of attorney?'' (he)
he (shopkeeper) replied.

The phrase came to her (Emma) like a breath of fresh air.

``Leave me the bill,'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma.

``Oh, it isn't worth while,'' (Lheureux/Monsieur Lheureux)
answered Lheureux.

He (shopkeeper) came back the following week and boasted of having, after much trouble, at last discovered a certain Langlois, who, for a long time, had had an eye on the property, but without mentioning his (Langlois) price.

``Never mind the price!'' (she)
she (Emma) cried.

But they would, on the contrary, have to wait, to sound the fellow. The thing was worth a journey, and, as she (Emma) could not undertake it, he (fellow) offered to go to the place to have an interview with Langlois. On his (Langlois) return he (Langlois) announced that the purchaser proposed four thousand francs.

Emma was radiant at this news.

``Frankly,'' (he)
he (Langlois) added,
``that's a good price.'' (he)

She (Emma) drew half the sum at once, and when she (Emma) was about to pay her (Emma) account the shopkeeper said--

``It really grieves me, on my word! to see you depriving yourself all at once of such a big sum as that.'' (the shopkeeper)

Then she (Emma) looked at the bank-notes, and dreaming of the unlimited number of rendezvous represented by those two thousand francs, she (Emma) stammered--

``What! what!'' (she)

``Oh!'' (he)
he (shopkeeper) went on, laughing good-naturedly,
``one puts anything one likes on receipts. Don't you think I know what household affairs are?'' (he)
And he (shopkeeper) looked at her (Emma) fixedly, while in his (shopkeeper) hand he (shopkeeper) held two long papers that he (shopkeeper) slid between his (shopkeeper) nails. At last, opening his (shopkeeper) pocket-book, he (shopkeeper) spread out on the table four bills to order, each for a thousand francs.

``Sign these,'' (he)
he (shopkeeper) said,
``and keep it all!'' (he)

She (Emma) cried out, scandalised.

``But if I give you the surplus,'' (Lheureux/Monsieur Lheureux)
replied Monsieur Lheureux impudently,
``is that not helping you?'' (Lheureux/Monsieur Lheureux)

And taking a pen he (shopkeeper) wrote at the bottom of the account,

``Received of Madame Bovary four thousand francs.'' (he)

``Now who can trouble you, since in six months you'll draw the arrears for your cottage, and I don't make the last bill due till after you've been paid?'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

Emma grew rather confused in her (Emma) calculations, and her (Emma) ears tingled as if gold pieces, bursting from their bags, rang all round her (Emma) on the floor. At last Lheureux explained that he (shopkeeper) had a very good friend, Vincart, a broker at Rouen, who would discount these four bills. Then he (shopkeeper) himself would hand over to madame the remainder after the actual debt was paid.

But instead of two thousand francs he (shopkeeper) brought only eighteen hundred, for the friend Vincart -LRB-which was only fair-RRB- had deducted two hundred francs for commission and discount. Then he (shopkeeper) carelessly asked for a receipt.

``You understand--in business--sometimes. And with the date, if you please, with the date.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

A horizon of realisable whims opened out before Emma. She (Emma) was prudent enough to lay by a thousand crowns, with which the first three bills were paid when they fell due; but the fourth, by chance, came to the house on a Thursday, and Charles, quite upset, patiently awaited his (Charles) wife's return for an explanation.

If she (wife) had not told him (Charles) about this bill, it was only to spare him (Charles) such domestic worries; she (wife) sat on his (Charles) knees, caressed him (Charles), cooed to him (Charles), gave him (Charles) a long enumeration of all the indispensable things that had been got on credit.

``Really, you must confess, considering the quantity, it isn't too dear.'' (Charles)

Charles, at his (Charles) wit's end, soon had recourse to the eternal Lheureux, who swore he (Charles) would arrange matters if the doctor would sign him (Charles) two bills, one of which was for seven hundred francs, payable in three months. In order to arrange for this he (Charles) wrote his (Charles) mother a pathetic letter. Instead of sending a reply she (mother) came herself; and when Emma wanted to know whether he (Charles) had got anything out of her (Emma),

``Yes,'' (her)
he (Charles) replied;
``but she (Madame) wants to see the account.'' (he)
The next morning at daybreak Emma ran to Lheureux to beg him (Charles) to make out another account for not more than a thousand francs, for to show the one for four thousand it would be necessary to say that she (Emma) had paid two-thirds, and confess, consequently, the sale of the estate--a negotiation admirably carried out by the shopkeeper, and which, in fact, was only actually known later on.

Despite the low price of each article, Madame Bovary senior, of course, thought the expenditure extravagant.

``Couldn't you do without a carpet? Why have recovered the arm-chairs? In my time there was a single arm-chair in a house, for elderly persons--at any rate it was so at my mother's, who was a good woman, I can tell you. Everybody can't be rich! No fortune can hold out against waste! I should be ashamed to coddle myself as you do! And yet I am old. I need looking after. And there! there! fitting up gowns! fallals! What! silk for lining at two francs, when you can get jaconet for ten sous, or even for eight, that would do well enough!'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

Emma, lying on a lounge, replied as quietly as possible--

``Ah! Madame, enough! enough!'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

The other went on lecturing her (Emma), predicting they would end in the workhouse. But it was Bovary's fault. Luckily he (shopkeeper) had promised to destroy that power of attorney.

``What?'' (unknown)

``Ah! he (you) swore he (you) would,'' (the woman)
went on the good woman.

Emma opened the window, called Charles, and the poor fellow was obliged to confess the promise torn from him (fellow) by his (fellow) mother.

Emma disappeared, then came back quickly, and majestically handed her (Emma) a thick piece of paper.

``Thank you,'' (the woman)
said the old woman. And she (woman) threw the power of attorney into the fire.

Emma began to laugh, a strident, piercing, continuous laugh; she (Emma) had an attack of hysterics.

``Oh, my God!'' (Charles)
cried Charles.
``Ah! you really are wrong! You come here and make scenes with her (I)!'' (mother)

His (Charles) mother, shrugging her (mother) shoulders, declared it was

``all put on.'' (mother)

But Charles, rebelling for the first time, took his (Charles) wife's part, so that Madame Bovary, senior, said she (wife) would leave. She (wife) went the very next day, and on the threshold, as he (Charles) was trying to detain her (wife), she (wife) replied--

``No, no! You love her (I) better than me, and you are right. It is natural. For the rest, so much the worse! You will see. Good day--for I am not likely to come soon again, as you say, to make scenes.'' (she)

Charles nevertheless was very crestfallen before Emma, who did not hide the resentment she (Emma) still felt at his (Charles) want of confidence, and it needed many prayers before she (Emma) would consent to have another power of attorney. He (attorney) even accompanied her (Emma) to Monsieur Guillaumin to have a second one, just like the other, drawn up.

``I understand,'' (unknown)
said the notary;
``a man of science can't be worried with the practical details of life.'' (Charles)

And Charles felt relieved by this comfortable reflection, which gave his (Charles) weakness the flattering appearance of higher pre-occupation.

And what an outburst the next Thursday at the hotel in their room with Leon! She (Emma) laughed, cried, sang, sent for sherbets, wanted to smoke cigarettes, seemed to him (Leon) wild and extravagant, but adorable, superb.

He (Leon) did not know what recreation of her (Emma) whole being drove her (Emma) more and more to plunge into the pleasures of life. She (Emma) was becoming irritable, greedy, voluptuous; and she (Emma) walked about the streets with him (Leon) carrying her (Emma) head high, without fear, so she (Emma) said, of compromising herself. At times, however, Emma shuddered at the sudden thought of meeting Rodolphe, for it seemed to her (Emma) that, although they were separated forever, she (Emma) was not completely free from her (Emma) subjugation to him (Rodolphe).

One night she (Emma) did not return to Yonville at all. Charles lost his (Charles) head with anxiety, and little Berthe would not go to bed without her (Emma) mamma, and sobbed enough to break her (Emma) heart. Justin had gone out searching the road at random. Monsieur Homais even had left his (Justin) pharmacy.

At last, at eleven o’clock, able to bear it no longer, Charles harnessed his (Charles) chaise, jumped in, whipped up his (Charles) horse, and reached the

``Croix-Rouge'' (Charles)
about two o’clock in the morning. No one there! He (Charles) thought that the clerk had perhaps seen her (clerk); but where did he (Charles) live? Happily, Charles remembered his (Charles) employer's address, and rushed off there.

Day was breaking, and he (Charles) could distinguish the escutcheons over the door, and knocked. Someone, without opening the door, shouted out the required information, adding a few insults to those who disturb people in the middle of the night.

The house inhabited by the clerk had neither bell, knocker, nor porter. Charles knocked loudly at the shutters with his (Charles) hands. A policeman happened to pass by. Then he (Charles) was frightened, and went away.

``I am mad,'' (he)
he (Charles) said;
``no doubt they kept her (I) to dinner at Monsieur Lormeaux'.'' (he)
But the Lormeaux no longer lived at Rouen.

``She (I) probably stayed to look after Madame Dubreuil. Why, Madame Dubreuil has been dead these ten months! Where can she (I) be?'' (him)

An idea occurred to him (Charles). At a cafe he (Charles) asked for a Directory, and hurriedly looked for the name of Mademoiselle Lempereur, who lived at No. 74 Rue de la Renelle-des-Maroquiniers.

As he (Charles) was turning into the street, Emma herself appeared at the other end of it. He (Charles) threw himself upon her (Emma) rather than embraced her (Emma), crying--

``What kept you yesterday?'' (her)

``I was not well.'' (unknown)

``What was it? Where? How?'' (She)

She (Emma) passed her (Emma) hand over her (Emma) forehead and answered,

``At Mademoiselle Lempereur's.'' (She)

``I was sure of it! I was going there.'' (unknown)

``Oh, it isn't worth while,'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma.
``She (I) went out just now; but for the future don't worry. I do not feel free, you see, if I know that the least delay upsets you like this.'' (she)

This was a sort of permission that she (Emma) gave herself, so as to get perfect freedom in her (Emma) escapades. And she (Emma) profited by it freely, fully. When she (Emma) was seized with the desire to see Leon, she (Emma) set out upon any pretext; and as he (Leon) was not expecting her (Emma) on that day, she (Emma) went to fetch him (Leon) at his (Leon) office.

It was a great delight at first, but soon he (Leon) no longer concealed the truth, which was, that his (Leon) master complained very much about these interruptions.

``Pshaw! come along,'' (she)
she (Emma) said.

And he (Leon) slipped out.

She (Emma) wanted him (Leon) to dress all in black, and grow a pointed beard, to look like the portraits of Louis XIII. She (Emma) wanted to see his (Louis) lodgings; thought them poor. He (Louis) blushed at them, but she (Emma) did not notice this, then advised him (Louis) to buy some curtains like hers, and as he (Louis) objected to the expense--

``Ah! ah! you care for your money,'' (he)
she (Emma) said laughing.

Each time Leon had to tell her (Emma) everything that he (Leon) had done since their last meeting. She (Emma) asked him (Leon) for some verses--some verses

``for herself,'' (him)
a
``love poem'' (him)
in honour of her (Emma). But he (Leon) never succeeded in getting a rhyme for the second verse; and at last ended by copying a sonnet in a
``Keepsake.'' (he)
This was less from vanity than from the one desire of pleasing her (Emma). He (Leon) did not question her (Emma) ideas; he (Leon) accepted all her (Emma) tastes; he (Leon) was rather becoming her (Emma) mistress than she (Emma) his (Leon). She (Emma) had tender words and kisses that thrilled his (Leon) soul. Where could she (Emma) have learnt this corruption almost incorporeal in the strength of its profanity and dissimulation?

Chapter Six

During the journeys he (Leon) made to see her (Emma), Leon had often dined at the chemist's, and he (Leon) felt obliged from politeness to invite him (Leon) in turn.

``With pleasure!'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
Monsieur Homais replied;
``besides, I must invigorate my mind, for I am getting rusty here. We'll go to the theatre, to the restaurant; we'll make a night of it.'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)

``Oh, my dear!'' (Madame Homais)
tenderly murmured Madame Homais, alarmed at the vague perils he (Leon) was preparing to brave.

``Well, what? Do you think I'm not sufficiently ruining my health living here amid the continual emanations of the pharmacy? But there! that is the way with women! They are jealous of science, and then are opposed to our taking the most legitimate distractions. No matter! Count upon me. One of these days I shall turn up at Rouen, and we'll go the pace together.'' (The druggist)

The druggist would formerly have taken good care not to use such an expression, but he (Leon) was cultivating a gay Parisian style, which he (Leon) thought in the best taste; and, like his (Leon) neighbour, Madame Bovary, he (Leon) questioned the clerk curiously about the customs of the capital; he (Leon) even talked slang to dazzle the bourgeois, saying bender, crummy, dandy, macaroni, the cheese, cut my stick and

``I'll hook it,'' (the bourgeois)
for
``I am going.'' (the bourgeois)

So one Thursday Emma was surprised to meet Monsieur Homais in the kitchen of the

``Lion d’Or,'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
wearing a traveller's costume, that is to say, wrapped in an old cloak which no one knew he (traveller) had, while he (traveller) carried a valise in one hand and the foot-warmer of his (traveller) establishment in the other. He (traveller) had confided his (traveller) intentions to no one, for fear of causing the public anxiety by his (traveller) absence.

The idea of seeing again the place where his (traveller) youth had been spent no doubt excited him (traveller), for during the whole journey he (traveller) never ceased talking, and as soon as he (traveller) had arrived, he (traveller) jumped quickly out of the diligence to go in search of Leon. In vain the clerk tried to get rid of him (Leon). Monsieur Homais dragged him (Leon) off to the large Cafe de la Normandie, which he (Leon) entered majestically, not raising his (Leon) hat, thinking it very provincial to uncover in any public place.

Emma waited for Leon three quarters of an hour. At last she (Emma) ran to his (Leon) office; and, lost in all sorts of conjectures, accusing him (Leon) of indifference, and reproaching herself for her (Emma) weakness, she (Emma) spent the afternoon, her (Emma) face pressed against the window-panes.

At two o’clock they were still at a table opposite each other. The large room was emptying; the stove-pipe, in the shape of a palm-tree, spread its gilt leaves over the white ceiling, and near them, outside the window, in the bright sunshine, a little fountain gurgled in a white basin, where; in the midst of watercress and asparagus, three torpid lobsters stretched across to some quails that lay heaped up in a pile on their sides.

Homais was enjoying himself. Although he (Emma) was even more intoxicated with the luxury than the rich fare, the Pommard wine all the same rather excited his (Emma) faculties; and when the omelette au rhum* appeared, he (Emma) began propounding immoral theories about women. What seduced him (Emma) above all else was chic. He (Emma) admired an elegant toilette in a well-furnished apartment, and as to bodily qualities, he (Emma) didn't dislike a young girl.

* In rum.

Leon watched the clock in despair. The druggist went on drinking, eating, and talking.

``You must be very lonely,'' (he)
he (Leon) said suddenly,
``here at Rouen. To be sure your lady-love doesn't live far away.'' (he)

And the other blushed--

``Come now, be frank. Can you deny that at Yonville--'' (The man)

The young man stammered something.

``At Madame Bovary's, you're not making love to--'' (unknown)

``To whom?'' (unknown)

``The servant!'' (He)

He (man) was not joking; but vanity getting the better of all prudence, Leon, in spite of himself protested. Besides, he (Leon) only liked dark women.

``I approve of that,'' (the chemist)
said the chemist;
``they have more passion.'' (the chemist)

And whispering into his (chemist) friend's ear, he (chemist) pointed out the symptoms by which one could find out if a woman had passion. He (chemist) even launched into an ethnographic digression: the German was vapourish, the French woman licentious, the Italian passionate.

``And negresses?'' (the clerk)
asked the clerk.

``They are an artistic taste!'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
said Homais.
``Waiter! two cups of coffee!'' (unknown)

``Are we going?'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)
at last asked Leon impatiently.

``Ja!'' (he)

But before leaving he (Leon) wanted to see the proprietor of the establishment and made him (Leon) a few compliments. Then the young man, to be alone, alleged he (man) had some business engagement.

``Ah! I will escort you,'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
said Homais.

And all the while he (man) was walking through the streets with him (man) he (man) talked of his (man) wife, his (man) children; of their future, and of his (man) business; told him (man) in what a decayed condition it had formerly been, and to what a degree of perfection he (man) had raised it.

Arrived in front of the Hotel de Boulogne, Leon left him (Leon) abruptly, ran up the stairs, and found his (Leon) mistress in great excitement. At mention of the chemist she (mistress) flew into a passion. He (Leon), however, piled up good reasons; it wasn't his (Leon) fault; didn't she (mistress) know Homais--did she (mistress) believe that he (Leon) would prefer his (Leon) company? But she (mistress) turned away; he (Leon) drew her (mistress) back, and, sinking on his (Leon) knees, clasped her (mistress) waist with his (Leon) arms in a languorous pose, full of concupiscence and supplication.

She (mistress) was standing up, her (mistress) large flashing eyes looked at him (Leon) seriously, almost terribly. Then tears obscured them, her (mistress) red eyelids were lowered, she (mistress) gave him (Leon) her (mistress) hands, and Leon was pressing them to his (Leon) lips when a servant appeared to tell the gentleman that he (Leon) was wanted.

``You will come back?'' (she)
she (mistress) said.

``Yes.'' (unknown)

``But when?'' (unknown)

``Immediately.'' (unknown)

``It's a trick,'' (the chemist)
said the chemist, when he (chemist) saw Leon.
``I wanted to interrupt this visit, that seemed to me to annoy you. Let's go and have a glass of garus at Bridoux'.'' (Leon/Monsieur Leon/Monsieur Leon Dupuis)

Leon vowed that he (Leon) must get back to his (Leon) office. Then the druggist joked him (Leon) about quill-drivers and the law.

``Leave Cujas and Barthole alone a bit. Who the devil prevents you? Be a man! Let's go to Bridoux'. You'll see his (devil) dog. It's very interesting.'' (the clerk)

And as the clerk still insisted--

``I'll go with you. I'll read a paper while I wait for you, or turn over the leaves of a `Code.'''

Leon, bewildered by Emma's anger, Monsieur Homais' chatter, and, perhaps, by the heaviness of the luncheon, was undecided, and, as it were, fascinated by the chemist, who kept repeating--

``Let's go to Bridoux'. It's just by here, in the Rue Malpalu.'' (the chemist)

Then, through cowardice, through stupidity, through that indefinable feeling that drags us into the most distasteful acts, he (Leon) allowed himself to be led off to Bridoux', whom they found in his (Leon) small yard, superintending three workmen, who panted as they turned the large wheel of a machine for making seltzer-water. Homais gave them some good advice. He (Leon) embraced Bridoux; they took some garus. Twenty times Leon tried to escape, but the other seized him (Leon) by the arm saying--

``Presently! I'm coming! We'll go to the `Fanal de Rouen' to see the fellows there. I'll introduce you to Thornassin.'' (him)

At last he (Leon) managed to get rid of him (Leon), and rushed straight to the hotel. Emma was no longer there. She (Emma) had just gone in a fit of anger. She (Emma) detested him (Leon) now. This failing to keep their rendezvous seemed to her (Emma) an insult, and she (Emma) tried to rake up other reasons to separate herself from him (Leon). He (Leon) was incapable of heroism, weak, banal, more spiritless than a woman, avaricious too, and cowardly.

Then, growing calmer, she (woman) at length discovered that she (woman) had, no doubt, calumniated him (Leon). But the disparaging of those we love always alienates us from them to some extent. We must not touch our idols; the gilt sticks to our fingers.

They gradually came to talking more frequently of matters outside their love, and in the letters that Emma wrote him (Leon) she (Emma) spoke of flowers, verses, the moon and the stars, naive resources of a waning passion striving to keep itself alive by all external aids. She (Emma) was constantly promising herself a profound felicity on her (Emma) next journey. Then she (Emma) confessed to herself that she (Emma) felt nothing extraordinary. This disappointment quickly gave way to a new hope, and Emma returned to him (Leon) more inflamed, more eager than ever. She (Emma) undressed brutally, tearing off the thin laces of her (Emma) corset that nestled around her (Emma) hips like a gliding snake. She (Emma) went on tiptoe, barefooted, to see once more that the door was closed, then, pale, serious, and, without speaking, with one movement, she (Emma) threw herself upon his (Leon) breast with a long shudder.

Yet there was upon that brow covered with cold drops, on those quivering lips, in those wild eyes, in the strain of those arms, something vague and dreary that seemed to Leon to glide between them subtly as if to separate them.

He (Leon) did not dare to question her (Emma); but, seeing her (Emma) so skilled, she (Emma) must have passed, he (Leon) thought, through every experience of suffering and of pleasure. What had once charmed now frightened him (Leon) a little. Besides, he (Leon) rebelled against his (Leon) absorption, daily more marked, by her (Emma) personality. He (Leon) begrudged Emma this constant victory. He (Leon) even strove not to love her (Emma); then, when he (Leon) heard the creaking of her (Emma) boots, he (Leon) turned coward, like drunkards at the sight of strong drinks.

She (Emma) did not fail, in truth, to lavish all sorts of attentions upon him (Leon), from the delicacies of food to the coquettries of dress and languishing looks. She (Emma) brought roses to her (Emma) breast from Yonville, which she (Emma) threw into his (Leon) face; was anxious about his (Leon) health, gave him (Leon) advice as to his (Leon) conduct; and, in order the more surely to keep her (Emma) hold on him (Leon), hoping perhaps that heaven would take her (Emma) part, she (Emma) tied a medal of the Virgin round his (Leon) neck. She (Emma) inquired like a virtuous mother about his (Leon) companions. She (Emma) said to him (Leon)--

``Don't see them; don't go out; think only of ourselves; love me!'' (him)

She (Emma) would have liked to be able to watch over his (Leon) life; and the idea occurred to her (Emma) of having him (Leon) followed in the streets. Near the hotel there was always a kind of loafer who accosted travellers, and who would not refuse. But her (Emma) pride revolted at this.

``Bah! so much the worse. Let him (chemist) deceive me! What does it matter to me? As If I cared for him (chemist)!'' (she)

One day, when they had parted early and she (Emma) was returning alone along the boulevard, she (Emma) saw the walls of her (Emma) convent; then she (Emma) sat down on a form in the shade of the elm-trees. How calm that time had been! How she (Emma) longed for the ineffable sentiments of love that she (Emma) had tried to figure to herself out of books! The first month of her (Emma) marriage, her (Emma) rides in the wood, the viscount that waltzed, and Lagardy singing, all repassed before her (Emma) eyes. And Leon suddenly appeared to her (Emma) as far off as the others.

``Yet I love him (chemist),'' (she)
she (Emma) said to herself.

No matter! She (Emma) was not happy--she (Emma) never had been. Whence came this insufficiency in life--this instantaneous turning to decay of everything on which she (Emma) leant? But if there were somewhere a being strong and beautiful, a valiant nature, full at once of exaltation and refinement, a poet's heart in an angel's form, a lyre with sounding chords ringing out elegiac epithalamia to heaven, why, perchance, should she (Emma) not find him (angel)? Ah! how impossible! Besides, nothing was worth the trouble of seeking it; everything was a lie. Every smile hid a yawn of boredom, every joy a curse, all pleasure satiety, and the sweetest kisses left upon your lips only the unattainable desire for a greater delight.

A metallic clang droned through the air, and four strokes were heard from the convent-clock. Four o’clock! And it seemed to her (Emma) that she (Emma) had been there on that form an eternity. But an infinity of passions may be contained in a minute, like a crowd in a small space.

Emma lived all absorbed in hers, and troubled no more about money matters than an archduchess.

Once, however, a wretched-looking man, rubicund and bald, came to her (Emma) house, saying he (man) had been sent by Monsieur Vincart of Rouen. He (man) took out the pins that held together the side-pockets of his (man) long green overcoat, stuck them into his (man) sleeve, and politely handed her (Emma) a paper.

It was a bill for seven hundred francs, signed by her (Emma), and which Lheureux, in spite of all his (man) professions, had paid away to Vincart. She (Emma) sent her (Emma) servant for him (man). He (man) could not come. Then the stranger, who had remained standing, casting right and left curious glances, that his (man) thick, fair eyebrows hid, asked with a naive air--

``What answer am I to take Monsieur Vincart?'' (the stranger)

``Oh,'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)
said Emma,
``tell him (chemist) that I haven't it. I will send next week; he (chemist) must wait; yes, till next week.'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

And the fellow went without another word.

But the next day at twelve o’clock she (Emma) received a summons, and the sight of the stamped paper, on which appeared several times in large letters,

``Maitre Hareng, bailiff at Buchy,'' (she)
so frightened her (Emma) that she (Emma) rushed in hot haste to the linendraper's. She (Emma) found him (fellow) in his (fellow) shop, doing up a parcel.

``Your obedient!'' (he)
he (fellow) said;
``I am at your service.'' (he)

But Lheureux, all the same, went on with his (fellow) work, helped by a young girl of about thirteen, somewhat hunch-backed, who was at once his (fellow) clerk and his (fellow) servant.

Then, his (fellow) clogs clattering on the shop-boards, he (fellow) went up in front of Madame Bovary to the first door, and introduced her (clerk) into a narrow closet, where, in a large bureau in sapon-wood, lay some ledgers, protected by a horizontal padlocked iron bar. Against the wall, under some remnants of calico, one glimpsed a safe, but of such dimensions that it must contain something besides bills and money. Monsieur Lheureux, in fact, went in for pawnbroking, and it was there that he (calico) had put Madame Bovary's gold chain, together with the earrings of poor old Tellier, who, at last forced to sell out, had bought a meagre store of grocery at Quincampoix, where he (Tellier) was dying of catarrh amongst his (Tellier) candles, that were less yellow than his (Tellier) face.

Lheureux sat down in a large cane arm-chair, saying:

``What news?'' (Lheureux/Monsieur Lheureux)

``See!'' (she)

And she (Tellier) showed him (Tellier) the paper.

``Well how can I help it?'' (she)

Then she (Tellier) grew angry, reminding him (Tellier) of the promise he (Tellier) had given not to pay away her (Tellier) bills. He (Tellier) acknowledged it.

``But I was pressed myself; the knife was at my own throat.'' (unknown)

``And what will happen now?'' (she)
she (Tellier) went on.

``Oh, it's very simple; a judgment and then a distraint--that's about it!'' (Emma/Mademoiselle Emma/Mademoiselle)

Emma kept down a desire to strike him (Tellier), and asked gently if there was no way of quieting Monsieur Vincart.

``I dare say! Quiet Vincart! You don't know him (bailiff); he (bailiff)'s more ferocious than an Arab!'' (Lheureux/Monsieur Lheureux)

Still Monsieur Lheureux must interfere.

``Well, listen. It seems to me so far I've been very good to you.'' (unknown)
And opening one of his (Tellier) ledgers,
``See,'' (he)
he (Tellier) said. Then running up the page with his (Tellier) finger,
``Let's see! let's see! August 3d, two hundred francs; June 17th, a hundred and fifty; March 23d, forty-six. In April--'' (He)

He (Tellier) stopped, as if afraid of making some mistake.

``Not to speak of the bills signed by Monsieur Bovary, one for seven hundred francs, and another for three hundred. As to your little installments, with the interest, why, there's no end to `em; one gets quite muddled over `em. I'll have nothing more to do with it.'' (She)

She (Emma) wept; she (Emma) even called him (Tellier)

``her (it) good Monsieur Lheureux.'' (him)
But he (Tellier) always fell back upon
``that rascal Vincart.'' (he)
Besides, he (Tellier) hadn't a brass farthing; no one was paying him (Tellier) now-a-days; they were eating his (Tellier) coat off his (Tellier) back; a poor shopkeeper like him (Tellier) couldn't advance money.

Emma was silent, and Monsieur Lheureux, who was biting the feathers of a quill, no doubt became uneasy at her (Emma) silence, for he (Tellier) went on--

``Unless one of these days I have something coming in, I might--'' (he)

``Besides,'' (he)
said she (Emma),
``as soon as the balance of Barneville--'' (she)

``What!'' (she)

And on hearing that Langlois had not yet paid he (Langlois) seemed much surprised. Then in a honied voice--

``And we agree, you say?'' (unknown)

``Oh! to anything you like.'' (he)

On this he (Langlois) closed his (Langlois) eyes to reflect, wrote down a few figures, and declaring it would be very difficult for him (Langlois), that the affair was shady, and that he (Langlois) was being bled, he (Langlois) wrote out four bills for two hundred and fifty francs each, to fall due month by month.

``Provided that Vincart will listen to me! However, it's settled. I don't play the fool; I'm straight enough.'' (he)

Next he (Langlois) carelessly showed her (Emma) several new goods, not one of which, however, was in his (Langlois) opinion worthy of madame.

``When I think that there's a dress at threepence-halfpenny a yard, and warranted fast colours! And yet they actually swallow it! Of course you understand one doesn't tell them what it really is!'' (He)
He (Langlois) hoped by this confession of dishonesty to others to quite convince her (Emma) of his (Langlois) probity to her (Emma).

Then he (Langlois) called her (Emma) back to show her (Emma) three yards of guipure that he (Langlois) had lately picked up

``at a sale.'' (he)

``Isn't it lovely?'' (Lheureux/Monsieur Lheureux)
said Lheureux.
``It is very much used now for the backs of arm-chairs. It's quite the rage.'' (a juggler)

And, more ready than a juggler, he (juggler) wrapped up the guipure in some blue paper and put it in Emma's hands.

``But at least let me know--'' (he)

``Yes, another time,'' (he)
he (juggler) replied, turning on his (juggler) heel.

That same evening she (Emma) urged Bovary to write to his (juggler) mother, to ask her (Emma) to send as quickly as possible the whole of the balance due from the father's estate. The mother-in-law replied that she (mother-in-law) had nothing more, the winding up was over, and there was due to them besides Barneville an income of six hundred francs, that she (mother-in-law) would pay them punctually.

Then Madame Bovary sent in accounts to two or three patients, and she (mother-in-law) made large use of this method, which was very successful. She (mother-in-law) was always careful to add a postscript:

``Do not mention this to my husband; you know how proud he (husband) is. Excuse me. Yours obediently.'' (She)
There were some complaints; she (mother-in-law) intercepted them.

To get money she (mother-in-law) began selling her (mother-in-law) old gloves, her (mother-in-law) old hats, the old odds and ends, and she (mother-in-law) bargained rapaciously, her (mother-in-law) peasant blood standing her (mother-in-law) in good stead. Then on her (mother-in-law) journey to town she (mother-in-law) picked up nick-nacks secondhand, that, in default of anyone else, Monsieur Lheureux would certainly take off her (mother-in-law) hands. She (mother-in-law) bought ostrich feathers, Chinese porcelain, and trunks; she (mother-in-law) borrowed from Felicite, from Madame Lefrancois, from the landlady at the Croix-Rouge, from everybody, no matter where.

With the money she (mother-in-law) at last received from Barneville she (mother-in-law) paid two bills; the other fifteen hundred francs fell due. She (mother-in-law) renewed the bills, and thus it was continually.

Sometimes, it is true, she (mother-in-law) tried to make a calculation, but she (mother-in-law) discovered things so exorbitant that she (mother-in-law) could not believe them possible. Then she (mother-in-law) recommenced, soon got confused, gave it all up, and thought no more about it.

The house was very dreary now. Tradesmen were seen leaving it with angry faces. Handkerchiefs were lying about on the stoves, and little Berthe, to the great scandal of Madame Homais, wore stockings with holes in them. If Charles timidly ventured a remark, she (mother-in-law) answered roughly that it wasn't her (mother-in-law) fault.

What was the meaning of all these fits of temper? He (Charles) explained everything through her (mother-in-law) old nervous illness, and reproaching himself with having taken her (mother-in-law) infirmities for faults, accused himself of egotism, and longed to go and take her (mother-in-law) in his (Charles) arms.

``Ah, no!'' (he)
he (Charles) said to himself;
``I should worry her (my).'' (he)

And he (Charles) did not stir.

After dinner he (Charles) walked about alone in the garden; he (Charles) took little Berthe on his (Charles) knees, and unfolding his (Charles) medical journal, tried to teach her (mother-in-law) to read. But the child, who never had any lessons, soon looked up with large, sad eyes and began to cry. Then he (Charles) comforted her (mother-in-law); went to fetch water in her (mother-in-law) can to make rivers on the sand path, or broke off branches from the privet hedges to plant trees in the beds. This did not spoil the garden much, all choked now with long weeds. They owed Lestiboudois for so many days. Then the child grew cold and asked for her (mother-in-law) mother.

``Call the servant,'' (Charles)
said Charles.
``You know, dearie, that mamma does not like to be disturbed.'' (she)

Autumn was setting in, and the leaves were already falling, as they did two years ago when she (mother-in-law) was ill. Where would it all end? And he (Charles) walked up and down, his (Charles) hands behind his (Charles) back.

Madame was in her (mother-in-law) room, which no one entered. She (mother-in-law) stayed there all day long, torpid, half dressed, and from time to time burning Turkish pastilles which she (mother-in-law) had bought at Rouen in an Algerian's shop. In order not to have at night this sleeping man stretched at her (mother-in-law) side, by dint of manoeuvring, she (mother-in-law) at last succeeded in banishing him (man) to the second floor, while she (mother-in-law) read till morning extravagant books, full of pictures of orgies and thrilling situations. Often, seized with fear, she (mother-in-law) cried out, and Charles hurried to her (mother-in-law).

``Oh, go away!'' (she)
she (mother-in-law) would say.

Or at other times, consumed more ardently than ever by that inner flame to which adultery added fuel, panting, tremulous, all desire, she (mother-in-law) threw open her (mother-in-law) window, breathed in the cold air, shook loose in the wind her (mother-in-law) masses of hair, too heavy, and, gazing upon the stars, longed for some princely love. She (mother-in-law) thought of him (Charles), of Leon. She (mother-in-law) would then have given anything for a single one of those meetings that surfeited her (mother-in-law).

These were her (mother-in-law) gala days. She (mother-in-law) wanted them to be sumptuous, and when he (Leon) alone could not pay the expenses, she (mother-in-law) made up the deficit liberally, which happened pretty well every time. He (Leon) tried to make her (mother-in-law) understand that they would be quite as comfortable somewhere else, in a smaller hotel, but she (mother-in-law) always found some objection.

One day she (mother-in-law) drew six small silver-gilt spoons from her (mother-in-law) bag -LRB-they were old Roualt's wedding present-RRB-, begging him (Leon) to pawn them at once for her (mother-in-law), and Leon obeyed, though the proceeding annoyed him (Leon). He (Leon) was afraid of compromising himself.

Then, on, reflection, he (Leon) began to think his (Leon) mistress's ways were growing odd, and that they were perhaps not wrong in wishing to separate him (Leon) from her (mistress).

In fact someone had sent his (Leon) mother a long anonymous letter to warn her (mother) that he (Leon) was

``ruining himself with a married woman,'' (he)
and the good lady at once conjuring up the eternal bugbear of families, the vague pernicious creature, the siren, the monster, who dwells fantastically in depths of love, wrote to Lawyer Dubocage, his (Lawyer) employer, who behaved perfectly in the affair. He (Lawyer) kept him (Lawyer) for three quarters of an hour trying to open his (Lawyer) eyes, to warn him (Lawyer) of the abyss into which he (Lawyer) was falling. Such an intrigue would damage him (Lawyer) later on, when he (Lawyer) set up for himself. He (Lawyer) implored him (Lawyer) to break with her (mother), and, if he (Lawyer) would not make this sacrifice in his (Lawyer) own interest, to do it at least for his (Lawyer), Dubocage's sake.

At last Leon swore he (Leon) would not see Emma again, and he (Leon) reproached himself with not having kept his (Leon) word, considering all the worry and lectures this woman might still draw down upon him (Leon), without reckoning the jokes made by his (Leon) companions as they sat round the stove in the morning. Besides, he (Leon) was soon to be head clerk; it was time to settle down. So he (Leon) gave up his (Leon) flute, exalted sentiments, and poetry; for every bourgeois in the flush of his (Leon) youth, were it but for a day, a moment, has believed himself capable of immense passions, of lofty enterprises. The most mediocre libertine has dreamed of sultanas; every notary bears within him (Leon) the debris of a poet.

He (Leon) was bored now when Emma suddenly began to sob on his (Leon) breast, and his (Leon) heart, like the people who can only stand a certain amount of music, dozed to the sound of a love whose delicacies he (Leon) no longer noted.

They knew one another too well for any of those surprises of possession that increase its joys a hundred-fold. She (Emma) was as sick of him (Leon) as he (Leon) was weary of her (Emma). Emma found again in adultery all the platitudes of marriage.

But how to get rid of him (Leon)? Then, though she (Emma) might feel humiliated at the baseness of such enjoyment, she (Emma) clung to it from habit or from corruption, and each day she (Emma) hungered after them the more, exhausting all felicity in wishing for too much of it. She (Emma) accused Leon of her (Emma) baffled hopes, as if he (Leon) had betrayed her (Emma); and she (Emma) even longed for some catastrophe that would bring about their separation, since she (Emma) had not the courage to make up her (Emma) mind to it herself.

She (Emma) none the less went on writing him (Leon) love letters, in virtue of the notion that a woman must write to her (woman) lover.

But whilst she (woman) wrote it was another man she (woman) saw, a phantom fashioned out of her (woman) most ardent memories, of her (woman) finest reading, her (woman) strongest lusts, and at last he (man) became so real, so tangible, that she (woman) palpitated wondering, without, however, the power to imagine him (man) clearly, so lost was he (man), like a god, beneath the abundance of his (man) attributes. He (man) dwelt in that azure land where silk ladders hang from balconies under the breath of flowers, in the light of the moon. She (woman) felt him (man) near her (woman); he (man) was coming, and would carry her (woman) right away in a kiss.

Then she (woman) fell back exhausted, for these transports of vague love wearied her (woman) more than great debauchery.

She (woman) now felt constant ache all over her (woman). Often she (woman) even received summonses, stamped paper that she (woman) barely looked at. She (woman) would have liked not to be alive, or to be always asleep.

On Mid-Lent she (woman) did not return to Yonville, but in the evening went to a masked ball. She (woman) wore velvet breeches, red stockings, a club wig, and three-cornered hat cocked on one side. She (woman) danced all night to the wild tones of the trombones; people gathered round her (woman), and in the morning she (woman) found herself on the steps of the theatre together with five or six masks, debardeuses* and sailors, Leon's comrades, who were talking about having supper.

* People dressed as longshoremen.

The neighbouring cafes were full. They caught sight of one on the harbour, a very indifferent restaurant, whose proprietor showed them to a little room on the fourth floor.

The men were whispering in a corner, no doubt consorting about expenses. There were a clerk, two medical students, and a shopman--what company for her (clerk)! As to the women, Emma soon perceived from the tone of their voices that they must almost belong to the lowest class. Then she (Emma) was frightened, pushed back her (Emma) chair, and cast down her (Emma) eyes.

The others began to eat; she (Emma) ate nothing. Her (Emma) head was on fire, her (Emma) eyes smarted, and her (Emma) skin was ice-cold. In her (Emma) head she (Emma) seemed to feel the floor of the ball-room rebounding again beneath the rhythmical pulsation of the thousands of dancing feet. And now the smell of the punch, the smoke of the cigars, made her (Emma) giddy. She (Emma) fainted, and they carried her (Emma) to the window.

Day was breaking, and a great stain of purple colour broadened out in the pale horizon over the St. Catherine hills. The livid river was shivering in the wind; there was no one on the bridges; the street lamps were going out.

She (Catherine) revived, and began thinking of Berthe asleep yonder in the servant's room. Then a cart filled with long strips of iron passed by, and made a deafening metallic vibration against the walls of the houses.

She (Catherine) slipped away suddenly, threw off her (Catherine) costume, told Leon she (Catherine) must get back, and at last was alone at the Hotel de Boulogne. Everything, even herself, was now unbearable to her (Catherine). She (Catherine) wished that, taking wing like a bird, she (Catherine) could fly somewhere, far away to regions of purity, and there grow young again.

She (Catherine) went out, crossed the Boulevard, the Place Cauchoise, and the Faubourg, as far as an open street that overlooked some gardens. She (Catherine) walked rapidly; the fresh air calming her (Catherine); and, little by little, the faces of the crowd, the masks, the quadrilles, the lights, the supper, those women, all disappeared like mists fading away. Then, reaching the

``Croix-Rouge,'' (she)
she (Catherine) threw herself on the bed in her (Catherine) little room on the second floor, where there were pictures of the
``Tour de Nesle.'' (she)
At four o’clock Hivert awoke her (Catherine).

When she (Catherine) got home, Felicite showed her (Catherine) behind the clock a grey paper. She (Catherine) read--

``In virtue of the seizure in execution of a judgment.'' (She)

What judgment? As a matter of fact, the evening before another paper had been brought that she (Catherine) had not yet seen, and she (Catherine) was stunned by these words--

``By order of the king, law, and justice, to Madame Bovary.'' (she)
Then, skipping several lines, she (Catherine) read,
``Within twenty-four hours, without fail--'' (she)
But what?
``To pay the sum of eight thousand francs.'' (unknown)
And there was even at the bottom,
``She (woman) will be constrained thereto by every form of law, and notably by a writ of distraint on her (woman) furniture and effects.'' (unknown)

What was to be done? In twenty-four hours--tomorrow. Lheureux, she (Catherine) thought, wanted to frighten her (Catherine) again; for she (Catherine) saw through all his (Hivert) devices, the object of his (Hivert) kindnesses. What reassured her (Catherine) was the very magnitude of the sum.

However, by dint of buying and not paying, of borrowing, signing bills, and renewing these bills that grew at each new falling-in, she (Catherine) had ended by preparing a capital for Monsieur Lheureux which he (Hivert) was impatiently awaiting for his (Hivert) speculations.

She (Catherine) presented herself at his (Hivert) place with an offhand air.

``You know what has happened to me? No doubt it's a joke!'' (unknown)

``How so?'' (He)

He (Hivert) turned away slowly, and, folding his (Hivert) arms, said to her (Catherine)--

``My good lady, did you think I should go on to all eternity being your purveyor and banker, for the love of God? Now be just. I must get back what I've laid out. Now be just.'' (He)

She (Catherine) cried out against the debt.

``Ah! so much the worse. The court has admitted it. There's a judgment. It's been notified to you. Besides, it isn't my fault. It's Vincart's.'' (unknown)

``Could you not--?'' (unknown)

``Oh, nothing whatever.'' (unknown)

``But still, now talk it over.'' (she)

And she (Catherine) began beating about the bush; she (Catherine) had known nothing about it; it was a surprise.

``Whose fault is that?'' (Lheureux/Monsieur Lheureux)
said Lheureux, bowing ironically.
``While I'm slaving like a nigger, you go gallivanting about.'' (unknown)

``Ah! no lecturing.'' (unknown)

``It never does any harm,'' (he)
he (bush) replied.

She (Catherine) turned coward; she (Catherine) implored him (bush); she (Catherine) even pressed her (Catherine) pretty white and slender hand against the shopkeeper's knee.

``There, that'll do! Anyone'd think you wanted to seduce me!'' (unknown)

``You are a wretch!'' (she)
she (Catherine) cried.

``Oh, oh! go it! go it!'' (unknown)

``I will show you up. I shall tell my husband.'' (unknown)

``All right! I too. I'll show your husband something.'' (Lheureux/Monsieur Lheureux)

And Lheureux drew from his (shopkeeper) strong box the receipt for eighteen hundred francs that she (Catherine) had given him (shopkeeper) when Vincart had discounted the bills.

``Do you think,'' (he)
he (shopkeeper) added,
``that he (husband)'ll not understand your little theft, the poor dear man?'' (he)

She (Catherine) collapsed, more overcome than if felled by the blow of a pole-axe. He (shopkeeper) was walking up and down from the window to the bureau, repeating all the while--

``Ah! I'll show him (husband)! I'll show him (husband)!'' (He)
Then he (shopkeeper) approached her (Catherine), and in a soft voice said--

``It isn't pleasant, I know; but, after all, no bones are broken, and, since that is the only way that is left for you paying back my money--'' (her)

``But where am I to get any?'' (her)
said Emma, wringing her (Emma) hands.

``Bah! when one has friends like you!'' (he)

And he (shopkeeper) looked at her (Emma) in so keen, so terrible a fashion, that she (Emma) shuddered to her (Emma) very heart.

``I promise you,'' (she)
she (Emma) said,
``to sign--'' (she)

``I've enough of your signatures.'' (she)

``I will sell something.'' (unknown)

``Get along!'' (he)
he (shopkeeper) said, shrugging his (shopkeeper) shoulders;
``you've not got anything.'' (he)

And he (shopkeeper) called through the peep-hole that looked down into the shop--

``Annette, don't forget the three coupons of No. 14.'' (he)

The servant appeared. Emma understood, and asked how much money would be wanted to put a stop to the proceedings.

``It is too late.'' (unknown)

``But if I brought you several thousand francs--a quarter of the sum--a third--perhaps the whole?'' (unknown)

``No; it's no use!'' (he)

And he (servant) pushed her (Emma) gently towards the staircase.

``I implore you, Monsieur Lheureux, just a few days more!'' (She)
She (Emma) was sobbing.

``There! tears now!'' (unknown)

``You are driving me to despair!'' (unknown)

``What do I care?'' (he)
said he (servant), shutting the door.

Chapter Seven

She (Emma) was stoical the next day when Maitre Hareng, the bailiff, with two assistants, presented himself at her (Emma) house to draw up the inventory for the distraint.

They began with Bovary's consulting-room, and did not write down the phrenological head, which was considered an

``instrument of his (you) profession'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)
; but in the kitchen they counted the plates; the saucepans, the chairs, the candlesticks, and in the bedroom all the nick-nacks on the whatnot. They examined her (Emma) dresses, the linen, the dressing-room; and her (Emma) whole existence to its most intimate details, was, like a corpse on whom a post-mortem is made, outspread before the eyes of these three men.

Maitre Hareng, buttoned up in his (Hareng) thin black coat, wearing a white choker and very tight foot-straps, repeated from time to time--

``Allow me, madame. You allow me?'' (Maitre Hareng)
Often he (Hareng) uttered exclamations.
``Charming! very pretty.'' (he)
Then he (Hareng) began writing again, dipping his (Hareng) pen into the horn inkstand in his (Hareng) left hand.

When they had done with the rooms they went up to the attic. She (Emma) kept a desk there in which Rodolphe's letters were locked. It had to be opened.

``Ah! a correspondence,'' (Maitre Hareng)
said Maitre Hareng, with a discreet smile.
``But allow me, for I must make sure the box contains nothing else.'' (he)
And he (Hareng) tipped up the papers lightly, as if to shake out napoleons. Then she (Emma) grew angered to see this coarse hand, with fingers red and pulpy like slugs, touching these pages against which her (Emma) heart had beaten.

They went at last. Felicite came back. Emma had sent her (Emma) out to watch for Bovary in order to keep him (Hareng) off, and they hurriedly installed the man in possession under the roof, where he (man) swore he (man) would remain.

During the evening Charles seemed to her (Emma) careworn. Emma watched him (Charles) with a look of anguish, fancying she (Emma) saw an accusation in every line of his (Charles) face. Then, when her (Emma) eyes wandered over the chimney-piece ornamented with Chinese screens, over the large curtains, the armchairs, all those things, in a word, that had, softened the bitterness of her (Emma) life, remorse seized her (Emma) or rather an immense regret, that, far from crushing, irritated her (Emma) passion. Charles placidly poked the fire, both his (Charles) feet on the fire-dogs.

Once the man, no doubt bored in his (man) hiding-place, made a slight noise.

``Is anyone walking upstairs?'' (Charles)
said Charles.

``No,'' (she)
she (Emma) replied;
``it is a window that has been left open, and is rattling in the wind.'' (she)

The next day, Sunday, she (Emma) went to Rouen to call on all the brokers whose names she (Emma) knew. They were at their country-places or on journeys. She (Emma) was not discouraged; and those whom she (Emma) did manage to see she (Emma) asked for money, declaring she (Emma) must have some, and that she (Emma) would pay it back. Some laughed in her (Emma) face; all refused.

At two o’clock she (Emma) hurried to Leon, and knocked at the door. No one answered. At length he (Leon) appeared.

``What brings you here?'' (unknown)

``Do I disturb you?'' (unknown)

``No; but--'' (he)
And he (Leon) admitted that his (Leon) landlord didn't like his (Leon) having
``women'' (he)
there.

``I must speak to you,'' (she)
she (Emma) went on.

Then he (Leon) took down the key, but she (Emma) stopped him (Leon).

``No, no! Down there, in our home!'' (unknown)

And they went to their room at the Hotel de Boulogne.

On arriving she (Emma) drank off a large glass of water. She (Emma) was very pale. She (Emma) said to him (Leon)--

``Leon, you will do me a service?'' (him)

And, shaking him (Leon) by both hands that she (Emma) grasped tightly, she (Emma) added--

``Listen, I want eight thousand francs.'' (she)

``But you are mad!'' (unknown)

``Not yet.'' (him)

And thereupon, telling him (Leon) the story of the distraint, she (Emma) explained her (Emma) distress to him (Leon); for Charles knew nothing of it; her (Emma) mother-in-law detested her (Emma); old Rouault could do nothing; but he (Rouault), Leon, he (Rouault) would set about finding this indispensable sum.

``How on earth can I?'' (unknown)

``What a coward you are!'' (she)
she (Emma) cried.

Then he (Rouault) said stupidly,

``You are exaggerating the difficulty. Perhaps, with a thousand crowns or so the fellow could be stopped.'' (he)

All the greater reason to try and do something; it was impossible that they could not find three thousand francs. Besides, Leon, could be security instead of her (Emma).

``Go, try, try! I will love you so!'' (He)

He (Leon) went out, and came back at the end of an hour, saying, with solemn face--

``I have been to three people with no success.'' (He)

Then they remained sitting face to face at the two chimney corners, motionless, in silence. Emma shrugged her (Emma) shoulders as she (Emma) stamped her (Emma) feet. He (Leon) heard her (Emma) murmuring--

``If I were in your place _I_ should soon get some.'' (He)

``But where?'' (unknown)

``At your office.'' (she)
And she (Emma) looked at him (Leon).

An infernal boldness looked out from her (Emma) burning eyes, and their lids drew close together with a lascivious and encouraging look, so that the young man felt himself growing weak beneath the mute will of this woman who was urging him (man) to a crime. Then he (man) was afraid, and to avoid any explanation he (man) smote his (man) forehead, crying--

``Morel is to come back to-night; he (Morel) will not refuse me, I hope'' (he)
-LRB-this was one of his (man) friends, the son of a very rich merchant-RRB-;
``and I will bring it you to-morrow,'' (a merchant)
he (man) added.

Emma did not seem to welcome this hope with all the joy he (man) had expected. Did she (Emma) suspect the lie? He (man) went on, blushing--

``However, if you don't see me by three o’clock do not wait for me, my darling. I must be off now; forgive me! Goodbye!'' (He)

He (man) pressed her (Emma) hand, but it felt quite lifeless. Emma had no strength left for any sentiment.

Four o’clock struck, and she (Emma) rose to return to Yonville, mechanically obeying the force of old habits.

The weather was fine. It was one of those March days, clear and sharp, when the sun shines in a perfectly white sky. The Rouen folk, in Sunday-clothes, were walking about with happy looks. She (Emma) reached the Place du Parvis. People were coming out after vespers; the crowd flowed out through the three doors like a stream through the three arches of a bridge, and in the middle one, more motionless than a rock, stood the beadle.

Then she (Emma) remembered the day when, all anxious and full of hope, she (Emma) had entered beneath this large nave, that had opened out before her (Emma), less profound than her (Emma) love; and she (Emma) walked on weeping beneath her (Emma) veil, giddy, staggering, almost fainting.

``Take care!'' (unknown)
cried a voice issuing from the gate of a courtyard that was thrown open.
