``I don't know! I don't know! It's a curse!'' (The druggist)

The druggist separated them.

``These horrible details are useless. I will tell this gentleman all about it. Here are the people coming. Dignity! Come now! Philosophy!'' (The fellow)

The poor fellow tried to show himself brave, and repeated several times.

``Yes! courage!'' (unknown)

``Oh,'' (the man)
cried the old man,
``so I will have, by God! I'll go along o' her (Emma) to the end!'' (the man)

The bell began tolling. All was ready; they had to start. And seated in a stall of the choir, side by side, they saw pass and repass in front of them continually the three chanting choristers.

The serpent-player was blowing with all his (man) might. Monsieur Bournisien, in full vestments, was singing in a shrill voice. He (man) bowed before the tabernacle, raising his (man) hands, stretched out his (man) arms. Lestiboudois went about the church with his (man) whalebone stick. The bier stood near the lectern, between four rows of candles. Charles felt inclined to get up and put them out.

Yet he (Charles) tried to stir himself to a feeling of devotion, to throw himself into the hope of a future life in which he (Charles) should see her (man) again. He (Charles) imagined to himself she (man) had gone on a long journey, far away, for a long time. But when he (Charles) thought of her (man) lying there, and that all was over, that they would lay her (man) in the earth, he (Charles) was seized with a fierce, gloomy, despairful rage. At times he (Charles) thought he (Charles) felt nothing more, and he (Charles) enjoyed this lull in his (Charles) pain, whilst at the same time he (Charles) reproached himself for being a wretch.

The sharp noise of an iron-ferruled stick was heard on the stones, striking them at irregular intervals. It came from the end of the church, and stopped short at the lower aisles. A man in a coarse brown jacket knelt down painfully. It was Hippolyte, the stable-boy at the

``Lion d’Or.'' (the stable-boy)
He (man) had put on his (man) new leg.

One of the choristers went round the nave making a collection, and the coppers chinked one after the other on the silver plate.

``Oh, make haste! I am in pain!'' (Madame Bovary/Bovary)
cried Bovary, angrily throwing him (man) a five-franc piece. The churchman thanked him (churchman) with a deep bow.

They sang, they knelt, they stood up; it was endless! He (churchman) remembered that once, in the early times, they had been to mass together, and they had sat down on the other side, on the right, by the wall. The bell began again. There was a great moving of chairs; the bearers slipped their three staves under the coffin, and everyone left the church.

Then Justin appeared at the door of the shop. He (Justin) suddenly went in again, pale, staggering.

People were at the windows to see the procession pass. Charles at the head walked erect. He (Charles) affected a brave air, and saluted with a nod those who, coming out from the lanes or from their doors, stood amidst the crowd.

The six men, three on either side, walked slowly, panting a little. The priests, the choristers, and the two choirboys recited the De profundis*, and their voices echoed over the fields, rising and falling with their undulations. Sometimes they disappeared in the windings of the path; but the great silver cross rose always before the trees.

*Psalm CXXX.

The women followed in black cloaks with turned-down hoods; each of them carried in her (women) hands a large lighted candle, and Charles felt himself growing weaker at this continual repetition of prayers and torches, beneath this oppressive odour of wax and of cassocks. A fresh breeze was blowing; the rye and colza were sprouting, little dewdrops trembled at the roadsides and on the hawthorn hedges. All sorts of joyous sounds filled the air; the jolting of a cart rolling afar off in the ruts, the crowing of a cock, repeated again and again, or the gambling of a foal running away under the apple-trees: The pure sky was fretted with rosy clouds; a bluish haze rested upon the cots covered with iris. Charles as he (Charles) passed recognised each courtyard. He (Charles) remembered mornings like this, when, after visiting some patient, he (Charles) came out from one and returned to her (Charles).

The black cloth bestrewn with white beads blew up from time to time, laying bare the coffin. The tired bearers walked more slowly, and it advanced with constant jerks, like a boat that pitches with every wave.

They reached the cemetery. The men went right down to a place in the grass where a grave was dug. They ranged themselves all round; and while the priest spoke, the red soil thrown up at the sides kept noiselessly slipping down at the corners.

Then when the four ropes were arranged the coffin was placed upon them. He (priest) watched it descend; it seemed descending for ever. At last a thud was heard; the ropes creaked as they were drawn up. Then Bournisien took the spade handed to him (priest) by Lestiboudois; with his (priest) left hand all the time sprinkling water, with the right he (priest) vigorously threw in a large spadeful; and the wood of the coffin, struck by the pebbles, gave forth that dread sound that seems to us the reverberation of eternity.

The ecclesiastic passed the holy water sprinkler to his (priest) neighbour. This was Homais. He (priest) swung it gravely, then handed it to Charles, who sank to his (Charles) knees in the earth and threw in handfuls of it, crying,

``Adieu!'' (Charles)
He (Charles) sent her (Lestiboudois) kisses; he (Charles) dragged himself towards the grave, to engulf himself with her (Lestiboudois). They led him (Charles) away, and he (Charles) soon grew calmer, feeling perhaps, like the others, a vague satisfaction that it was all over.

Old Rouault on his (Rouault) way back began quietly smoking a pipe, which Homais in his (Rouault) innermost conscience thought not quite the thing. He (Rouault) also noticed that Monsieur Binet had not been present, and that Tuvache had

``made off'' (Monsieur Tuvache/Tuvache)
after mass, and that Theodore, the notary's servant wore a blue coat,
``as if one could not have got a black coat, since that is the custom, by Jove!'' (the notary)
And to share his (Theodore) observations with others he (Theodore) went from group to group. They were deploring Emma's death, especially Lheureux, who had not failed to come to the funeral.

``Poor little woman! What a trouble for her (woman) husband!'' (The druggist)

The druggist continued,

``Do you know that but for me he (husband) would have committed some fatal attempt upon himself?'' (The druggist)

``Such a good woman! To think that I saw her (woman) only last Saturday in my shop.'' (unknown)

``I haven't had leisure,'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
said Homais,
``to prepare a few words that I would have cast upon her (woman) tomb.'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)

Charles on getting home undressed, and old Rouault put on his (Rouault) blue blouse. It was a new one, and as he (Rouault) had often during the journey wiped his (Rouault) eyes on the sleeves, the dye had stained his (Rouault) face, and the traces of tears made lines in the layer of dust that covered it.

Madame Bovary senior was with them. All three were silent. At last the old fellow sighed--

``Do you remember, my friend, that I went to Tostes once when you had just lost your first deceased? I consoled you at that time. I thought of something to say then, but now--'' (the fellow)
Then, with a loud groan that shook his (fellow) whole chest,
``Ah! this is the end for me, do you see! I saw my wife go, then my son, and now to-day it's my daughter.'' (He)

He (fellow) wanted to go back at once to Bertaux, saying that he (fellow) could not sleep in this house. He (fellow) even refused to see his (fellow) granddaughter.

``No, no! It would grieve me too much. Only you'll kiss her (daughter) many times for me. Good-bye! you're a good fellow! And then I shall never forget that,'' (he)
he (fellow) said, slapping his (fellow) thigh.
``Never fear, you shall always have your turkey.'' (he)

But when he (fellow) reached the top of the hill he (fellow) turned back, as he (fellow) had turned once before on the road of Saint-Victor when he (fellow) had parted from her (granddaughter). The windows of the village were all on fire beneath the slanting rays of the sun sinking behind the field. He (fellow) put his (fellow) hand over his (fellow) eyes, and saw in the horizon an enclosure of walls, where trees here and there formed black clusters between white stones; then he (fellow) went on his (fellow) way at a gentle trot, for his (fellow) nag had gone lame.

Despite their fatigue, Charles and his (Charles) mother stayed very long that evening talking together. They spoke of the days of the past and of the future. She (mother) would come to live at Yonville; she (mother) would keep house for him (Charles); they would never part again. She (mother) was ingenious and caressing, rejoicing in her (mother) heart at gaining once more an affection that had wandered from her (mother) for so many years. Midnight struck. The village as usual was silent, and Charles, awake, thought always of her (mother).

Rodolphe, who, to distract himself, had been rambling about the wood all day, was sleeping quietly in his (Rodolphe) chateau, and Leon, down yonder, always slept.

There was another who at that hour was not asleep.

On the grave between the pine-trees a child was on his (Leon) knees weeping, and his (Leon) heart, rent by sobs, was beating in the shadow beneath the load of an immense regret, sweeter than the moon and fathomless as the night. The gate suddenly grated. It was Lestiboudois; he (Leon) came to fetch his (Leon) spade, that he (Leon) had forgotten. He (Leon) recognised Justin climbing over the wall, and at last knew who was the culprit who stole his (culprit) potatoes.

Chapter Eleven

The next day Charles had the child brought back. She (culprit) asked for her (culprit) mamma. They told her (culprit) she (culprit) was away; that she (culprit) would bring her (culprit) back some playthings. Berthe spoke of her (culprit) again several times, then at last thought no more of her (culprit). The child's gaiety broke Bovary's heart, and he (Charles) had to bear besides the intolerable consolations of the chemist.

Money troubles soon began again, Monsieur Lheureux urging on anew his (Charles) friend Vincart, and Charles pledged himself for exorbitant sums; for he (Charles) would never consent to let the smallest of the things that had belonged to HER be sold. His (Charles) mother was exasperated with him (Charles); he (Charles) grew even more angry than she (mother) did. He (Charles) had altogether changed. She (mother) left the house.

Then everyone began

``taking advantage'' (everyone)
of him (Charles). Mademoiselle Lempereur presented a bill for six months' teaching, although Emma had never taken a lesson -LRB-despite the receipted bill she (Emma) had shown Bovary-RRB-; it was an arrangement between the two women. The man at the circulating library demanded three years' subscriptions; Mere Rollet claimed the postage due for some twenty letters, and when Charles asked for an explanation, she (Emma) had the delicacy to reply--

``Oh, I don't know. It was for her (daughter) business affairs.'' (she)

With every debt he (Charles) paid Charles thought he (Charles) had come to the end of them. But others followed ceaselessly. He (Charles) sent in accounts for professional attendance. He (Charles) was shown the letters his (Charles) wife had written. Then he (Charles) had to apologise.

Felicite now wore Madame Bovary's gowns; not all, for he (Charles) had kept some of them, and he (Charles) went to look at them in her (wife) dressing-room, locking himself up there; she (wife) was about her (wife) height, and often Charles, seeing her (wife) from behind, was seized with an illusion, and cried out--

``Oh, stay, stay!'' (Charles)

But at Whitsuntide she (wife) ran away from Yonville, carried off by Theodore, stealing all that was left of the wardrobe.

It was about this time that the widow Dupuis had the honour to inform him (Dupuis) of the

``marriage of Monsieur Leon Dupuis her (daughter) son, notary at Yvetot, to Mademoiselle Leocadie Leboeuf of Bondeville.'' (him)
Charles, among the other congratulations he (Charles) sent him (Charles), wrote this sentence--

``How glad my poor wife would have been!'' (him)

One day when, wandering aimlessly about the house, he (Charles) had gone up to the attic, he (Charles) felt a pellet of fine paper under his (Charles) slipper. He (Charles) opened it and read:

``Courage, Emma, courage. I would not bring misery into your life.'' (He)
It was Rodolphe's letter, fallen to the ground between the boxes, where it had remained, and that the wind from the dormer window had just blown towards the door. And Charles stood, motionless and staring, in the very same place where, long ago, Emma, in despair, and paler even than he (Charles), had thought of dying. At last he (Charles) discovered a small R at the bottom of the second page. What did this mean? He (Charles) remembered Rodolphe's attentions, his (Charles) sudden, disappearance, his (Charles) constrained air when they had met two or three times since. But the respectful tone of the letter deceived him (Charles).

``Perhaps they loved one another platonically,'' (he)
he (Charles) said to himself.

Besides, Charles was not of those who go to the bottom of things; he (Charles) shrank from the proofs, and his (Charles) vague jealousy was lost in the immensity of his (Charles) woe.

Everyone, he (Charles) thought, must have adored her (Charles); all men assuredly must have coveted her (Charles). She (Charles) seemed but the more beautiful to him (Charles) for this; he (Charles) was seized with a lasting, furious desire for her (Charles), that inflamed his (Charles) despair, and that was boundless, because it was now unrealisable.

To please her (Charles), as if she (Charles) were still living, he (Charles) adopted her (Charles) predilections, her (Charles) ideas; he (Charles) bought patent leather boots and took to wearing white cravats. He (Charles) put cosmetics on his (Charles) moustache, and, like her (Charles), signed notes of hand. She (Charles) corrupted him (Charles) from beyond the grave.

He (Charles) was obliged to sell his (Charles) silver piece by piece; next he (Charles) sold the drawing-room furniture. All the rooms were stripped; but the bedroom, her (Charles) own room, remained as before. After his (Charles) dinner Charles went up there. He (Charles) pushed the round table in front of the fire, and drew up her (Charles) armchair. He (Charles) sat down opposite it. A candle burnt in one of the gilt candlesticks. Berthe by his (Charles) side was painting prints.

He (Charles) suffered, poor man, at seeing her (Charles) so badly dressed, with laceless boots, and the arm-holes of her (Charles) pinafore torn down to the hips; for the charwoman took no care of her (Charles). But she (Charles) was so sweet, so pretty, and her (Charles) little head bent forward so gracefully, letting the dear fair hair fall over her (Charles) rosy cheeks, that an infinite joy came upon him (Charles), a happiness mingled with bitterness, like those ill-made wines that taste of resin. He (Charles) mended her (Charles) toys, made her (Charles) puppets from cardboard, or sewed up half-torn dolls. Then, if his (Charles) eyes fell upon the workbox, a ribbon lying about, or even a pin left in a crack of the table, he (Charles) began to dream, and looked so sad that she (Charles) became as sad as he (Charles).

No one now came to see them, for Justin had run away to Rouen, where he (Justin) was a grocer's assistant, and the druggist's children saw less and less of the child, Monsieur Homais not caring, seeing the difference of their social position, to continue the intimacy.

The blind man, whom he (man) had not been able to cure with the pomade, had gone back to the hill of Bois-Guillaume, where he (man) told the travellers of the vain attempt of the druggist, to such an extent, that Homais when he (man) went to town hid himself behind the curtains of the

``Hirondelle'' (he)
to avoid meeting him (man). He (man) detested him (man), and wishing, in the interests of his (man) own reputation, to get rid of him (man) at all costs, he (man) directed against him (man) a secret battery, that betrayed the depth of his (man) intellect and the baseness of his (man) vanity. Thus, for six consecutive months, one could read in the
``Fanal de Rouen'' (unknown)
editorials such as these--

``All who bend their steps towards the fertile plains of Picardy have, no doubt, remarked, by the Bois-Guillaume hill, a wretch suffering from a horrible facial wound. He (Dupuis) importunes, persecutes one, and levies a regular tax on all travellers. Are we still living in the monstrous times of the Middle Ages, when vagabonds were permitted to display in our public places leprosy and scrofulas they had brought back from the Crusades?'' (unknown)

Or--

``In spite of the laws against vagabondage, the approaches to our great towns continue to be infected by bands of beggars. Some are seen going about alone, and these are not, perhaps, the least dangerous. What are our ediles about?'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)

Then Homais invented anecdotes--

``Yesterday, by the Bois-Guillaume hill, a skittish horse--'' (Homais/Monsieur Homais)
And then followed the story of an accident caused by the presence of the blind man.

He (man) managed so well that the fellow was locked up. But he (fellow) was released. He (fellow) began again, and Homais began again. It was a struggle. Homais won it, for his (fellow) foe was condemned to life-long confinement in an asylum.

This success emboldened him (fellow), and henceforth there was no longer a dog run over, a barn burnt down, a woman beaten in the parish, of which he (fellow) did not immediately inform the public, guided always by the love of progress and the hate of priests. He (fellow) instituted comparisons between the elementary and clerical schools to the detriment of the latter; called to mind the massacre of St. Bartholomew a propos of a grant of one hundred francs to the church, and denounced abuses, aired new views. That was his (Bartholomew) phrase. Homais was digging and delving; he (Bartholomew) was becoming dangerous.

However, he (Bartholomew) was stifling in the narrow limits of journalism, and soon a book, a work was necessary to him (Bartholomew). Then he (Bartholomew) composed

``General Statistics of the Canton of Yonville, followed by Climatological Remarks.'' (he)
The statistics drove him (Bartholomew) to philosophy. He (Bartholomew) busied himself with great questions: the social problem, moralisation of the poorer classes, pisciculture, caoutchouc, railways, etc.. He (Bartholomew) even began to blush at being a bourgeois. He (Bartholomew) affected the artistic style, he (Bartholomew) smoked. He (Bartholomew) bought two chic Pompadour statuettes to adorn his (Bartholomew) drawing-room.

He (Bartholomew) by no means gave up his (Bartholomew) shop. On the contrary, he (Bartholomew) kept well abreast of new discoveries. He (Bartholomew) followed the great movement of chocolates; he (Bartholomew) was the first to introduce

``cocoa'' (he)
and
``revalenta'' (he)
into the Seine-Inferieure. He (Bartholomew) was enthusiastic about the hydro-electric Pulvermacher chains; he (Bartholomew) wore one himself, and when at night he (Bartholomew) took off his (Bartholomew) flannel vest, Madame Homais stood quite dazzled before the golden spiral beneath which he (Bartholomew) was hidden, and felt her (Bartholomew) ardour redouble for this man more bandaged than a Scythian, and splendid as one of the Magi.

He (Bartholomew) had fine ideas about Emma's tomb. First he (Bartholomew) proposed a broken column with some drapery, next a pyramid, then a Temple of Vesta, a sort of rotunda, or else a

``mass of ruins.'' (he)
And in all his (Bartholomew) plans Homais always stuck to the weeping willow, which he (Bartholomew) looked upon as the indispensable symbol of sorrow.

Charles and he (Charles) made a journey to Rouen together to look at some tombs at a funeral furnisher's, accompanied by an artist, one Vaufrylard, a friend of Bridoux's, who made puns all the time. At last, after having examined some hundred designs, having ordered an estimate and made another journey to Rouen, Charles decided in favour of a mausoleum, which on the two principal sides was to have a

``spirit bearing an extinguished torch.'' (Charles)

As to the inscription, Homais could think of nothing so fine as Sta viator*, and he (viator) got no further; he (viator) racked his (viator) brain, he (viator) constantly repeated Sta viator. At last he (viator) hit upon Amabilen conjugem calcas**, which was adopted.

* Rest traveler.

** Tread upon a loving wife.

A strange thing was that Bovary, while continually thinking of Emma, was forgetting her (Emma). He (traveler) grew desperate as he (traveler) felt this image fading from his (traveler) memory in spite of all efforts to retain it. Yet every night he (traveler) dreamt of her (Emma); it was always the same dream. He (traveler) drew near her (Emma), but when he (traveler) was about to clasp her (Emma) she (Emma) fell into decay in his (traveler) arms.

For a week he (traveler) was seen going to church in the evening. Monsieur Bournisien even paid him (traveler) two or three visits, then gave him (traveler) up. Moreover, the old fellow was growing intolerant, fanatic, said Homais. He (fellow) thundered against the spirit of the age, and never failed, every other week, in his (fellow) sermon, to recount the death agony of Voltaire, who died devouring his (fellow) excrements, as everyone knows.

In spite of the economy with which Bovary lived, he (fellow) was far from being able to pay off his (fellow) old debts. Lheureux refused to renew any more bills. A distraint became imminent. Then he (fellow) appealed to his (fellow) mother, who consented to let him (fellow) take a mortgage on her (mother) property, but with a great many recriminations against Emma; and in return for her (Emma) sacrifice she (Emma) asked for a shawl that had escaped the depredations of Felicite. Charles refused to give it her (Emma); they quarrelled.

She (Emma) made the first overtures of reconciliation by offering to have the little girl, who could help her (Emma) in the house, to live with her (Emma). Charles consented to this, but when the time for parting came, all his (Charles) courage failed him (Charles). Then there was a final, complete rupture.

As his (Charles) affections vanished, he (Charles) clung more closely to the love of his (Charles) child. She (Emma) made him (Charles) anxious, however, for she (Emma) coughed sometimes, and had red spots on her (Emma) cheeks.

Opposite his (Charles) house, flourishing and merry, was the family of the chemist, with whom everything was prospering. Napoleon helped him (Napoleon) in the laboratory, Athalie embroidered him (Napoleon) a skullcap, Irma cut out rounds of paper to cover the preserves, and Franklin recited Pythagoras' table in a breath. He (Franklin) was the happiest of fathers, the most fortunate of men.

Not so! A secret ambition devoured him (Franklin). Homais hankered after the cross of the Legion of Honour. He (Franklin) had plenty of claims to it.

``First, having at the time of the cholera distinguished myself by a boundless devotion; second, by having published, at my expense, various works of public utility, such as'' (he)
-LRB-and he (Franklin) recalled his (Franklin) pamphlet entitled,
``Cider, its manufacture and effects,'' (he)
besides observation on the lanigerous plant-louse, sent to the Academy; his (Franklin) volume of statistics, and down to his (Franklin) pharmaceutical thesis-RRB-;
``without counting that I am a member of several learned societies'' (he)
-LRB-he (Franklin) was member of a single one-RRB-.

``In short!'' (he)
he (Franklin) cried, making a pirouette,
``if it were only for distinguishing myself at fires!'' (he)

Then Homais inclined towards the Government. He (Franklin) secretly did the prefect great service during the elections. He (Franklin) sold himself--in a word, prostituted himself. He (Franklin) even addressed a petition to the sovereign in which he (Franklin) implored him (Franklin) to

``do him (member) justice'' (him)
; he (Franklin) called him (Franklin)
``our good king,'' (him)
and compared him (Franklin) to Henri IV.

And every morning the druggist rushed for the paper to see if his (Henri) nomination were in it. It was never there. At last, unable to bear it any longer, he (Henri) had a grass plot in his (Henri) garden designed to represent the Star of the Cross of Honour with two little strips of grass running from the top to imitate the ribband. He (Henri) walked round it with folded arms, meditating on the folly of the Government and the ingratitude of men.

From respect, or from a sort of sensuality that made him (Henri) carry on his (Henri) investigations slowly, Charles had not yet opened the secret drawer of a rosewood desk which Emma had generally used. One day, however, he (Charles) sat down before it, turned the key, and pressed the spring. All Leon's letters were there. There could be no doubt this time. He (Leon) devoured them to the very last, ransacked every corner, all the furniture, all the drawers, behind the walls, sobbing, crying aloud, distraught, mad. He (Leon) found a box and broke it open with a kick. Rodolphe's portrait flew full in his (Leon) face in the midst of the overturned love-letters.

People wondered at his (Leon) despondency. He (Leon) never went out, saw no one, refused even to visit his (Leon) patients. Then they said

``he (king) shut himself up to drink.'' (some person)

Sometimes, however, some curious person climbed on to the garden hedge, and saw with amazement this long-bearded, shabbily clothed, wild man, who wept aloud as he (man) walked up and down.

In the evening in summer he (man) took his (man) little girl with him (man) and led her (girl) to the cemetery. They came back at nightfall, when the only light left in the Place was that in Binet's window.

The voluptuousness of his (man) grief was, however, incomplete, for he (man) had no one near him (man) to share it, and he (man) paid visits to Madame Lefrancois to be able to speak of her (girl).

But the landlady only listened with half an ear, having troubles like himself. For Lheureux had at last established the

``Favorites du Commerce,'' (Lheureux/Monsieur Lheureux)
and Hivert, who enjoyed a great reputation for doing errands, insisted on a rise of wages, and was threatening to go over
``to the opposition shop.'' (Hivert)

One day when he (man) had gone to the market at Argueil to sell his (man) horse--his (man) last resource--he (man) met Rodolphe.

They both turned pale when they caught sight of one another. Rodolphe, who had only sent his (Rodolphe) card, first stammered some apologies, then grew bolder, and even pushed his (Rodolphe) assurance -LRB-it was in the month of August and very hot-RRB- to the length of inviting him (Rodolphe) to have a bottle of beer at the public-house.

Leaning on the table opposite him (Rodolphe), he (Rodolphe) chewed his (Rodolphe) cigar as he (Rodolphe) talked, and Charles was lost in reverie at this face that she (man) had loved. He (Charles) seemed to see again something of her (man) in it. It was a marvel to him (Charles). He (Charles) would have liked to have been this man.

The other went on talking agriculture, cattle, pasturage, filling out with banal phrases all the gaps where an allusion might slip in. Charles was not listening to him (Charles); Rodolphe noticed it, and he (Rodolphe) followed the succession of memories that crossed his (Rodolphe) face. This gradually grew redder; the nostrils throbbed fast, the lips quivered. There was at last a moment when Charles, full of a sombre fury, fixed his (Charles) eyes on Rodolphe, who, in something of fear, stopped talking. But soon the same look of weary lassitude came back to his (Rodolphe) face.

``I don't blame you,'' (he)
he (Rodolphe) said.

Rodolphe was dumb. And Charles, his (Charles) head in his (Charles) hands, went on in a broken voice, and with the resigned accent of infinite sorrow--

``No, I don't blame you now.'' (Charles)

He (Charles) even added a fine phrase, the only one he (Charles) ever made--

``It is the fault of fatality!'' (he)

Rodolphe, who had managed the fatality, thought the remark very offhand from a man in his (Rodolphe) position, comic even, and a little mean.

The next day Charles went to sit down on the seat in the arbour. Rays of light were straying through the trellis, the vine leaves threw their shadows on the sand, the jasmines perfumed the air, the heavens were blue, Spanish flies buzzed round the lilies in bloom, and Charles was suffocating like a youth beneath the vague love influences that filled his (Charles) aching heart.

At seven o’clock little Berthe, who had not seen him (Charles) all the afternoon, went to fetch him (Charles) to dinner.

His (Charles) head was thrown back against the wall, his (Charles) eyes closed, his (Charles) mouth open, and in his (Charles) hand was a long tress of black hair.

``Come along, papa,'' (she)
she (Charles) said.

And thinking he (Charles) wanted to play; she (Charles) pushed him (Charles) gently. He (Charles) fell to the ground. He (Charles) was dead.

Thirty-six hours after, at the druggist's request, Monsieur Canivet came thither. He (Charles) made a post-mortem and found nothing.

When everything had been sold, twelve francs seventy-five centimes remained, that served to pay for Mademoiselle Bovary's going to her (Charles) grandmother. The good woman died the same year; old Rouault was paralysed, and it was an aunt who took charge of her (aunt). She (aunt) is poor, and sends her (aunt) to a cotton-factory to earn a living.

Since Bovary's death three doctors have followed one another at Yonville without any success, so severely did Homais attack them. He (Rouault) has an enormous practice; the authorities treat him (Rouault) with consideration, and public opinion protects him (Rouault).

He (Rouault) has just received the cross of the Legion of Honour.
